PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, when I began my remarks on the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill in May--
—It has been a long time.
—As my colleague says, that was a very long time ago.
—Now you have thought of something to say.

—Other events have transpired, such as the Budget performance last night. I drew attention then to the fact that this Bill has three main purposes. The first is to remove the distinction between trading and savings banks; the second is to provide the phasing out of statutory reserve deposits (SRDs); the third is to provide specific powers for the establishment of prudential requirements in respect of the banks and their administration by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The first part of this matter is rather dry and technical; I hope I can liven it up after that. The first part of the Bill is to remove the distinction between the trading and savings banks. This reflects the fact that in recent years most savings bank subsidiaries of banks have existed not as distinct physical or managerial structures but as different sets of accounts within banking groups. The removal of the distinction between them will enable banks to have better use and allocation of funds, more simple funding and accounting requirements, and greater flexibility in servicing customers.

SPEECH.PARA: The second purpose of the Bill is to phase out statutory reserve deposits. The statutory reserve deposit requirement dates from the early 1940s and was designed as an instrument of monetary policy. By adjusting the SRD ratio the Reserve Bank could add to or reduce liquidity in the banking system and, hence, banks' capacity to lend funds. This was a somewhat blunt but pretty effective instrument. With the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System a more market-oriented approach to monetary policy implementation was adopted and the SRD lapsed as a tool of monetary policy. In the circumstances, the SRDs continued to have something of a distorting effect as they acted to increase the cost of trading bank lending because of the relatively low interest rates paid on SRD funds, thus diverting business to savings and other non-bank financial institutions and encouraging banks to fund their operations through sources other than Australian dollar deposits.

While the SRD was somewhat primitive and inefficient it nevertheless acted very directly on the quantity of money. In the context of the new deregulated order that began to emerge, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in January 1985 discarded-altogether too lightly, I suggest-taking account of the quantity of money; monetary targeting, as it was then called. Yet over the past 12 months, for example, we find-and we do not have to look further for this than the figures that always appear on the back page of the Economist-the money supply in Australia increased by 26.8 per cent, compared with 9.4 per cent in Japan, 5.3 per cent in Germany, and 4.2 per cent in the United States. The increase in Australia is a very large increase. It was at an annual rate of no less than 49.2 per cent in the month of June last. As one commentator put it, `Money has been loose beyond belief in this country'. Provided one is prepared to pay the high interest rates, credit funds have been very easy to obtain.

This has been a recipe for volatile speculation, especially in property, up to a few months ago, on top of the overheated economy. The Hawke-Keating Government, and I am unhappy to say the Reserve Bank of Australia, must accept a heavy responsibility for the loose credit availability which, over the past year or so, has so fed inflation and excess demand in this economy. At the same time average families with housing mort- gages have had to cope with increases of upwards of 40 per cent in their mortgage repayments making severe inroads into their budgets and standards of living.

The third major purpose of the Bill, as I said, is to provide for the prudential supervision of the banking systems by the Reserve Bank, as distinct from the implementing of monetary policy. In fact, it formalises what are already reasonably well established practices for the prudential supervision of the banking system. In these terms the Bill is a natural culmination of the process of deregulation of the system over the past eight to 10 years. I say eight to 10 years because that is at least how long-it has probably been even longer-the process has been under way. While the Australian Labor Party has claimed a lot of credit for the deregulation of the financial system, the matter needs to be seen in perspective. I give credit where it is due but not more than that. In fact, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), as Treasurer in the Fraser Government, began the process by setting up the Campbell Committee which reported in September 1981. This was followed by the Martin Committee. The relaxation of more direct controls of the system began in 1981-82 and applications for the entry of foreign banks were actually called before the Fraser Government was defeated in 1983.

Whatever the claims of the Government, there was an inevitability about all this. Even the freeing up of the exchange rate at the end of 1983 was largely because the number, size and sophistication of the players in the foreign exchange market were such that the Government, in the end, had little choice but to substantially deregulate the market. I will give credit where it is due: the Government took the necessary decisions in these matters with the minimum of disruption. The trouble is that, for reasons I will not elaborate on in this debate, the deregulation largely ended with the financial system and did not extend into other crucial areas of the economy, especially into the rigid and highly centralised wages and industrial relations system.

The case for the Reserve Bank to prudentially supervise banks is unquestioned but there are not lacking people who would seek to limit this, maybe even to seek a measure of re-regulation, certainly a more significant monitoring of the banks-including in particular bank charges-in the present context of apparently record bank profits and murderously high interest rates. Of course, plenty of attacks are being made on the banks, as witness many Government speakers when this debate was held in the previous session, with the Treasurer, then quoted several times, leading the charge. I recall his statement of 17 April:
As soon as they (the banks) see some of that profit growth being threatened, they are out there squealing like stuck pigs on television every time they get a chance.
This comment was especially directed at the Treasurer's pet target, Mr Nobby Clark, the head of the National Australia Bank.

By and large, I believe that these attacks which are being made on the banks are ill-informed and without justification. If one relates profits to the capital invested, then one sees that there has been something of a decline in the level of bank earnings with the greater degree of competition in recent years. Again, if one studies the process closely one sees that the banks have, generally speaking, delayed rises in their rates in the wake of increases in the costs of funds to them.

In fact, it is not the banks, nor the process of deregulation itself-a process which often attracts the criticism, wrongly, that the murderous level of interest rates is the fault of deregulation-but rather the wrong-headed and failed economic policies of this Government that are to blame for the very high interest rates and the very serious economic problems facing the country.

In referring to interest rates, the truth is that the 17 per cent mortgage rate is exactly what the Government was aiming to achieve in order to cut the demand for housing. But, in relation to overall policy, the basic manifestation of the Government's failure is the vast continuing gap, the deficit, in our balance of payments and the frightening growth in the overseas debt, from the order of $30 billion in 1983 to a gross debt in excess of $130 billion today, and rising.

It may be, as someone said on the radio this morning, that there is a wider understanding out there of this whole matter, but people need to get a very clear picture of this. The debt rises inexorably every second of every hour of every day, so that right now the country is some $50m more into hock than it was at this time yesterday. If the balance of payments deficit comes in today, as is widely predicted, at nearer $2 billion for the month, we are talking about going an extra $70m into hock every day.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worrying the people.

—It does worry the people. A suggestion is often made by the Treasurer that this matter of the debt is something that is not so serious, that it is rather remote from the man in the street. But that is very much not the case. There was a reference recently to the debt clock that was set up in New York. As the United States has moved into debtor country status, but with not nearly as great a problem as us, the clock ticks away over New York to bring home how fast and frighteningly the debt problem grows. We need such a clock here. This debt will forever be the monument to, if you can call it that, the measure of the failure, the lamentable legacy of, the Keating years-worse indeed than the Whitlam years.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we have this Budget which was brought down last night. It has as its centrepiece the $9.1 billion surplus, but that stems from the great revenue flows from the taxes imposed by this highest taxing government in all Australia's history. There is no doubt that it is something of a `fix' when we allow for asset sales in the phoney role as a reduction of Government spending or bringing tax payments by companies up front, having them pay early accounting for something like $800m-also the extent of last year's revenue brought into this year, and such factors. When we take all those factors into account, with no significant cut in the Commonwealth's own real spending-though let me acknowledge as good the programs for pensioners, homeless youth and the other social justice initiatives-we see that this is not a strong Budget; if anything, it is an easing of fiscal policy. So we have that easing, we have the prospect of continued murderous high interest rates to slow further private demand, since very little has been done to slow government demand, but in the key policy area of measures to increase production and productivity--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is central.

—As my colleague says, that is central, the key thrust of policy-there is nothing new other than a proposal to extend the Industries Assistance Commission into an Industry Commission. If aggregate output next year is projected to grow at 2 3/4 per cent, so also is employment, and so the very projection is for no measurable productivity growth. The key thrust of policy must be in increasing the nation's production through increased productivity. That production is the nation's income. When one is in debt, is it not the first priority to increase one's income, as well as to save more-to reduce one's spending, in other words-in order to meet interest payments and to begin to pay off debt? This applies to the nation as well as to individuals. It is in this critical area of increasing production, particularly through increased productivity, where the Government has failed abysmally.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard much about the investment boom of recent times, but even Budget Statement No. 2 shows that the bulk of that is in the non-tradable goods area. Therefore, it does not bear directly on the important increased production for export or import replacement. Further, what is crucial in the process is the whole area of micro-economic reform, including changes to the rigid and inflexible wages and industrial relations system; changes to allow for increased productivity on the wharves, in coastal shipping, in virtually every form of transport and communications; and improved management practice and the ceasing of restrictive work practices which so hold back productivity across the nation and impoverish everybody. Such reform also includes the privatisation of publicly owned businesses for greater efficiency, and so on. As I have said, we only have to state those prerequisites of micro-economic policy to understand why fundamental economic progress has been so limited and productivity growth so abysmal under this Government.

As I said, all we had in the Budget Papers last night was reference to a new Industry Commission. There was no advance on the weak approach to reforms on the wharves and shipping. Yesterday, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) referred to the so-called Waterfront Industry Reform Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Yes, my colleague might well spurn it. It is a cosy cabal between the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and the stevedoring companies which does not bring into the picture at all the importers and exporters who are so disadvantaged by the arrangements which prevail there. When it comes to coastal shipping the Government says there needs to be consultation. That is what that industry was told to do in the statement in the chamber last May. There was no reference to the absolute necessity for increased competition, for exposure to foreign-Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development-competition, which is the only way to any effective achievement in that area. We do get these things because, of course, by the nature of the Government's main constituency, the trade unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, significant change in most of those areas is `not on'; and privatisation is blackballed by the left wing of the Labor Party. As I have said, there is only one recipe for this nation: when the election does come about, it is to change the Government to enable this side of the House to implement these essential reforms for the future of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is usual to commence debate on a matter such as the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill by going straight to the heart of the subject, but I have been so delighted by the opportunities for cheap point scoring that the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) has placed in my way that for once I will give in to temptation and strike whilst the iron is hot. Essentially, what we have heard exposes the paucity of the Opposition's whole response to the economic environment that Australia finds itself in.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard criticism of the Government's micro-economic policy, its waterfront reform and its plans to move cooperatively with the trade union movement and employers to make sure that Australia can respond effectively to what is a difficult, and accepted to be difficult, position on the waterfront. But what is the Opposition's solution? I suppose that it wants national strikes, in the same way as it wants national strikes as a consequence of its wages policy. The Opposition rejects entirely the accord proposals as a way of enabling government, the trade union movement and employers to accept moderation in wage outcomes in Australia, thus forgoing the bloodbath of industrial crisis that would arise from a wages free-for-all. The Liberals' wages policy is demonstrated by the airline dispute. The Liberals' wages policy would permit demands such as that of the pilots for a 30 per cent wage rise outside indexation guidelines. When the Liberals talk about deregulating the wages market they are talking about a bloodbath, a free-for-all, where the winner takes what he can, where the strong exploit their economic position and the weak accept what limited outcomes they can achieve.

Of course, some might say that, as a result of such a disruptive and unsettled industrial climate, in which the strike rate rises to what it was under previous Liberal administrations, with an economy damaged by strikes in key sectors such as airlines, ports and the like, somehow from this ruination the Australian economy might rise phoenix-like out of the ashes. I suggest that that is complete and utter nonsense. If one starts by smashing the underpinnings of cooperation that exist between those working in partnership in industry and sets those people against each other, one is hardly providing a recipe for a jolly, happy outcome. In fact, the obvious consequence of such a wages policy would be years of unsettled economic conditions in Australia, with Australia's competitiveness facing increased pressure as the powerful within the industrial wings of the labour movement take what they can by way of strike action and threats of industrial dislocation.

Let us remember that there is still a time of significant firmness in the labour market. The labour movement is not weak and powerless. Its acceptance of the need for restraint so that the Australian economic position can be strengthened is one of the great successes of the Labor Government and one of the key reasons why all the prognostications and blatherings that we hear from the Liberal Party are as nothing in terms of its capacity to come to an effective outcome that would persuade the Australian people that it is worth its salt.

I now return to the Bill. The honourable member for Berowra identified in his initial remarks the three key elements of this legislation. The first element is to eliminate the distinction between savings and trading banks. Increasingly over time their functions have intermeshed. There really is no point in maintaining the paper fiction as to what was a savings bank and a trading bank function and, as those institutions have evolved and new banking products have come on to the marketplace, I think it has been broadly accepted that those distinctions are no longer appropriate. So this Bill undoes some of the technical rules that had limited the flexibility of banking institutions. It is welcomed across the board by this Government, by the Opposition and I believe also by the banking industry.

The honourable member for Berowra made some very interesting comments on the second major leg of the legislation-the statutory reserve deposits (SRDs) provisions. I think what he said on that point bears some further consideration. Certainly there is a case that the SRD mechanism was a relatively blunt instrument of policy, but at least it was a mechanism in the hands of government allowing the Reserve Bank to control money supply, or at least that part of money supply which relates to the amount of credit on loans extended by the Bank. However, the problem with that relatively blunt instrument is that the way of manufacturing credit and money in our society has so exploded with new instruments that, in a sense, controlling just one way of creating `money' was a relatively limited mechanism. The complexity is illustrated by the various ways in which money supply can be measured-the so-called M1, M2 and M3 measurements. The SRD system attracted condemnation from two review bodies set up to examine Australia's financial system-the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System and the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System-and as a result of the criticisms advanced in those reports it was largely disused as an instrument of government policy.

Nonetheless, I do note the points that the honourable member for Berowra has made. Future governments may wish to intervene directly in the creation of money. In a deregulated market-place there are only limited ways in which governments can influence the direction of an economy. Some of those are obvious. For example, wages outcomes are capable of being influenced provided that government has an arrangement with the trade union movement and there is broad agreement between the parties. That is why I prefaced my remarks by pointing out the importance of actually having a policy in relation to wages outcomes. The second way in which governments can influence the macro-economic settings is through their own budget decisions. They can influence macro-economic savings either by accumulating surpluses and repaying debt, or by spending more and thereby seeking to stimulate growth within an economy.

Obviously, with the Australian economy growing dramatically and strongly, notwithstanding attempts to slow it down, the Government has brought in a Budget which has predicted a Budget surplus of $9.1 billion. It is one way in which the Government is saving on behalf of the Australian people. That contributes to a slowdown of the rate of economic growth and, to the soft landing which is predicted in the Budget Papers. Those are the first two ways in which governments can influence the macro-economic settings.

The third way is through interest rates. Because the Government has put as much weight as it can on its Budget and wages policy, the Government has had to lean fairly heavily on interest rates in seeking to influence the Australian economy to slow down, to take demand off imports and to create an environment where there is a capacity for productive investment to kick along within Australia but without placing the pressure on imports that has bedevilled the Australian economy over the last two years. Those are the three principal arms of economic policy in current use.

However, potentially there are other arms. One of those other arms would be a capacity to influence total money supply and money growth. To some extent, that is influenced through the Reserve Bank of Australia and by the way in which notes are issued or withdrawn from the market. The SRD was also such a mechanism, used during the 1950s to promote what were then regarded as credit squeezes. I do not think that anyone would wish to advance the argument that Australia is now ripe for a credit squeeze. I do not think that has been an argument advanced by anyone in the financial community, and certainly not, I imagine, by the honourable member for Berowra, who raised some concerns about the withdrawal of the SRD mechanism. Nonetheless, the availability of a mechanism to influence money growth does seem to me to be something that perhaps should not be too lightly discarded. It has certainly not been replaced by the one per cent non-callable deposit. That is a flat deposit which is there essentially for prudential reasons to ensure that there is a buffer in case of bad debts or the like in the banking system, rather than as a mechanism for controlling the rate of growth of the money supply. I therefore think there is a point worth noting in the remarks made by the honourable member for Berowra in relation to the SRD. It is a point that warrants some further reflection.

I turn to one aspect of this Bill, namely, prudential management. With the deregulation of the banking system and the introduction of many new banking products there has been a need to update the way in which the banking system is monitored and regulated. The monitoring function is to be enhanced by a series of provisions in the legislation which provide that banks must supply the Reserve Bank with detailed information to enable the Reserve Bank to formulate policy responses to ensure that there is no default within the banking system.

Clause 15 of the Bill, headed `Collection and publication of information about banks', I regard as one of the most important provisions. For the first time there is a firm legislative basis in the law which enables the Reserve Bank to identify exactly what is occurring in the marketplace with banks. It has become increasingly important because, more and more, banks have become the source of almost all consumer credit in Australia as well as driving commercial investment. About 80 per cent of all personal consumer credit is now extended through the banking system. There has been a significant change over the last five years. Before there was a deregulated banking system and various new products were attractively made available by the banks much of the personal consumer credit business was transacted by finance companies, building societies, credit unions, and the like. Eighty per cent of consumer credit transactions are now conducted by banks. As well as traditional commercial funding functions banks now provide most of the credit available to ordinary citizens. It is crucial that the Commonwealth and its agencies have full capacity to collect and publish information about the banks. Clause 15 of the Bill provides for those reporting provisions.

The Bill also provides a legislative framework for the Government, through the Reserve Bank, to ensure that banks are properly monitored and that proper prudential arrangements are in place. Fortunately, in recent history banks in Australia have not closed because of bad debt. That has not always been the case. In the late 1800s several banks in Victoria fell to insolvency. There are a number of very interesting books about those very racy days of early bank financing. Several of Victoria's leading citizens of the day were involved in essentially piratical activities and in the sponsorship of banks which ultimately failed, to the detriment of those who had their savings locked into those banks. It is simply unacceptable nowadays to accept a situation where major financial institutions in which ordinary people place their savings can fail. The Australian Government, through its control of prudential arrangements, has to make sure that banks do not crash at the expense of ordinary customers who have lent their moneys to the banks. These arrangements under clause 6, which are influenced also by the licensing conditions provided by clause 5 of the Bill, are very important provisions.

Finally, I would like to say something about banking generally. Given that consumer credit is now generated through the banking system rather than through other institutions, I believe it is more important than ever to look at the consumer responsibility of banking. One of the realities that we have seen is a change in Australian business. The banks had been previously regarded as benevolent, rather lazy institutions but ones which were always looking after the interests of their customers. Under the pressure of increasing competition and deregulation they have become much more market oriented and much more profit oriented. But they are still not regulated by the ordinary rules about consumer credit that apply to other institutions. There are still on the financial market products that do not adequately disclose rates of interest or provide the sort of information that customers are entitled to.

Bank customers are being left in a position where they need greater protection. I hope that comes about through the work that is now proceeding towards uniform consumer credit laws, work that is occurring between the Commonwealth and State Ministers. If that process fails, I believe there is a need to establish a clear set of consumer credit laws to apply to banks. For example, banks' contracts are often vague, written in terms which many regard as unconscionably in favour of the banks. There are no effective mechanisms for consumers to be advised about the state of their transactions with banks.

One point that came to my attention recently from a number of my constituents is that they had been repaying on a monthly basis loans that had been extended to them and they had believed that those repayments would be sufficient to reduce the principal and to repay the loan. However, the bank, without notifying them, had increased the interest rate that was applicable on those loans so that they were not, in effect, repaying the loans at all. The principal was accumulating. They ended up owing more at the end of three years than when they began paying.

These people were business consumers. They borrowed money for a business purpose. If business consumers are the victims in such a situation then think of the thousands of small consumers that are not protected. The banks can extend better protection: they advise clients who borrow more than $100,000-the big customers-if their repayments are no longer covering principal, but the little customer can go swing. It is vital that we have effective coverage of consumer credit laws extended as soon as possible. If the process between the State and Commonwealth Ministers fails then this Parliament should legislate, and legislate quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like former speakers in this debate today, would like to speak to the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill that is before the House and, perhaps, conclude with more general comments about the banking sector. As we have already heard in the contributions made by people, both those opposite and those on the Government side, there are a number of major changes proposed in this legislation. The first, of course, is to provide the Reserve Bank of Australia with the formal authority for the prudential supervision of banks. I do not think anybody could disagree with the need for supervision of some of the banks in Australia, particularly since deregulation and the emergence of a number of overseas banks and the decisions subsequently taken by some of them to close their doors and cease trading here.

SPEECH.PARA: The second major change proposed in the legislation is the removal of the distinction between trading banks and saving banks. My colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who has just spoken, went to some lengths to describe how those changes were to be brought about, and the need to have the distinction between trading banks and savings banks is therefore eliminated. Interestingly, it means that references to savings and/or trading banks in relation to different corporations, government entities and so on need to be amended. The legislation does just that. The third major change looks at replacing the statutory reserve deposit requirement on trading banks with a new non-callable deposit requirement on all banks. Again, I think that is a step in the right direction.

Finally, a change is proposed which will make the arrangements for the collection and publication of banking statistics more flexible. I do not think anybody in the community could quibble with the concept of there being a need to collect banking statistics in this era of a requirement for a fairly substantial information base. In this day and age everyone's attention seems to be concentrated on the economy and economic matters. In days gone by, at this time speeches in this place probably would have been about the success of the Australian cricket team, but now they are centred on interest rates, the economy, and so on. It is important that there be a statistical base from which people can make meaningful judgments and come to conclusions. Perhaps governments also need that base from which to make decisions on what is necessary for the economic well-being of our country.

I will look very quickly at the impact of each of these changes as I perceive them. Firstly, obviously there will be a promotion of stability in the banking system. Clearly, that is necessary to the economy. As my colleague the honourable member for Denison has just stated, we cannot live with a situation where there is a temptation for banks to manipulate things. We cannot live with a potential situation of banks going to the wall or financial institutions finding themselves in some degree of difficulty. There must be stability in the banking system. There must be a balance in the economy. Given the role the banks now play in the provision of finance and their contribution to our economic well-being-whether simply by providing finance to home buyers or to small or large businesses looking to expand and take advantage of economic conditions-it is necessary for that stability in the banking system to remain with us.

There is also a need for the continued protection of those who deposit funds with banks. People who deposit money in banks assume they will get a particular interest rate. The must have certainty in their minds that their money is protected and that they will have the opportunity to withdraw that money if and when necessary and that whatever is due to them will flow to them. Continued protection, therefore, under this amending legislation is quite appropriate.

The removal of the distinction between savings and trading banks is also timely. No longer is any purpose served by having a distinction between them. They do the same basic tasks. Those who will ultimately benefit from this process will be the customers because lower costs should be associated with banking services. That is a very interesting point and one that I will return to in a moment when I address the contribution made by the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), who talked about bank bashing and banks being subjected to a great deal of criticism which was perhaps unfair. One of the fundamental things to flow from the removal of the distinction between savings and trading banks will be lower costs to customers. The banks should no longer need to impose charges on transactions because the distinction will no longer be there. That in turn should promote efficiency in the banking sector. In all parts of the economy efficiency is now the key word, and it is certainly no different in the banking sector. As a result, the Government's ability to monitor the financial sector will also be improved. I believe that that is most important because it allows the general public to be better informed about banks, the roles which they play and the contribution they make to the economy in its broader sense.

Let me turn now to prudential supervision, perhaps with a bit more detail. The Reserve Bank up until recently has relied heavily on the cooperation of individual banks to fulfil its obligatory role of prudential supervision. However, due to the effects of deregulation, when we saw a number of banks come into Australia, which has meant more banks, more competition and so on, it is now desirable for the Reserve Bank to have a clear statutory base for its prudential supervision of banks. I think that is quite appropriate. Given deregulation and the fact that there are more players out there in the game, in the marketplace, we need to ensure that what is being done not only is within the law of Australia but also, even more importantly, is to the benefit of the people who use the banking system. Certainly it is not the Government's intention to alter the prudential standards or their administration; it is simply to ensure that they apply equitably amongst all banks.

The question of the removal of the statutory reserve deposit, or SRD, also is included within this legislation. It was recommended, as has been stated in debate, by both the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System. I just point out that the latter committee did not involve me or any of my relatives, to my knowledge. The SRD requirement has had something of a distorting effect on the financial system for quite some time. It is to be phased out over three years and will be replaced with a system of non-callable deposits which banks will be required to maintain with the Reserve Bank. Again I think that that is sensible. It is a reflection of the banking system in the latter half of this century and is in keeping with modern practices. As the economy changes, as it expands, as the volume of money increases, it is necessary to ensure that the functions performed by the banks in this country are efficient and effective and meet the needs of the customers. The new arrangements represent further and significant steps in the process of financial deregulation. I know that there is some degree of criticism still about the process of deregulation in our economy. I think that generally speaking deregulation has been reasonable and that benefits have flowed to people but, as I will point out shortly, there are also one or two little problems.

Finally in relation to the legislation itself, the collection and publication of statistics about banks, as I have already remarked, will be quite significant, particularly for customers and consumers who look at what their banks do. They get the annual reports, but quite often they are uncertain what it all means. However, with the collection of statistics now being made available-and hopefully they will be-by the Government, there should be a clearer understanding as to just what role the banks play in our economy. The statistics will be simplified, they will be more flexible, and will keep up with the significant and rapid changes in the nature of the financial markets and the types of financial instruments used by banks. This measure is clearly designed to assist customers-that is, the consumers.

I indicated that, in the time that I have this morning, I wanted to make one or two comments about the banking industry in general and perhaps also respond to some of the comments made by the honourable member for Berowra in his contribution this morning. Firstly, I think that the honourable member indicated that he felt that criticisms of banks were not justified. Many people are concerned about interest rates and the possibility of problems with their industry or business or in maintaining home mortgage repayments and so on. I think that the honourable member is very much under the illusion, like so many in the banking industry, that concerns from people such as that about what part the banks have played in all this are not real and are not justified. I would just like to go to four specific areas where I think perhaps the honourable member might like to look to see whether the criticisms of banks are justified in some way.

The first relates to bank charges themselves. How many of us in this place receive representations from battlers, from pensioners, from people who kept less than $250 in bank accounts-particularly with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia-and were subjected to charges every time a transaction was made? Because of pressure from both sides of this House the Commonwealth Bank has relented to some extent and indicated that it is prepared to waive those charges for specific people, but not everybody. Battlers-people who have a minimum amount of money kept in their accounts-are being subjected to the $2.50 charge simply because the banks say-because of their lack of efficiency, I presume-that they are unable to process any of those transactions of their customers. Frankly, I find that is appalling. The banks, particularly the Commonwealth Bank, should look at that aspect of their operations. If that is being critical of the banks, and one bank in particular, is that not justified? Perhaps in the electorate of the honourable member for Berowra there are not too many people who have minimum balances of less than $250, but I can assure him there are many who do in other parts of Australia, and this is a concern.

The second issue is that of debt. I used the line in my electorate last night after the Budget that the Budget surplus was being used in much the same way as a household which has a surplus but also a Bankcard problem would use that surplus. We will pay off some of the debt. When a household runs up a Bankcard debt there comes a time when it has to make a few payments. There is a minimum repayment every month, and the household hopes eventually to discharge that debt. The question of debt and the role that banks play, however, is also worthy of examination. For example-I am sure there are others, like myself, who have had constituents see them about this issue-how many of us can remember the old days when one went to see a bank loans officer or a bank manager and said, `Look, I am in the process of buying a home and I want to borrow some money to enable me to do it'? The bank manager or loans officer would go through a complicated set of calculations based, essentially, on the gross income of the worker in the family. It did not matter whether one's wife worked; she was excluded. It did not matter whatever else might have been around. If one had assets, they were included. A gross figure was arrived at and the amount of money that the banks were prepared to lend was no more than 25 per cent of that gross salary, in terms of the weekly repayments.

That does not happen now. One might go to the bank manager or loans officer and say, `Look, I have to buy a house'. In Sydney or Melbourne the cost of housing has been driven up because of the supply and demand question. The manager will say, `How much do you want?'. One may say, `I want $100,000'. The bank manager will say, `Look, it is only money, take $200,000. You can repay it and if interest rates go up we will extend the time for repayment'. What he does not say is that the amount to be repaid, therefore, will be a lot higher. Where is the responsibility on the part of some of those people in the banking sector to their customers, particularly to battlers? I used the figure of $100,000. In Sydney I think that is probably about the minimum that people now have to borrow in order to purchase a house. In electorates like mine $60,000 to $70,000 is probably about average, but the same principle applies. People who are looking to buy first, second or even third homes go to banks and say they need to borrow money. Instead of giving them a realistic figure, which will not get them into consumer difficulties later on in meeting repayments, the banks are prepared to go overboard.

The same thing applies equally to Bankcard and other forms of credit that banks offer. Recently I received a letter from my bank saying, `We notice you have a very low Bankcard limit. We think that should be upped, and we are making you this once in a lifetime offer. You can have another $3,000 or $4,000 on top of that if you want'. I declined, I hasten to add. Having a wife and four children, and a cat and a dog, makes it very hard to make ends meet at the best of times without getting into the issue of consumer credit. Again, I ask the honourable member for Berowra, as somebody in a normal family situation, whether I am being too critical of banks because they are saying to people, `We will make credit far more easy for you'. Of course, it often gets people into situations where they cannot meet their debts.

The third point I want to address quickly is the banks' views on capital gains tax. I am reminded of an interview with Will Bailey of the ANZ Bank on Business Sunday on 23 April. This is just a passing comment in relation to capital gains tax-and it flows from my former comment on housing and housing interest rates. He said:
If we're going to have a capital gains tax, I believe it ought to apply equally across the board to all sorts of investments, and that includes a (owner-occupied) house.

Am I being critical of somebody like Will Bailey from the ANZ Bank who says that capital gains tax should apply to owner-occupied houses? I do not think I am. I do not think too many people in this place would agree to something like that applying. Even those on the other side of the House who are against capital gains tax as such would not, I am sure, agree with that statement.

Finally, I come to the question of the role that banks play in international profit shifting and the use of tax havens. This matter was brought to the attention of the Parliament in May this year when a document from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration was published entitled Taxpayers or taxplayers. That report goes to the heart of the issue about banks and the way they use money, and other people's money, and shift it around between Australia, tax havens and other corporations. It goes to the heart of the way in which the Australian Taxation Office has directed its attention to certain matters of concern, and its ongoing investigations. It also directs concern at the role which some banks play and the amount of profits which they hold in tax havens. I refer to page 63 of that report where table 1, entitled `Tax haven profits by companies', lists 15 companies which have over $100m, or greater than 100 per cent of their profits, contained in tax havens. A bank is one of those top 15 companies that use tax havens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which bank?

—It is the ANZ Bank. But if one turns to a table at the back of that document, one also sees that many other banks are listed, with the profits they derive from tax havens. This has been drawn to the attention of the Parliament. The Government has already announced that legislation will be put in place to crack down on the use of tax havens by Australian corporations, including individual banks, and rightly so. Again, I will probably be accused in the banking sector of bank bashing and criticising banks. The evidence that came before this Committee showed that the banks either have no idea or choose not to have an idea as to how money is moved around between Australia and tax havens and overseas corporations and subsidiaries. What clearly came out as well is that if one moves less than $50,000 from Australia overseas, one does not need a tax clearance certificate from Australia-one can just do it, and people have no idea as to where that money is going. It could come from illegal activities in this country, but banks do not know and do not want to know. Again, I will be accused of being critical and bank bashing. I am not. I am raising legitimate concerns of people. Those concerns will be continuously addressed to the Government and, certainly, by this Committee in its ongoing commitment to look at this issue of international profit shifting.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is good legislation. It proposes major changes, but there are criticisms of banks which I think are justified. I do not have time to go to the heart of the matter of profiteering by banks. There is ample evidence to suggest that is the case, and I do not think people should forget that either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been explained by the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) in introducing this Bill and by other speakers, this Banking Legislation Amendment Bill will change significantly the Banking Act of 1959. There will no longer be that distinction between trading and savings banks and, importantly, the Government is addressing the problems brought to its attention by the banks concerning statutory reserve deposits (SRDs). Instead of SRDs there will be a new non-callable deposit requirement on all the banks. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) made some very valid points about the changes and how they will reduce costs. I hope that those changes and the reduction in costs will flow to consumers, because that should be the ultimate aim. We ought to see some of the hidden charges disappearing. We ought to see some of those other administrative costs being reduced. But it is an important change to legislation and I know it will be supported by members of the Opposition. It will certainly be supported by Government members and I think by the banking system generally.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one denies that the banking system is a very important part of our society. It is central to the operation of this nation's financial system. It makes a very important contribution to the nation's broader economy. At the same time, putting the banks on a pedestal, as the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) did, is really overdoing it a bit. He made out that the banks were squeaky clean-like Rinso, white. That is certainly not the case when one looks at the sorts of problems people have faced because of the banks' policies, including wrong advice on offshore borrowing and the difficulties of farmers who have been called upon to pay penalty interest rates. The interest rate for some farmers was 17 per cent but for others, because of financial difficulties, it was 22 per cent. The honourable member for Macarthur raised the matter of tax havens. They are totally un-Australian. Australian banks that are involved in offshore tax havens ought to have a hard look at themselves and question whether they are truly pro this nation.

The honourable member for Berowra also tried to set aside any blame on the banks for high interest rates. One could almost believe that the banks are some sort of community charitable organisation, that if one goes along and asks them nicely one gets money for nothing. How ridiculous! The honourable member for Berowra either is a member of the board of directors of some bank or, because of his long accounting and economic background, is locked into a mentality that can see no wrong. He is wearing blinkers where the banks are concerned. He painted a picture of banks being perfect and pure. That is not the case. It is time people started to realise what is taking place behind the scenes. In fact, sometimes one does not even have to look behind the scenes at the hidden charges and the additional costs! One just has to look at the openly declared profits to see the sort of money the banks are making.

One needs to look too at the differences between the interest paid on on-call deposits and the interest charged to borrowers. That is the issue here. One only has to make the comparison to see who is doing the right thing and who is affecting interest rates. Not so long ago a woman rang me. She was irate because her daughter had to pay a higher interest rate with a building society. She informed me that her daughter would now have to pay 16 per cent. I said to her, `Maybe we should look at the building society's profits'. She thought that was an unfair comment and that I was just trying to protect the Hawke Labor Government. I was not. I asked her what sort of money she was getting on her investment with that building society. It happened to be the Rockhampton building society called the Rock Building Society. She said, `I'm probably getting 13 or 14 per cent'. I said that that would be nonsense. I asked whether she had less than $5,000 invested. She said it was none of my business. I said, `What would you have? I'm going to put it to you, lady, that if you've got less than $4,999 you're getting a meagre 6 per cent on your money'. She called me a couple of things and said I was telling lies, that it was untrue. I challenged her to ring the building society and find out what interest she was being paid on her deposits. She rang back about 15 minutes later and apologised. She had less than $4,999 in that account and she was getting 6 per cent interest. She started to understand that there was something wrong when she and tens of thousands of other depositors were getting 6 per cent on their money but the building society was charging 16 per cent.

I took the time to pull out some other figures because I did not want to target only the Rock Building Society. I wanted to make sure that this was correct, so I went back to the Reserve Bank figures to see what is taking place out there, what movement has occurred in the interest being paid on on-call deposits contrasted with the interest changes for people who have borrowed money. The Reserve Bank figures for June are quite exciting. In April this year there was about $9,000m in passbook accounts across this nation. Those $9,000m worth of accounts are getting only 3.7 per cent. If one looks at that as a percentage of the total savings one sees that 16 per cent to 20 per cent of total savings in this nation are attracting 3.75 per cent. At the moment the bank charges to someone borrowing for a home are 17 per cent. Yet the honourable member for Berowra told us that we ought to put the banks on some sort of pedestal.

Let us look at the plastic card accounts. Plastic card accounts have some $9 1/2 billion in them. That amount has increased since these figures were pulled out. In 1988 those accounts were attracting 8.75 per cent. In a year when we have seen an increase of 3 per cent and 4 per cent in interest rates to borrowers, those plastic card accounts have gone from 8.75 per cent to 9 per cent. So if people have money in plastic card accounts they have gained a massive one-quarter per cent interest increase during a year, but those who are borrowing their money through the banks are paying 3 per cent and 4 per cent more. What has this meant for the banks? It has meant an additional $300m in profits for the banks who control and manage those passbook accounts. For the plastic card accounts it has meant a windfall profit of some $310m. So on two types of accounts-the average savings accounts with 3.75 per cent interest and the plastic card accounts-the banks have picked up a $610m profit. If one looks at the other types of accounts in the banking system one sees that in this year, when interest rates have risen by 3 per cent and 4 per cent, and in some cases 5 per cent, for those trying to buy a home, people with money in these accounts have gained between a quarter of a per cent and one per cent.

The building societies are no better. It is time we took a hard look at the building societies, which are supposed to be out there with the specific responsibility of helping people build homes. They were set up to provide money for homes. The average account rate they were paying last year was 8.3 per cent. This year, 12 months later, it has gone up to only 8.69 per cent-less than half a per cent increase in interest. In fact, it is a 0.39 per cent increase. Yet the lending rates during that same period have gone from an average of 13.05 per cent to 15.94 per cent-a rise of almost 3 per cent. That is a lot of money. There is $6 billion in these accounts I am targeting. This has meant an extra profit of $148m to the building societies in that 12-month period.

Let us come back to some specifics. If a depositor has less than $500 in the Metway Bank Ltd, a metropolitan building society that became a bank with the idea of competing and serving the community in Rockhampton, Brisbane or any other part of Queensland, he gets 4 per cent interest. If he has between $500 and $1,000 he gets 8 per cent interest. It is only when he has more than $1,000 that he gets 11 per cent interest. If he has less than $5,000 in the Rock Building Society I mentioned before he gets 6 per cent. If he has up to $10,000 he gets only 7 per cent. If he has between $10,000 and $25,000 he gets only 8 per cent interest.

A depositor has to have more than $25,000 to get the 11 per cent interest rate that the bank keeps advertising. The advertisements talk about 11 per cent; they do not talk about 6 per cent or 7 per cent. The bank does not bother to tell people, except in the very fine print or unless they ring up and ask, that they need $25,000 to get 11 per cent. If a depositor has less than $1,000 in the Bank of Queensland-praised again for being pro-Queensland-he gets 3.75 per cent. If he has less than $5,000 he gets 6.25 per cent. This one is a beauty: if he has less than $50,000 he still gets only 7.5 per cent. What is the bank charging? It is charging 17 per cent. Is it any wonder that members of parliament, those involved in the consumer movement and people buying homes are getting fed up with the profiteering that is taking place in the banking industry.

The Commonwealth Bank of Australia is not much better. If a depositor has less than $4,000 he gets 3.75 per cent. If he has more than $4,000-he can have $44,000-he gets only 6 per cent interest in the savings account. In keycard accounts the interest goes up to 8.5 per cent. It is only when one gets into the investment areas that the figures start to improve but that money cannot be withdrawn; so it is not the sort of money that most people have.

There are signs everywhere around Canberra and Queanbeyan about how wonderful the St George Building Society is. If a depositor has less than $500 he gets 5 per cent. If he has less than $2,000 he gets 8 per cent. I think the only bank I came across that deserves any credit is Westpac Banking Corporation. I do not usually pick and praise anyone, but at least with Westpac if a customer has under $2,999 in the bank he gets interest at 9 per cent; if he has up to $10,000, he gets interest at 9 1/2 per cent; and if he goes over that to the $20,000 mark, or over $19,999, he gets interest at 12 per cent. Westpac is creating the competition. It is a pity that some of the other banks did not follow suit. It is a pity that some of the building societies did not do the right thing by those who were depositing with them instead of ripping off those who were borrowing from them.

A person can have $9,999 in the Mackay Building Society and he will get only a miserable 5 per cent interest rate. The credit unions of Australia talk about the 14 per cent rates that they give, but if we go back to their on-call accounts we see that if a person has less than $1,000, he gets interest at 6 per cent. This is typical of what is to be found for the vast majority of Australians as we work through the building societies and the banks. I think it is time that the banks and the building societies started being fair with people when they borrow money, and they ought to start doing something about the little rorts that take place.

In Queensland, Suncorp has a policy whereby the moment the interest rate is increased to borrowers it charges the borrower to adjust his account. It is getting the extra money because interest rates have gone up, but it puts a special administrative charge on the borrower. It is the same building society that the Queensland Consumers Association is investigating at the moment because of its advertisements. It is advertising now that people can borrow at 16 per cent. What it does not tell them is that eventually the higher interest rate must be caught up with. After some three years built into this is an amount of money that has to be picked up. At the moment it is a lower interest rate, but later on the customer will be paying more. There is a need to have a hard look at the interest rates being charged. It is time that the banks started returning some of these profits to the people who allow them to make the profits; that is, the depositors. The 3.75 per cent interest rate is a nonsense amount. It does not even go anywhere near the costs of inflation; it does not help depositors in any way to meet the sorts of charges that they have to bear. As the honourable member for Macarthur says, if a depositor has a small amount in the bank, the bank does not even pay interest rates; instead it charges the depositor to have his money there. I suggest that we need to look at cocktail loans. As 20 per cent of the money in the savings accounts attracts interest at 3.75 per cent, it is time the banks started calculating the charges accordingly. The fact is that on 20 per cent of their money they are paying only 3.75 per cent in interest.

I have pulled out some figures that show that if a borrower took out a $50,000 loan and $10,000 of that, which is 20 per cent, was calculated on the 3.75 per cent interest rate, which is what the banks are paying for it, he should be paying interest at only 6 per cent or 7 per cent at the most on $10,000 of that $50,000 loan. The figures that I have given indicate that for some 20 per cent of the savings moneys that are in the accounts, the banks are paying only about 6 per cent, and another 20 per cent of that $50,000 loan ought to be calculated on the cost of the money to the bank. This would mean that the borrower should pay only some 9 or 10 per cent for that 20 per cent borrowed. As I pointed out also, there is some 20 per cent of the money in savings accounts for which the banks are paying around 8 per cent. Again, the borrower should have a lesser cost for the money borrowed and that should be brought back to 11 per cent, 12 per cent or, at the very most, 13 per cent. If a $50,000 loan were cocktailed, if I can use that term, so that parts of it were calculated on what the banks were really paying for the money, we would see thousands of dollars being saved. I did a test to show that a $50,000 loan based on these 20 per cent groupings would save the average home borrower between $2,000 and $3,000 a year in interest alone. If the banks did the correct thing, we would be talking about savings of $40 to $60 a week.

I am not going to start calling for inquiries into the banks. I just want competition. That is what it is about. That is why the banks were deregulated, and that is why we allowed the banks to come in. I have yet to see the advantage of the deregulation process for the ordinary consumer, the man in the street, the family in the home. Except for a case such as Westpac, it seems that there is a policy out there that the banks and building societies pay the least possible interest rate for the money that is deposited with them and that they take every skerrick they can from those who borrow it back. The differences are massive. The banks are paying only 3.75 per cent to 20 per cent of their depositors. In many banks it is more. I spoke to a Commonwealth Bank manager recently who just happened to be holidaying in central Queensland. I said to him, `What sorts of numbers would there be of people who have less than $5,000 in your bank?'. He paused a moment and said, `Look, I cannot give you the actual figures, but I think that about 70 to 80 per cent of people would have less than $5,000 in my bank'. That is quite amazing because it means that 70 or 80 per cent of people who are banking with that bank are getting 3.75 per cent or, at the very most, 5.5 per cent to 5.75 per cent on their money.

It is almost criminal that this is taking place when we hear the honourable member for Berowra and others getting up and blaming the Government for high interest rates. Of course there is a need to increase the cost of money to try to dampen down the economy, to stop the imports and to stop people from buying video recorders, television sets and so on. We have a very real problem in this country when it comes to imported goods. For instance, not one square metre of vinyl floor covering is made in this country. I went to an electrical appliance store the other day and the manager said that there was not one product in his store, in regard to video recorders, televisions and those sorts of appliances, that was made in Australia. They are all being imported, and they are causing problems internationally for this country. I suppose that the more money people have the more they will spend on those items. But when it comes to housing, the basic catalyst for our economy, the dream of every Australian, surely there has to be a rationale that will reduce the cost of purchasing a home, and that begins with the banks. It is not an unfair task to put before them because it is not as if we are saying, `Reduce your profit margin and work on one per cent or 2 per cent'. Some banks are borrowing at 3.75 per cent from the ordinary public and they are charging 17.5 per cent. The building societies are no better.
There is a need to look at this issue. I hope as the consumer movements across the nation are starting to campaign about this that the banks will listen. I ask them simply to become more competitive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Banking Legislation Amendment Bill relates to important amendments to the powers and responsibilities of the Reserve Bank of Australia and to the framework for trading and savings banks. I want to use this opportunity to discuss a related issue-the relationship between the Government and the Reserve Bank-but before doing that I would like to welcome the provisions of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal amendment gives formal authority to the Reserve Bank for the prudential supervision of banks. The deregulation of the financial system greatly increased the risk of financial instability. In the first half of the 1980s a number of important changes were made to the regulatory framework for banks, including the removal of ceilings on interest rates on some deposits payable by trading and savings banks, and that happened in December 1980; the lifting of virtually all exchange controls and floating the Australian dollar in late 1983; the abolition of the remaining controls on bank deposit interest rates in August 1984; and the removal of interest rate ceilings on bank loans of under $100,000, other than those for owner-occupied housing, in April 1985.

The effects of this deregulation are still being worked through, but experience of financial deregulation overseas as well as in Australia suggests that it is essential that prudential supervision-prudential regulation of a more informal kind-be strengthened. The Reserve Bank is required to protect those who deposit funds with the banks. It also has responsibility for the stability of the financial system. To achieve those goals, the Reserve Bank has developed arrangements which require each bank to maintain itself in a sound financial position. These prudential requirements relate to such matters as the adequacy of capital, the structure of assets and liabilities, management of exposures to risk, the capacity of its directors and senior management, and the representation of shareholders by directors.

While prudential supervision has apparently worked well until now, there is clearly value and appropriateness in strengthening the position of the Reserve Bank vis-a-vis the commercial banks by providing a clear statutory basis for its prudential supervision. The amendment empowers the Treasurer, after consultation with the Reserve Bank, to establish regulations for prudential supervision. This power is also being supplemented by an increase in the scope for placing conditions on the banks. The Bill transfers power to conduct investigations of banks from the Auditor-General to the Reserve Bank. These powers will be reserve powers, available to the Government and the bank for ensuring that the private banks act responsibly, that their directors maintain a proper fiduciary duty towards not only shareholders but also depositors, and that financial probity and stability be maintained. Clearly, these are all centrally important aspects of an effective and stable financial system. This is a very important step towards a new pattern of regulation of the banks in Australia.

Another of the amendments in the Bill abolishes the system of statutory reserve deposits, which has been used as a means of implementing monetary policy, and replaces it with a new system of non-callable deposits which at the end of a transitional three-year period will be required to be one per cent of bank liabilities. This amendment will reduce the burden on banks of the statutory reserve deposit arrangements while also providing a limited instrument for influencing bank behaviour. Other amendments in this significant Bill remove the distinction between trading and savings banks and make arrangements for the collection and publication of banking statistics.

Debate on this Bill provides an opportunity for discussion of a central element of monetary policy management in Australia-the relationship between the Government and the Reserve Bank. Few people in Australia seem to realise that the Reserve Bank is not directly under government control. It is not like the Department of the Treasury, which is entirely responsible to the Treasurer for what it does. The Reserve Bank is a statutory authority, the functions of which are set out in the Reserve Bank Act 1959, the Banking Act 1959 and the Financial Corporations Act 1974. These Acts give the Reserve Bank a wide range of powers and responsibilities, especially for monetary policy, external policy and the stability of the financial system. Section 10 of the Reserve Bank Act states:

(2) It is the duty of the Board, within the limits of its powers, to ensure that the monetary and banking policy of the Bank is directed to the greatest advantage of the people of Australia and that the powers of the Bank . . . are exercised in such a manner as, in the opinion of the Board, will best contribute to-
(a) the stability of the currency of Australia;
(b) the maintenance of full employment in Australia; and
(c) the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia.

These are fine, wide ranging and centrally important goals given to the bank by the government of the time which set it up. They are goals which are sometimes difficult to achieve simultaneously, but of course that is the problem of all economic policy making. The interesting point, though, is that it would conceptually be quite possible for the Reserve Bank to have a different view about how these goals should be achieved to that of the government of the time. The bank has a separated statutory existence and, as with any institution, will responsibly and inevitably build up quite clear views about how those goals should be achieved. Their approach could well be quite different to that of a government.

The drafters of the Reserve Bank Act foresaw that danger and made the bank ultimately subordinate to the Government in the determination of overall monetary, banking and external policy. First, the bank is required to inform the Government from time to time about its monetary and banking policies. Secondly, it is required to endeavour to reach agreement with the Government if a difference of opinion ever occurs but, thirdly, in the event of failure to reach agreement, the bank is required to pursue the Government's chosen policy. If such a disagreement occurs, which leads the Government to require that the bank adopt its policies, the Treasurer is required to notify Parliament of the view of both the Government and the bank. This provision ensures that the integrity of the bank is maintained. So far that requirement has never been used, because there has never been an irreconcilable difference of opinion of sufficient magnitude to require reference to Parliament. However, the bank does have substantial independent powers of action in the implementation of monetary, external and prudential policy. For example, the bank can decide how it is going to intervene in buying and selling foreign exchange to influence the exchange rate and how it is going to operate in the open market for government securities. So there are still substantial areas of potential conflict.

The structure of bank-government relations appears to work pretty well and to be satisfactory for most potential conflicts. The fact that the Secretary to the Treasury is a member of the bank board is another avenue for government influence, as are the multitude of informal contacts and forms of shared information which exist. Nevertheless, it is a strange inconsistency that one of the centrally important arms of economic management is not under direct and comprehensive government control. We believe in representative democracy, we believe in electing parliamentarians with responsibility for a whole range of policies including economic management, but we exclude from that direct control parts of the area of monetary and external policy.

The reason for the current position of the bank is probably that there was doubt at the time the Act was introduced that governments would be fully responsible about monetary policy-that because of political constraints they would not be prepared to pursue appropriately tight monetary policy when this was necessary. The United States of America is a particularly clear example of a country where that fear has led to a structure for monetary policy which is generally independent of the US Administration. The privately owned US Federal Reserve Board-and it is extraordinary that the central bank of the US is privately owned-must report twice a year to Congress on its policies but not to the President or the Executive. In practice the Federal Reserve is in frequent informal contact with all policy making arms of the government; nevertheless its statutory position is one of independence from the US Cabinet. In many other countries the central bank is subject to directions of government. For example, in the United Kingdom the Bank of England is subject to directions of the British Treasury, though in practice I understand decisions are generally reached jointly. In New Zealand the central bank is subject to directions from the Minister of Finance in carrying out economic policy. In France, the Ministry of the Economy, Finance and the Budget, through the Treasury Directorate, dictates even the day-to-day conduct of monetary policy. In contrast, in Australia the Reserve Bank has a legal obligation to keep the Government informed of its policies, but it is not subject to approval by any branch of government for much of what it does. The report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System included comment on what it described as `the bank's broad legislative powers'. That Committee, by the way, endorsed the present structure of the Government's relations with the Reserve Bank, but the description of the Reserve Bank as having legislative powers draws attention to the seriousness of the issue being discussed.

While I do not believe that this issue is one of immediate importance, or is one that is causing any significant difficulty at present, I am inclined to think that there is an inconsistency between commitment to representative democracy and the present extent of the Reserve Bank's powers. The time could come when the directness of the contact between the bank and Cabinet will need to be strengthened. The Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration recommended in 1976 that the Governor of the bank should have direct access to the economic committee of Cabinet on a regular basis. It would appear that since that time the amount of contact between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Governor has increased, but it could well be that Cabinet itself should give more attention to the structure of monetary policy and also to the means of implementing it, and that the Governor should meet with Cabinet to discuss those questions.

Australians are suffering indirectly from the independence of the Federal Reserve Board in the United States because the United States Administration and the Federal Reserve had inconsistent fiscal and monetary policy during the Reagan years. Fiscal policy was expansionary, driven particularly by the rapid increase in military expenditure in the first six of the Reagan years. Monetary policy in contrast was tight and restrictive in an attempt to control inflation, so that interest rates were driven up in 1979-80 and were kept high by the pincer movement of expansionary fiscal and tight monetary policies. The high level of real interest rates in the United States during the 1980s has been the principal cause of high real interest rates in Australia during this decade. A greater consistency in economic policy in the United States, to which integration of economic policy-making might have contributed, could have reduced this problem.

A Reserve Bank economist, listening to this speech, might well argue that the problems of the United States illustrate the reasons for the independence of the Reserve Bank, in that the excessively generous fiscal policies, particularly towards the United States military-industrial establishment, led to the problem. However, if the Reagan Administration had been responsible for both arms of policy there would have been greater pressure on it to be more sceptical of the excessive claims for increased United States military expenditure. In any case, a structure which provides a sound basis for consistency in policy is better than one which generally tends to lead to conflict.

The Australian system is much better than the one in the United States but it still leaves a residue of concern about the potential for conflict. This issue may need to be addressed again one day. In the meantime, the strengthening of the regulatory basis for prudential supervision, which this Bill involves, is to be warmly welcomed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, as have a number of Government members, to support the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill. The purpose of this Bill is to establish formal prudential supervision of the banks by the Reserve Bank, to abolish the distinction between trading and savings banks and, lastly, to abolish the statutory reserve deposit scheme. I believe that these reforms put forward by the Government have been long overdue. With respect to the prudential supervision of banks by the Reserve Bank, this has mostly been done by cooperation between the banks and the Reserve Bank, but this Government is formalising that system by legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we mean by `prudential supervision'? The prudential requirements observed by banks in Australia, like those applying in other developed countries, relate to matters such as the adequacy of capital, the structure of assets and liabilities, the management of exposures to risk, the capacity of directors and senior management, and the representation of shareholders by directors. There is very little difference these days between savings and trading banks, so that distinction is being abolished. They do not have the separate managerial structures that they used to have. In fact, maintenance of the distinction actually distorted banking patterns. Banks often relied on getting their money through commercial bills and offshore borrowings. The statutory reserve deposit requirement which I mentioned had that distorting effect.

My interest in banks is not limited to this piece of legislation. I noticed that the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) in his contribution dwelt on the role of the banking system and commented in particular on the national debt. He suggested that the current level of national debt was a matter of real concern. I want to expose some of the flaws in his logic. It must be said that the national debt of the Federal Government is diminishing; it is not increasing. The overseas borrowing component of Federal Government debt is more than offset by reserves. The honourable member for Berowra used the good old example of ordinary householders borrowing more than they can repay. We must make two points about the Federal Government: firstly, its debt is diminishing and, secondly, the level of debt is more than matched by the level of its reserves. Also, more than 60 per cent of overseas borrowings are by private companies, not the Government. The honourable member for Berowra said that there ought to be more deregulation but he is very upset about the level of overseas borrowings by private companies. I happen to share that concern but I think there is a gross inconsistency in his position. He says, `This Government hasn't gone far enough in deregulation; but we need to re-regulate this part of private sector operations'. Of course, he did not mention that we are now getting a dividend stream from overseas of about $2.6 billion a year. That did not exist in years gone by.

There is some room for concern on the national debt.
