But members of the public ought to be aware that the prime cause is not profligacy by this Federal Government or irresponsible management of the public purse; its debt is diminishing. The private sector is responsible for the majority of overseas borrowings. Hopefully, without wanting to reflect on any Appropriation Bill, the level of superannuation savings generated by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and proposed to be increased may make it even more attractive for companies to borrow domestically rather than overseas and thus increase the debt. The banking system has been exposed to a great deal of deregulation and this Banking Legislation Amendment Bill reflects a minor part of that. By and large, it has worked well for Australia. A lot of people forget that, in terms of generating well over 1.2 million jobs in the economy, deregulation of the financial market and the banking system was a prerequisite, but, like any move, it ought to be subject to review.

I believe that, whilst we are putting formally into place the prudential supervision of the banks, no-one seems to be speaking up on behalf of the banking customer-the ordinary mums, dads and children of Australia who bank with the banks. I am very keen to see a joint parliamentary select committee review those organisations, such as the banks, that offer consumer banking facilities. Building societies and credit unions would have to be included in the review because these days they operate very much like banks. That review could be done from a consumer perspective. Let me outline some of the reasons why I think we ought to have that review. I have already said that, when we implement something like massive deregulation, it is only appropriate that we review the results of it so that there is accountability and responsibility. I say in fairness to the Australian Bankers Association that it does not object to this scrutiny. I hope the Government will grasp the nettle in regard to this review.

Let us look at the issue of housing interest rates. Quite a number of banks are offering new home buyers interest rates at 17 per cent, but at least one Victorian building society is able to offer those same householders an interest rate of 14.5 per cent. About a month ago, Citibank Ltd offered new home buyers a fixed term loan at 15.5 per cent. A month later it dropped that rate to 14.9 per cent. Citibank is not one of the four major players but it is doing this and its customers are benefiting. I am in favour of a five-year fixed term loan because in the first five years of home ownership home owners are most vulnerable and most exposed to any upward fluctuations in interest rates. Over the course of that five years it may cost home owners a little more to have a fixed interest loan, but they would prefer the certainty of that fixed interest rate.

Citibank has been criticised. It has been suggested that it is out after market share. Indeed it may be, and good luck to it. I think the move by Citibank is predicated on two things: one is a belief that interest rates will fall. I think that view is even shared by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). Secondly, maybe the banks are making just a little too much profit out of home owners, particularly new home owners. I think there is a very good case for that too. In fact, I would like to see a committee investigate that and see whether the major banks should be getting into the fixed five-year term home loan for new home owners. I quote from the Daily Mirror:
Mortgage rates `can be cut to 14 per cent'
Australian banks could afford to cut mortgage interest rates down to 14 per cent, according to figures in a new confidential report.

The report, by stockbrokers McIntosh Hamson Hoare Govett, shows the bigger banks reaping double the profit margins of their foreign competitors while maintaining mortgage interest rates at record high levels.

Maybe that is just an irresponsible report. That is the question. But are the banks making exorbitant profits by penalising their ordinary customers? The banks acknowledge that there are cross-subsidies within the banking system. In whose direction do the cross-subsidies work? Are ordinary bank customers subsidising corporate accounts? Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be aware that the larger the corporate account the better the discount and that there is quite some competition for it. But what happens to the ordinary customers? Are they reaping the benefits of that competition?

Secondly, quite a significant number of new banking products have been put on to the market and offered to people by the banks. I welcome that. Once again the question is: Does the ordinary customer really understand the benefits about each package? Have the banks really gone out to explain what they are offering? If a survey were undertaken in the electorate of Grayndler, would the banking customers of Grayndler really understand the different products? I hazard a suggestion that the answer is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Chifley should not attempt to use the Chair in his debate.
—I am sorry. I was thinking of a very distinguished electorate. I apologise.
—Otherwise I might have to bring him back to the substance of the matter before the Chair.

—Yes, indeed. It could very well be in Chifley. The point is not that there is something untoward in that situation, but it may be a legitimate criticism that the banks have not gone far enough. Honourable members of this House would be aware that the banks propose to set up an independent ombudsman. It will be a voluntary system which the banks will fund, but it will be based on the United Kingdom model. The rub is that the United Kingdom model has been subject to extensive review by Professor Jack on behalf of the Thatcher Government, which is hardly the most radical government, on my side of politics anyway. The Jack report said that a self-funded, voluntary system is hopelessly inadequate and that the powers of the Ombudsman are inadequate.

SPEECH.PARA: It may work in Australia, but we need to see in what way this independent ombudsman is going to protect customers. We ought to review the situation and form an opinion about it. We may say that this has been a good move. I want to thank the Australian Bankers Association for at least taking that step. But is this good enough for Australian banking customers? Will it serve Australia and Australian customers? I cannot answer that question. Reading the Jack report, the answer is definitely not, but it may have information that has not been made available to me, and it may work.

In the area of automatic tellers and dispute resolution of the problems with automatic tellers, the banks make the quite legitimate point that, given the number of transactions, the number of complaints is very low. But I know personally of many complaints of customers. There has been an inadequate dispute resolution process. That is the good work that I think an inquiry should do. I do not think the inquiry should predetermine the outcome, but I think that the situation is ripe to protect Australian banking customers, whether they are banking with the banks, building societies or credit unions. Let us have a review from a customer perspective and then set down the groundwork for the system into the 1990s so that, with all the changes that have been accomplished, we in this House can at least have the satisfaction of knowing that these changes are definitely working in the interests of the customers. Mr Deputy Speaker, I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise today to speak on the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill. It affords me the opportunity of making some comments of an institution which, for generations, has had a very privileged position within our community. It is quite interesting that the majority of speakers on this Bill are Australian Labor Party members. It shows that we have a concern for the bank depositors. The Liberal-National Party Opposition-of course everyone knows its interest in banking-wants to remove the 13.5 per cent ceiling which the Government has forced the banks to retain. If it were to be removed, approximately 1.3 million people from all walks of life would be affected. If the Liberals ever got into power it is quite frightening to think what would happen to Australian families through the Liberals' manipulation of the banking industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me start with a definition of a bank. It is an institution offering certain financial services such as safekeeping of money and lending of money at interest. I thought that was a very interesting definition. Banks are certainly practising what they preach and what they have a charter to do. But are they making a bit too much? Are they providing a service to the public or just putting their profits before people? Some years ago the banking industry was deregulated or freed up so that overseas banks could come into Australia and create a bit of competition. It was assumed that services to the customers would improve, that competition would come about and that interest rates would drop. I suppose these things have happened. There is bigger competition now to see who can make the biggest profit. I suppose the banks are having a bit of a competition over customer service to see who can give the least service and make the customer wait the longest by closing down the branches in the various suburbs. On interest rates, I suppose the banks are seeing who can squeeze the most out of their customers without their really knowing. If honourable members have already picked up a hint of cynicism regarding banks, they are spot on. I have always believed that any organisation that receives your money and gives, say, 3.75 per cent to 5 per cent interest and then lends at 17 per cent to 22 per cent has a lot to answer for.

Let us have a look at some of the 1988 profits of the big four banks. The Westpac Banking Corporation's profit was $594m; National Australia Bank Ltd, $531m; the Australia and New Zealand Banking Corporation (ANZ), $535m; and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, $313m. I also read a few headlines in relation to bank profits. One headline reads: `ANZ boosts dividend 188pc on $505m profit'. The article in part reads:
Directors have rewarded shareholders with a 188 per cent increase in dividend in response to higher profitability and the introduction of dividend imputation.
The ANZ Bank is one of the top 15 players in relation to offshore tax havens. It puts its money offshore and does not pay any tax on it in Australia.

A headline reading `ANZ lifts profits by 60pc' outlines the half yearly results to March 1989. Another headline reads, `Three big firms head tax haven lists'. This is an interesting article because it shows not only that the ANZ Bank is amongst the top 15 in the list but also that some of our biggest companies in Australia are using the banking system to shift profits offshore, make money offshore and not pay tax. At the top of the tax haven list are News Corporation, Bond Corporation, Elders-IXL Ltd and so on. A further headline reads `ANZ pays $6m to push Dalgety stake to 25 pc'. The article reads:
ANZ has lifted its stake in Australia's second biggest pastoral house, Dalgety Farmers by four per cent to 25 per cent following recent share purchases. It paid more than $6 million for the parcel.

This could be a trend in banking as banks gradually move into those areas-Dalgety is probably one of ANZ's customers-and take over large companies that make good profits. Under the headline `NAB streaks away with $1bn profit performance' the article reads:

National Australia Bank yesterday became the first Australian bank to breach the $1 billion profit mark when it reported gross earnings of $1.01 billion for the year to September 30, a jump of 66.8 per cent over 1987.
It is interesting to note who is one of the National Australia Bank's biggest shareholders. The article continues:

From its final dividend payout, which represents an annual dividend of 50c a share, the bank's largest shareholder with 12.8 per cent, Adelaide Steamship Co.'s Mr John Spalvins will stand to receive $32.9 million in tax free cash and scrip.
The name `Mr John Spalvins' rang a bell. I went back to my files and dug out this article from Australian Business dated 9 May 1984:

Adelaide Steamship, linchpin in a group of companies stitched together by John Spalvins, provides the least amount for tax of any tax-paying company in the Statex study. Its rate: a measly 0.11 per cent.
That is 0.11c in the dollar. Mr Spalvins is a tax winner. An article headed `NAB payout up as profit soars 52pc to $480m' and `NAB scorches ahead 62 p.c.' reads:
A buoyant year of interest income growth has catapulted the National Australia Bank past the $1 billion pre-tax profit level . . .
On the same page of the Melbourne Sun there is a heading which reads `Home rates could go higher'. The Managing Director, Mr Nobby Clark, said:
If one looked at the pure numbers, one would say that we are probably getting to the stage where some further assessment would be required.

That is, interest rates should go up. One must remember that, as the Managing Director of the National Australia Bank, Mr Nobby Clark's salary is a measly $420,000 per annum, or about $8,000 per week. He has the cheek to say that his customers should pay higher interest rates! It is unbelievable what these banks put over us. We sit here mildly and meekly and say nothing about it. Another headline reads `NAB tops Westpac's profit' with a sub-heading `Nobby Clark hits back over mortgage criticism'. I could go on and on, reading headline after headline, about the amount of money that these banks have made and what they are giving back to their customers. We see the headlines, `Westpac zooms to $693m profit', `Banks to show profit bonanza continues', `Banks big profit rise' and `Commonwealth lifts profit 38 pc'.

Instead of saying good things about the banks such as how much profit they have made and what a good job they are doing for their shareholders, I would like to say a few nasty things that the banks may not like, such as advertising how much profit they have made. It is important that the general public is aware of what our banks are doing, what sort of service we are getting and what we can expect from them. I know that I will probably never get a loan from them after this speech but that does not particularly worry me. What about the report of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct? An article tucked away in a little part of a paper states that Mr Fitzgerald has criticised the banks. It reads:

But Mr Fitzgerald reserves special criticism for the Australian Bankers Association and major State branches which had ``declined to cooperate'' with the Commission's investigation of false accounts used to conceal profits from crime.
Apart from a question of amnesties for staff who might expose their own and their . . . bank accounts placed them at a disadvantage with building societies.

This is a little article of 4 July tucked away under the heading `Organised crime'. I do not know whether there is an omen there when it talks about organised crime and banks. However, it is about time, as the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) stated, that we had a close look at the banks to see exactly what they are doing to this country and to their customers. In the Melbourne Herald of 4 August 1989 there was a headline which reads `Banks ``can cut interest rates'' '. The article reads:
Australia's major banks could substantially cut interest rates and still make big profits, figures contained in a report released in the United States indicate.
Based on the figures, it would appear the National Australia Bank, Westpac and the ANZ could afford to cut mortgage rates by up to three per cent. Other interest rates could be cut accordingly.
The report, by Australia's biggest stockbroker, shows Australian banks have become among the most profitable in the world because they operate on much higher margins than banks in other countries.
In May, when the banks announced half-yearly profit increases of up to 60 per cent, they said mortgage interest rates had to stay high because of the Hawke Government's tight monetary policies.
It would now appear the policies of the banks also play a big part in keeping interest rates high.

Of course it does, and everyone knows it. How can we get the banks to change? I do not suppose that we could go as far as Jack Lang tried to go years ago. It might give them a bit of a shock now and again if they were reminded of what happened then. He was put out of government. It was something that upset the banks a bit. I believe that we should look at the banks closely and there should be an inquiry.
Another headline tucked away in the financial section at the back of the paper, which no-one ever reads, states `Banks' binge behind debt blow-out'. It is an interesting headline. The article reads:
A $3 billion foreign borrowing splurge by Australian banks-to finance the housing boom-appears to have been the main factor pushing Australia's foreign debt over the $100 billion mark in March.
All the time we hear that we have this huge overseas debt but the banks keep their debt and their borrowings tucked away very quietly. The article continues:
Banks owed $22.19 billion to foreign lenders at the end of the March quarter of this year, 24 per cent of Australia's debt-
that is, 24 per cent of Australia's debt is owed by the banks-
according to figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics yesterday.
How many people know that? Not many. It is hidden away. The article goes on:
Net debt, excluding reserve assets and overseas lending, stood at $103.9 billion at the end of March.
Bankers were at a loss yesterday to explain the big plunge into overseas debt markets as there have not been any big ``one-off'' transactions.

They are at a loss to explain; they do not want to explain it. They are borrowing money overseas at low interest rates of 3, 4 or 5 per cent, they come back here and lend it to us at rates of 17, 18 or 20 per cent, and say nothing about it. They are increasing our foreign debt and making big profits for themselves. One of the areas in which they are lending this money is in the credit area. One of the biggest problems we have in overseas debt is in plastic cards. Bankcard and Visa card contribute to half of our problems. The banks are borrowing money from overseas, lending it to us at a higher rate and we are buying overseas goods in rapid numbers. We are buying television sets, new cars, video recorders and whatever else we can get on these credit cards. The banks are increasing the amount of credit they will give us.

I would like to give a few facts and figures about Bankcard in particular. There are now eight million credit cards on issue, which averages out at one card for every two Australians. This excludes the specialised cards such as those that operate in department stores. It also excludes the charge cards: Diners Club and American Express. The amount people have chalked up on cards has escalated quite dramatically. Ten years ago Australians using bank credit cards owed $776m. By December of last year this had soared by more than 350 per cent to $3.6 billion.

Spectacular though this increase was, it was exceeded only by the amount the banks were prepared to lend to their plastic carded customers. The limits on these cards grew from $2.1 billion in 1979 to $13.4 billion in 1988, an increase of more than 520 per cent. My Visa card credit limit was increased automatically. I did not ask for it to be increased. It was increased from $1,500 to $3,000. I can go out and borrow $3,000 now and pay it back at an interest rate of about 20 per cent. Most banks now charge about 22 per cent interest on Bankcard. This is due to go higher in the next few months. These are some of the things that are happening and some of the reasons we should be looking very closely at banks.

Summing up, we should have a look at whether the banks can afford to charge less and to cut interest rates. In the year ended 30 September 1988 Westpac had an increase in profits of about 49 per cent. In the half year to 31 March 1989 it had an increase in profits of 63 per cent. The National Australia Bank had a profit increase of 62 per cent in the year ended 30 September 1988, and in the half year to 31 March 1989 a 52 per cent increase. The ANZ Bank had an increase in profits in the year ended 30 September 1988 of about 62 per cent and in the half year to 31 March 1989 an increase of 60 per cent. In the year ended 30 September 1988 the banks on average paid 40 per cent of net profits to shareholders by way of dividends. As at 30 September 1988 this had increased to 80 per cent.

The banks are selling off all their premises. They are selling off their shop fronts all over the countryside and then they are leasing them back. The banks get a tax advantage from that. That is a pretty smart move, one might say. But why should we help the banks increase their profits? I have already mentioned the Fitzgerald report, which I can assure honourable members criticises the banks very strongly. The ANZ Bank, in particular, has been listed as being one of the top 15 companies that use tax havens. Maybe we should look at a couple of solutions. Maybe we should look at freezing plastic money transactions for a set period, with the exception of those by international visitors to this country and also with the exception of electronic funds transfers. This would possibly assist in returning the country to a cash based society rather than the debt based society that it has become. Maybe we should look at placing tighter controls on financial overseas borrowings.

I would like to give a good example of how the banks are ripping off the people. I went to my bank on a Friday afternoon some months ago and paid $1,000 off my Bankcard and another $1,000 off my Visa card-I just happened to get my pay at the time. Those amounts were debited to my bank account on that Friday. Bang! No worries! The bank took it out of my account and put it somewhere else. But when I looked at the Bankcard and Visa card statements I received, it showed that the money was not paid until the following Wednesday. So the bank had the money on Saturday, Sunday, Monday, Tuesday. It is quite easy for banks to set up a computer program so that, when anyone pays $1,000 on a Bankcard or Visa card, the money goes into a special account. Those funds get placed on the short-term money market and, bingo, the banks make a lot of money. These are the sorts of things the banks are doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Change your bank.

—Where can I go? There is no competition. I think I should put my money in a box under my bed. One only has to go into a bank to see the lack of customer service provided. People have to wait in long queues. There are not enough people working on front counters. It is about time there was a bit of real competition in the banks. It is about time the banks played a part in assisting the people of Australia, those people suffering tough economic times. It is not the time for greedy and avaricious bankers to abuse the privileged position that they have within our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During his address to Parliament the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) said that the Opposition's position was to remove the 13.5 per cent ceiling which applies to certain people who have home mortgages. That is an outright falsehood. It is not supported in any way. It is typical of the Goebbels principle of particular backbenchers opposite who, day after day after day, resort to falsehoods that they keep repeating. It is a tactic they learnt from Goebbels. I concede that they are good at it. The next Government speaker will get up in a minute and say, `You have no policies'. I have here a copy of the Opposition's policy on housing. I defy any member of the Government to find anywhere in it a commitment to remove that particular 13.5 per cent limit.
—Tell us about Mr McLachlan.

—Mr McLachlan is a great Australian who taught some of the Labor union bureaucrats a few lessons that they needed to learn. We have plenty of union bureaucrats in this place and we know them all. We hear their squeals every time one of their union bureaucrat mates gets pushed around. The Australian Labor Party does not represent the working class in this place. We have plenty of proof of that with 17 per cent housing interest rates. Let us get that straight. The Government wants us to say what we will do about the 13 1/2 per cent interest rate-but we will not. But its members do not want to stand up in this place and say that it is the Government's policy-not the banks' policy-that puts 17 per cent and 25 per cent interest rates on ordinary Australians. That is the Government's policy. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) stood up last night and said, `There is nothing I can do about it. It will stay that way. But continue to love me, please'.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am saying to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that the honourable member for Dunkley is relying on the good old Goebbels principle: if he says it often enough, someone will eventually believe it. Let us get down to the written word because there has been quite a bit of discussion in recent times on this particular issue. I issued a press release on 27 June 1989 which stated:

The Shadow Minister for Housing, Wilson Tuckey, said today that the removal of the 13.5 percent home loan ceiling, which is applicable to about 30 percent of the monetary value of the housing loan commitments of financial institutions (approx. 17.3bn of the total $57.6bn-Reserve Bank figures March 1989) is not on the Coalition agenda.

We are not even giving the matter consideration, let alone making any commitment. That is what I said. That is on the record and we do not need Government members practising what Goebbels taught some of their mates in times gone by. If Government members want to continue their Goebbels practices, if they want to stand up and say `There are no policies in the Liberal Party' let me remind them that 27 have been published and one of them has the bureaucratic union mates of the Australian Labor Party terrified.

The Minister at the table, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), discovers our policies when he thinks he can criticise them. The next day he stands up in this Parliament and says that they do not exist. Have your pick! Either we do not have policies and therefore people have nothing to worry about, or we have policies. The point is that the Minister wants to have his cake and eat it too. I will say to him, `Goebbels, Goebbels, Goebbels' every time he comes up with this sort of ploy. It is outrageous. It is wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —You sound like a turkey.
—And you look like a turkey.
—Turn it up.
—Have a look at the colour of the face, for a start.
—Order! I draw the attention of the honourable member for O'Connor to the Bill before the House and ask him to return to the Bill.

—I will return to the Bill and I will return to some of the other comments of the honourable member for Dunkley. He has just engaged in a good old bank kicking exercise. I am not standing here as a defender of financial institutions but let us get one thing straight: banks deal with money in the same way as Coles and Woolworths deal with baked beans. They buy at a price and they sell at a price.

SPEECH.PARA: Another misrepresentation in the honourable member's speech was the suggestion that the banks can borrow money at 4 per cent. In general, Japanese businessmen can borrow at 4 per cent in yen, but nobody in the world will lend money to an Australian bank at 4 per cent. We are charged interest rates as a nation, and under the economic management of the Labor Government our credit rating has gone right out the window. We have no national credit rating. We are just waiting for Moody's Investors Service Inc. to pass judgment on that again. It is the economic management of honourable members opposite that has done it. If honourable members opposite were to check the assets of the banking industry which, in effect, are their loans, they would find that those assets total between $270 billion and $280 billion. If that $280 billion in assets is divided by the profits of the banking industry, it will be seen that it could not reduce interest rates by even one per cent, even if the industry gave back every penny it made. How then could the honourable member for Dunkley come to some of his conclusions? His speech would make great reading for members of his electorate, who could say that their member was battling for them. If the honourable member wants to do any good for his electorate, he should convince the Treasurer to do something for people who own homes. There was nothing in the Budget announced yesterday to help home owners, the people who put their faith in honourable members opposite and voted for them once. They will not do it again.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have jobs, which they would not have if you were in charge.

—The interjector is the fellow who said it was a load of rubbish when I suggested that high interest rates were breaking up families. Two days later it was reported in the papers that the Marriage Guidance Council was saying the same thing. We know all about the honourable member for McMillan. His callous disregard of people who are buying their homes is outrageous. The Labor Government's interest rate policy is the problem. The Government is laying down the rules. If the Treasurer had half an ounce of brain, he might ring up the Treasurers of some other countries and ask them how they can have economic growth equal to that of Australia and interest rates a quarter of those in Australia. The economic growth in Japan, the United Kingdom and America is roughly the same as that in Australia. The interest rates are half ours or even lower; yet honourable members opposite want to blame the banks.

SPEECH.PARA: The other great strategy of the Labor Party is to say that it is never its fault but always somebody else's. I am waiting for honourable members opposite to pick on Billy Hughes; he was a Liberal and the only one I can find who has not yet been criticised by honourable members opposite. The honourable member for Dunkley stood up here today and blamed the banks. It is the Labor Government's economic policy that has created the problem that is hurting Australia. The Labor Government does not know how to fix the problem and it does not have the right to fix it because Bill Kelty rings up and tells the Government the way to do things. The union bureaucrats have the Government totally under control.

Of course, the Treasurer has a wonderful background for his job. He was a union bureaucrat until the day he became a member of parliament at the age of 24. He had no experience in business and no academic training. He is a victim of everyone. He thinks he has it right.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a manager at one stage.

—I do not know when, and I have read his book. I invite the honourable member to tell me when he was a manager. I think he ran around at night doing a bit of moonlighting managing a rock group. If the truth be known, he was probably the roadie-he might have driven the truck and carted the blooming instruments. I have seen dozens of such fellows. I know what they look like. I have even employed some of them.
—Order! I suggest the honourable member return to the Bill.

—The closest the Treasurer would ever have been to managing anything would have been as a roadie. I concede that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was the managing director of Bourke's store in Melbourne. Honourable members opposite would know a bit about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dunkley clearly said that it was the Opposition's policy to remove the 13.5 per cent ceiling on some home loan interest rates. I reject that. Not one word in our policy document says that. In recent times I have put out press releases refuting even suggestions that we should consider it. I might add that some of the lobby groups that would like to see the ceiling removed would not be too pleased with our stance, but they got it straight. The Liberal Party will not consider changing that ceiling. Our policy is to get interest rates down so that everybody enjoys a better interest rate, and not having to jack up the interest rates of those with a small privilege at present. We know that most of them have quite small loans anyway and we have no intention of altering the rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debate on the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill has become fairly wide-ranging, covering questions of banking, savings and housing policy and, indeed, national economic policy. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) to some degree has livened up the debate and broadened it. I will respond to a couple of the comments that he made in relation to overall macro-economic policy. The honourable member for O'Connor suggested that a Liberal-National Party government would bring down interest rates. Indeed, one of his shadow Ministers, Senator Austin Lewis, only some days ago on national radio suggested that within a matter of a couple of years a Liberal-National Party government would have interest rates down to 5 per cent.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member knows that the statement that he just made about Senator Austin Lewis is false, and that Senator Austin Lewis issued a statement clarifying that position. He never said it and it should not be repeated.
—I call the honourable member for Bendigo.

—I do not want to get into a debate with an individual Opposition member in the House, but I heard the interview with Senator Lewis and there is no question but that he said that within a matter of years a Liberal-National Party government would have interest rates at 5 per cent. He was rebuffed the next day by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) for being a fool.
—Order!

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: If the honourable member wishes to continue with this, I will also. If I provide him with a transcript of the interview, I assume he will apologise to the House.
—Order! I had not in fact called the honourable member for Warringah. I call the honourable member for Bendigo.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. To return to the subject matter before the House, I was responding to some of the comments by the honourable member for O'Connor. I simply want to make this point: the Budget the Government released last night contains a set of economic statistics which, although certainly not perfect, are immeasurably superior to the economic environment which the Government inherited in 1983. In 1982-83 under the previous Liberal Government interest rates were 23 per cent. The trade deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product was no lower than it is today. We had double digit inflation. We had double digit unemployment. Far from having a Budget surplus of $9.1 billion, such as the Government announced last night-the largest surplus ever in Australia's history-we had a $9.6 billion deficit. So there has been a dramatic turnaround in the Australian economy in the six years in which this Government has been in office.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax levels in the Budget announced last night, at 26.2 per cent of gross domestic product, are identical to the proportions which existed in 1981-82 and 1982-83 under the previous Liberal Government. We have turned around a prospective $9.6 billion deficit in 1983 from the Liberals to a $9 billion surplus. We have done it through better government, smaller government, and proper targeting of government programs. We have achieved it without any real increase in overall taxation levels. I just say that in response to the honourable member for O'Connor because he came into the House with a housing policy. He said that the Opposition was committed to maintaining the ceiling of 13.5 per cent.

What is really at issue in this debate is the Opposition's tax policy. For the last year, since August 1988, I have waited for the tax policy promised for release at that time by the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), to be released. It is now August 1989, some 12 months later; we still have not seen the tax and macro-economic policy of the Opposition parties. It is cant and hypocrisy for people to come into the House and say that they will bring down interest rates through their policies but then not elaborate on what those policies are. In fairness to the Parliament and the Australian people, it is incumbent on the Opposition parties to release that policy as soon as possible so that the public and the markets can make a judgment as to whether interest rates would come down. Interest rates are important because we are discussing a Bill in relation to banking, savings and trading banks, and so on. It is impossible to talk on a banking legislation Bill without bringing into the debate these questions of overall savings levels and macro-economic policy.

I want to make a few points in this debate about the question of savings levels in Australia. There is a need-and the Government recognises it-to increase private and aggregate savings levels in the Australian economy. In recent weeks there has been considerable interest in the issue of one alleged way to increase national savings through inflation adjusting the tax system. Comprehensive inflation adjustment involves changing the tax treatment of monetary assets and liabilities, stocks, capital gains and the depreciation arrangements for physical assets. In recent weeks we have seen a proposal-released, to be fair, only in broad form-by the Opposition parties which has focused on a partial inflation adjustment system. The key features of that system, as we can gather them from newspaper reports, are that the Opposition has proposed a reduction in tax deductions for interest expense, but with some provisos-with the grandfathering of existing borrowings, a reduction in the taxable proportion of interest receipts from banks and building societies, and possibly some form of phasing in of the new arrangements.

In this debate, which concerns banking and savings, pursuing either a partial or comprehensive inflation adjustment scheme in my view would have disastrous implications for the Australian economy and would do nothing to lift either private or aggregate savings levels across the Australian economy. There are flaws in this inflation adjustment proposal. In academic circles a comprehensive inflation adjustment proposal is seen to have some merit but I believe that a partial inflation adjustment proposal is seriously flawed indeed. I will explain why I think that is so.

Firstly, such a proposal is somewhat lopsided. If one inflation adjusts certain interest but not stocks or depreciation, one will ensure that there are lopsided and erratic effects on the Australian economy. If one adjusted interest but not stocks or depreciation, the assets side of the balance sheet of Australian business would be taxed without inflation adjustment but the liabilities would be inflation adjusted. To adjust only interest rates, while leaving stocks and depreciation unaffected, would represent a major tax burden on business investments.

The second flaw in the proposal is that it would fail to recognise Australia's place in the international economy. Two things have become certain in the decade of the 1980s. One is that, in the decade of the 747, people travel much more widely all around the world; so there is a much greater movement of people around the world. The other phenomenon is economic-that, increasingly, economies have become integrated into a world economic system. Australia is not insulated from the rest of the world; we are very much part of the international economy. If partial inflation adjustment occurred in Australia this country would be throwing its lot in with a few of the high-inflation countries in the Third World which have so far experimented with these systems. A country such as Australia, which is exposed to international finance markets, cannot sustain a tax system which is dramatically out of line with those of our major competitors. The Hawke Government has achieved a great deal to move our tax system far closer to those applying in the major countries with which we do business. Even more importantly, if we could sustain such a position in the long run we would have to suffer the enormous costs of adjusting to that position.

It is an international commercial reality that companies combine equity funds with borrowings in order to maximise their returns for shareholders. In every developed country except Australia they would be able to get full deductions for interest on their borrowings. If only interest were adjusted, our taxes on business investments would be considerably higher than elsewhere in the world. That would have some implications. In many cases then shareholders would prefer to make their next investment overseas rather than in Australia, so more Australian equity would flow out of Australia and less foreign capital would flow into Australia. The sudden fall in the attraction of capital inflow and that increased incentive for capital outflow would cause a sharp drop in the value of the Australian dollar. It would in that sense increase inflation and probably bring about a decline in investment. Ironically, all of those repercussions probably would produce a depressed Australian economy. There would be a sudden shock in the Australian economy and the net effect, possibly and ironically, would be a drop in national savings-and certainly not an increase.

The third point I want to make about this partial inflation adjustment proposal is that it would increase tax on certain forms of savings. The Opposition has indicated that, in floating this inflation adjustment proposal, it is motivated by a desire to increase savings levels. That is a worthwhile and commendable objective, but it is important that total national savings rise and not just savings of one kind at the expense of another. The Opposition proposal involves a reduction in the tax on saving and an increase in the tax on borrowing, as explained by the Leader of the Opposition. That explanation seems to stem from a basic misunderstanding. The Opposition's proposal involves a redistribution of taxes on savings and not any reduction in taxes on savings.

It needs to be understood that savings in Australia, if we analyse them, are undertaken by business and government as well as by households. A very large part of Australia's savings comprises the equity investments of Australians in large and small businesses and farms. The return on those savings in business is increased by the ability of businesses to borrow. It is a nonsense to claim, as some people have, that business savings would not fall because borrowed funds would be replaced by equity capital. If the tax on business is increased, the return on business savings is reduced and there will be less of it. If we look at the proposal from an economy-wide viewpoint, inflation adjustment of interest does not necessarily have much net effect on aggregate savings. The proposal would change the pattern of savings and may change the relative returns of different activities in the economy but would not necessarily increase total savings. Worst of all, if it were badly designed, the proposal could reduce overall national savings.

The fourth flaw in the proposal is extremely relevant to the Bill before the House. It concerns the distortions that a partial inflation adjustment proposal would introduce in the Australian economy. The Opposition has floated a proposal that only some types of interest and some classes of debt would be inflation adjusted. But, as with anything of an economic nature, if one picks and chooses one creates distortion. There will be some winners and some losers. I think it is fair to say that in the proposal the Opposition has put up there would be massive distortions in savings patterns across the Australian economy. For example, the Opposition has said that it would inflation adjust interest only on bank and building society accounts and building society deposits. If we examine that proposition we see that it would seriously bias the tax system. For example, households would find it less advantageous to invest in shares, equity trusts, credit unions, friendly societies, life offices, unit trusts, cash management trusts and State and Commonwealth bonds and debentures. Even family borrowing arrangements, which are common among small businesses, no longer would be viable and the relative advantages of superannuation savings also would be eroded. Over time these changes would tend to break down longer term savings arrangements in favour of short term bank deposits, making the savings systems markedly less efficient than they are today. The banks would be the big winners because their competition would be weakened.

One of the other implications of this proposal is that it would create some winners and some losers amongst households in the Australian community. For instance, when looking at the question of partial inflation adjustment for money in banks and building societies one needs to look at who would be the main beneficiaries of that plan. Obviously, people with the greatest amount of money in the banks would stand to gain the most. The well-off would get the maximum benefit from this proposal which has been put up by the Leader of the Opposition. Figures provided by the Australian Taxation Office, for instance, show that of the total cost to revenue of the Opposition's proposal 50 per cent would go to 20 per cent of taxpayers at the very top of the income scale. Looking at it another way, the Australian Taxation Office statistics show that taxpayers on $100,000 a year or more typically declare sufficient interest to benefit from the Opposition's proposal by around $90 a week. Someone on $100,000 a year, with savings in a bank or building society, would be better off by around $90 a week. However, taxpayers in the $20,000 to $30,000 bracket, which is where most taxpayers are in Australia, typically declare sufficient interest in their bank accounts to benefit by only $4 a week.

In summary, under the partial inflation adjustment proposal, as explained by the Leader of the Opposition, by providing a tax break to people with money in banks and building societies, the beneficiaries will be the very wealthy in the Australian community-people on an income of $100,000 a year or more. Under the proposal put forward by the Leader of the Opposition one will get $90 a week if one earns more than $100,000 a year, and $4 week if one is only an average income earner. For that reason alone this proposition is badly flawed. The banking system as a whole, for reasons which I do not have time to go into in detail, would also be a major beneficiary of the plan put up by the Leader of the Opposition.

There are other flaws in this proposal. There would be a heavy burden on many small business people-farmers, small businesses and investors. The grandfathering is impossible to implement. There are problems of rolling over loans. How will it be decided whether a loan is an old loan or a new loan? There are problems with gearing levels between different firms. Of course, there are massive opportunities, in a partial inflation adjustment proposal, for tax avoidance on a grand scale probably, similar to the level that occurred in Australia in the 1970s.

In summary, I want to say this about savings: obviously national savings are the difference between the value of what Australia produces-its national income-and what Australians spend. Households save, obviously, if they receive more income than they spend. Businesses save if they receive more from their sales than they pay out in expenses, wages and dividends. Governments save if they take more in revenue than they spend on outlays. There is a big difference between national savings and a simple bank account. To focus, as the Opposition has done, on a program to improve national savings simply by looking at bank accounts is a very badly flawed proposition indeed. In last night's Budget the Government announced massive changes to retirement incomes policy and superannuation in Australia. In time we will achieve considerable-indeed, massive-increases in aggregate and private savings levels in Australia. We will achieve that responsibly and sensibly through encouraging and providing incentives for people to save in the form of superannuation, and at the same time we will be providing individuals with the benefit through a better retirement income level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to thank those honourable members who participated in this rather broad ranging debate both in the earlier session and this morning. The Government welcomes the support which the Opposition has given to the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill during the debate, but there are a few points upon which I would like to comment.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the removal of the distinction between trading and savings banks, the Government is aware of the wish on the part of the banks concerned for a further legislative provision to directly facilitate the integration of trading and savings banks. As I indicated in my second reading speech the Government is considering the possibility of further legislative action for this purpose. On the subject of re-regulation of the banking sector, I note there has been a suggestion that the proposed amendment to the Banking Act to introduce a power for the prudential regulation of banks could amount to re-regulation of the banking sector by the back door. The Government considers that any suggestion along these lines is quite unwarranted. Supervision of banks is directed at the protection of depositors and the stability of the financial system. The pre-1980s banking regulations involved determining the terms and conditions under which banks could borrow and lend funds. It is clear from a reading of the Bill that the new powers are confined to prudential matters which are defined in the Bill.

The proposed changes are intended essentially to give a clearer statutory basis for the arrangement for the prudential supervision of banks which have long operated on an informal basis. Given the increased number of banks now operating in Australia and the more dynamic market environment in which banks now compete, it is desirable that there should be a clear statutory basis for the Reserve Bank of Australia to supervise banks. At the same time it is envisaged that the Reserve Bank's supervision will continue to operate through informal consultation and cooperation, since that approach has so far worked well. The new powers will be kept in reserve to be used only as necessary.

There has also been concern expressed regarding the provision in clause 16 of the Bill which provides a power for the Reserve Bank to conduct investigations into specified prudential matters relating to a bank. The Government does not believe that the proposed new clause should give rise to concern. To put this question in perspective it is worth noting that powers to conduct investigations into the affairs of a bank or seek information from it are currently available under sections 61 and 62 of the Banking Act. Only two changes would be made by the Bill in this area.

Firstly, the power of investigation will be vested in the Reserve Bank rather than with the Auditor-General. It is logical that this power should be vested in the same institution which has the responsibility for the prudential supervision of banks. Secondly, the Bill will enable the Reserve Bank to obtain information about the affairs of an individual customer. However, I want to emphasise that this will be permitted only if the affairs of the individual customer are relevant to the prudential standing of the bank. In practice, this power is likely to be used when the exposure of a bank to an individual customer is significant in relation to the bank's capital. Exposures of this magnitude would usually be incurred in relation to corporate institutions rather than individuals. It is necessary that the Reserve Bank have access to such information because, in order to discharge properly its responsibilities in relation to the depositors in each bank and to the broader financial system, it may need to know the extent to which banks could potentially be affected by large credit exposures. I note that the Opposition shares this view.

The Government does not believe there is any reason for concern regarding the indiscriminate use of the Reserve Bank power as suggested by the Opposition. It is fundamental to the successful discharge of the supervisory duties of the Reserve Bank that it maintain close and constructive relationships with banking institutions. The Reserve Bank will have no reason to impair these relationships by making injudicious demands upon the banks. Both the officers and the agents of the Reserve Bank are required by regulations to protect the secrecy of information in the possession of the bank. We should recognise the exemplary record of the Reserve Bank over many years in protecting the information it has received in the course of its duties. Accordingly, the Government is confident that any information that the Reserve Bank may need to obtain for prudential purposes will be adequately protected. I thank those honourable members who have participated in the debate in the earlier session and this session, and I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 15, page 8, before proposed paragraph 51 (1) (a) insert the following paragraph:
``(aa) requiring a bank to prepare, and to give to the Reserve Bank, accounts and financial statements;''.
(2) Clause 15, page 8, line 8, insert ``accounts and financial statements are to be prepared and given or in which the'' after ``in which the''.
(3) Clause 15, page 8, line 9, insert ``accounts, financial statements or'' before ``information''.
(4) Clause 15, page 8, lines 12 and 13, omit ``such an obligation to give information'', substitute ``an obligation of the kind mentioned in paragraph (a)''.

The amendments are intended to allow banks to prepare annual accounts in accordance with the requirements under the Banking Act rather than those established for companies generally by the Companies Code. Section 288 (3) of the Companies Code provides that if a bank is required to prepare accounts under a Commonwealth banking law and the accounts of the bank comply with that law, they are deemed to comply with the requirements of the Code. Banks are currently required by part VI of the Banking Act to prepare and deliver accounts to the Reserve Bank of Australia. The purpose of the new part VI proposed by clause 15 of the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill is to rationalise the arrangements for the collection of statistical information from banks and make them more flexible. To achieve this, proposed new section 51 provides for the Governor-General to make regulations specifying the information which banks would be required to submit to the Reserve Bank and the manner in which information would be submitted. However, proposed section 51 does not provide that banks may be required to prepare accounts. Unless amended, the new section may not have the effect that section 288 (3) of the Companies Code would apply to banks. The proposed amendment to clause 15 will ensure that the current position of banks in relation to section 288 (3) can be maintained through the regulations. I commend the amendments to the Committee.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being after 12.45 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 101a, I shall report progress.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. If, as the Treasurer has stated, `every cent of the Commonwealth's $9 billion surplus will be used to pay back debt', how does the Prime Minister propose to fund the tax cuts in the wage-tax trade-off package he foreshadowed last week?

—I find the question almost incomprehensible. The simple facts are that, as far as the Government is concerned, we have taken the decision to create a surplus of $9.1 billion. As we said in April when we made the announcement, that will enable us to fund the tax cuts and still retain the thrust of the Budget to take that amount of money out of the spending capacity in the community. There is no question at all of the technical capacity of the Commonwealth to do it.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware of claims that the Government's retirement income policy, announced last night, does nothing for women? Given that the current labour force participation rate of women has reached historically high levels, could the Minister explain how the measures contained in the Government's retirement income policy will be of benefit to women in the work force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is totally false to claim that the retirement income policy neglects women workers; in fact, their concerns are placed at the centre of our comprehensive and integrated retirement income policy. The measures developed by the Government will significantly increase women's superannuation coverage; implement arrangements that are more responsive to women's employment patterns; and improve the level of their superannuation benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: Award based superannuation, initiated by the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, has extended superannuation to many women for the first time ever. The Government is committed to the further extension of award based superannuation and will consider the gradual introduction of a further 3 per cent. The Government will also change access to tax assisted personal superannuation to better reflect women's employment patterns. Women working as few as 10 hours a week or who are outside the paid work force for up to two years will be granted access to tax assisted superannuation from next July. Changes to superannuation reasonable benefit limits will also particularly assist women. These changes will allow funds to increase substantially reversionary benefits to widows and will base limits for tax assisted benefits on a worker's highest average salary in any three consecutive years rather than the final three years of employment.

Award based superannuation provides for full vesting and preservation to age 55 or later retirement. Many old schemes operating before the 1986 reforms have inadequate vesting and preservation arrangements. This particularly disadvantages women who stay for short periods with an employer or who leave and later re-enter the work force. These measures fully implement-I emphasise `fully implement'-the Government's commitments in the National Agenda for Women on retirement income matters. The age pension will remain for those who have not had adequate opportunities to save for retirement. As we know, 70 per cent of people who depend on the age pension are women. The Government has made a commitment not only to exceed 25 per cent of average weekly earnings but also, as conditions permit, to provide for further increases.

Women can also be confident that the Government will monitor the progress of women's participation in superannuation and labour market opportunities, particularly during the period from 1995, when improved vesting and preservation standards apply, before giving consideration to an increase in the age pension or service pension age for women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the House that we have present in the gallery the Rt Hon. Lord Mackay of Clashfern, the United Kingdom Lord Chancellor. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitor.
—My question is directed to the Treasurer. What is the projected ratio of net foreign debt to gross domestic product (GDP) by the end of this financial year?

—Off the top of my head, I could not recall the number we have in. The honourable member can do the sums himself with a calculator. He just has to work out what he thinks GDP is from the papers. I do not have to answer the honourable member's puny question by doing research for him.
—Will the Minister for Community Services and Health inform honourable members whether the Government has taken steps to ensure that child-care remains within the reach of low income families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity of saying that the honourable member for Phillip has been one of the Government members who have done much to develop the policy of child-care within the Government ranks. The theme of equity and affordability is central to the changes that have been made this year in the Budget as it relates to child-care. As all honourable members know, because they have experienced it in their own electorates, this Government has presided over a massive expansion of publicity funded child-care. Since we came to office we have more than doubled the number of places-from 46,000 to 114,000 today-and we are committed to another 30,000 over the next three years. A total of 8,200 will be in place by the end of this financial year, and the Budget provides for those extra places.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, this year's Budget has concentrated on ensuring that child-care remains affordable to lower income families. Honourable members will recall that in 1984 this Government introduced fee relief for families in child-care centres, designed to benefit lower income families. This Budget announces that the Government intends for the first time to index this fee annually, so that the fee relief payments will be adjusted from now on each year. The fee relief ceilings for government funded child-care will rise to $92.50 for the long-day centres and to $68 for family day care schemes. Again, with the same point in mind, to make the system as equitable as possible we have decided to increase from $255 per week gross to $280 per week gross the threshold income at which users start to pay more than minimum fees. These initiatives will mean a rise of $7 per week per child in government assistance to families receiving that relief and that will be adjusted each year in line with inflation.

In addition, the Budget also provides increases in operational subsidies for all kinds of government funded child-care, which includes occasional care centres, family day care schemes and long-day centres this year. Further, for the first time the Government has proposed a new fee relief scheme to assist lower income families making use of outside school hours care. We are approaching the States to cost-share this fee relief scheme in outside school hours care.

I believe that these measures acknowledge the crucial role of child-care not only in our social policies but also in our economic policies and will extend the affordability of child-care to families in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Treasurer. What is the revenue effect of bracket creep for the 1989-90 financial year?

—There seems to be a total misunderstanding of the Budget concept this year on the part of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition asked a question earlier about the tax cuts. The tax cuts are funded in this year's Budget. Were it not for the tax cuts, the Budget would not be $9.1 billion in surplus, it would be $14.6 billion. I then get a question from the shadow Treasurer asking what will be the effect of bracket creep over the course of the year, when the largest tax cut in our history is being funded from this year. So where the balance between collections and tax cuts finally lies, I am not certain. There is quite a clear commentary about some of these points in Budget Statement No. 2. The main point is that the tax share in gross domestic product this year will be the same as in the year when the last Government was in office; that is, in the last two years of the Budgets of the Fraser Government the revenue share in GDP was 26.2 per cent, which is the same as is forecast for this year. But instead of a Budget deficit of $9 billion plus which was bequeathed to this Government we have a surplus of $9 billion. There is a surplus of over 2 per cent of GDP on the same revenue share which the Opposition had when it was last in office. So how does that grab you?

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In view of the significance of the Australian live sheep trade to Saudi Arabia which is worth $130m per year-and I know my farmers in Ballarat are very concerned about this-can the Minister advise what steps the Government has taken to clarify quarantine issues raised by the Saudi Arabian Government in recent weeks? Can the Minister further advise whether any additional evidence as to the disease status of recent live sheep shipments has come to light?

—I thank the honourable member for his question and his ongoing interest in this issue. Honourable members may be interested to note that he has asked me four times as many questions this year as has the shadow spokesman for primary industry.
—And you have organised every one of them.

—No. As honourable members would be aware, three shipments of live sheep to Saudi Arabia have been rejected by the Saudi authorities in recent weeks on the contention that bluetongue and sheep pox were present in some sheep. I stress that Australian authorities have been given no evidence that the sheep were in fact infected and, having regard to Australia's internationally accepted animal health status, we have not accepted the Saudi view. However, there is a clear need to ensure that the live sheep trade with Saudi Arabia is conducted on a stable, transparent basis. To that end the Government has been in close contact with Saudi Arabian Ministers and the Saudi Arabian Ambassador in Canberra. I have announced today that a high level delegation, to be headed by Dr Gardner Murray, an executive director of my Department, will shortly be leaving for Riyadh to hold discussions with the Saudi Arabian authorities. I should emphasise that the Government is concerned to ensure that an agreed means of handling any concerns which the Saudi Arabians may have about Australia's sheep disease status in future be established. The decision to send such a high level delegation to Saudi Arabia is supported by Australian sheep producers and export industry groups which met with my Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Sydney yesterday. I would also like to assure the House that the Government is closely monitoring the issue.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. In light of Simon Crean's comment that the Budget does not contain a trading strategy and of today's current account deficit of over $1.7 billion for July, when will the Government remove impediments to export growth such as its illogical three mines policy for uranium, the floor price for uranium and the coal export levy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very interesting question from the Leader of the National Party of Australia as to the existence or absence of strategies, because he delivered a remarkable observation this morning when he was entering Parliament House. I do not know whether he was recovering from a late night or whether there is any other reasonably innocuous explanation for what he said. The question put to him was this:

ANSWER.PARA: When would you like to see the Opposition's policies released?
He replied:
Well, we've released nearly 30 policies.
He was then asked:
Economic policies?
The answer was:
Well when the Prime Minister tells us when the election is, then we'll tell you when we're going to release our policies.

This man has the temerity to get up in this place and ask about the existence or non-existence of our policies! He is telling the Australian people that the Opposition will not release its economic policies until the Prime Minister announces the election date. Have honourable members ever heard anything more politically irresponsible? I wonder whether that is the position of the Leader of the Opposition, because it is not what he has been saying, and it is not what the shadow Treasurer has been saying. We have been getting different statements from them: it was going to be released in April this year, then it was going to be in June, then it was going to be in August, and then--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. I refer to standing order 145, which relates to relevance. The question put to the Prime Minister is of great national importance and he wants to do the only thing he is good at and make a couple of jokes. It is not even funny.
—Order! The honourable member has put his point of order. The Prime Minister will now answer the question.

—I was just giving a nice introduction to the answer, Madam Speaker. It was a very relevant introduction. What I gently said about my good friend and soon-to-be colleague on this side of the House after the next election, whenever I announce it, was that Simon had not quite got it right. That is the case. We can have circumstances in which otherwise very erudite, learned, well-informed people can get it slightly wrong. My good friend Simon Crean, the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, got it slightly wrong. In fact, the strategy of the Government is quite clear, in regard to both the question of inflation that he was particularly talking about, and lowering the current account deficit.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Treasurer has had cause to say, we should not only look at the year-on-year average; it is very important in the financial year 1989-90 to look at what is happening through the course of the year. In regard to inflation, as I pointed out when commenting upon Simon Crean's observation, we expect that through the course of the year inflation will be trending down. Why do we say that? We can identify three specific reasons why that will be the case. Firstly, there will be, as we pointed out, a significant easing of demand pressures associated with the strategy of the Budget. In regard to the strategy of the Budget and reaction to the Budget, I make the observation that in the less than 24 hours that have transpired since the Treasurer delivered the Budget, two things have become clear. One is the responsibility and honesty of the Budget. The second thing that has emerged is the pathetic irrelevancy of the Opposition. The reaction is best summed up by what was said on AM this morning by a spokesperson for Shearson, Layman and Hutton, the United States firm.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Moody's in New York?
—Order! The House will come to order. The honourable member for Bruce will come to order.

—The spokesperson for Shearson, Layman and Hutton, one Lisa Sinstrom, is a remarkably perspicacious person. What did Lisa Sinstrom have to say? She said that the Budget is surprisingly honest, given that it is the last one before the next election. She also said:

ANSWER.PARA: He's-
the Treasurer-
not trying to make things look any, you know, sort of better than they actually are. So I think that that should give them some credibility.
Then she delivered this obviously delectable aside:
And to be fair, they really don't have too much in the way of opposition anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. My point of order again relates to relevance. You have just complained about the noise on this side, yet you are tolerating the Prime Minister doing anything but telling us about the Government's three mines uranium policy and those other questions--
—Order! The Prime Minister is answering the question.

—As I was saying, by way of a slight aside, to put it in context, on the two questions that Simon Crean talked about-that is, inflation and the current account situation-we expect through the year the inflation situation to improve. I said that that would be for three reasons. The first I have gone to, that is, the easing of demand. Secondly, the increased impetus to price movements resulting from the increase in the price of vegetables because of the floods in New South Wales will, if I can say so, wash out of the system this year. Thirdly, we believe that there will be a decline in house prices and, by the end of the year, a decline in mortgage interest rates. So there is a strategy; there is in operation a number of factors which will involve, through the year, a decline in the rate of inflation.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the current account situation is concerned, I think it would be instructive if we looked at some of the figures that are contained in the papers associated with the Budget because that will give an indication of just what we expect to be happening during the year. Let us look at imports. In 1988-89 there was a 25 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I take a point of order.
—We are coming to it.
—The Prime Minister tells me that he is coming to it. So is Christmas. I asked a question which related to two aspects of the uranium policy and the coal export levy.
—Order! The Prime Minister is answering the question.
—I do not know what the price of vegetables has to do with it.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Madam Speaker, speaking to the point of order: on the question of relevance, the honourable gentleman's question referred not just to the question of uranium--
—Order!

—I am speaking to the point of order. The honourable gentleman's question referred not just to the question of uranium. He included in his preamble a discussion of what Simon Crean had had to say and he also asked a question which related to the overall trading policy of the Government. I would say that this answer is manifestly relevant and the repeated interjections by honourable members on the other side in the form of points of order are disorderly.
—I was saying, in directly answering the question, that we had a situation--

—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. The Minister for Defence, in his concluding remarks, reflected on you, the Chair. You gave no ruling in respect of those comments by the Minister for Defence. Is there a ruling in respect of that further comment by the Minister for Defence?
—As I have said three times before, the Prime Minister is answering the question. He is entitled to answer the question in his own way.

—In 1988-89 we had a 25 per cent increase in imports and a 3 per cent increase is projected for 1989-90. In 1988-89 there was a one per cent increase in exports and there is a projected increase of 7 1/2 per cent for 1989-90. That will involve a massive turnaround in net exports, which intrinsically is what Simon Crean was talking about and what the honourable gentleman has addressed his question to. We will have a turnaround of over 5 percentage points. In 1988-89 net exports contributed minus 4.4 per cent and they are expected to contribute three-quarters of a percentage point positive in 1989-90. So that is a turnaround of over 5 per cent, and that will be consistent with what the Treasurer and I have been talking about-that is, that we have been making the decisions in this country in a whole range of areas, including the mining industry, which have involved investment and which are now bringing into place projects which will have income and export streams starting this year and going on into the future.

ANSWER.PARA: Specifically, if members of the Opposition want to talk about uranium, I have nothing more to say on that point than I have said before: that the policy of this Government has been properly arrived at. We have a three-mine policy and, under that policy, the existing producers are having difficulty getting adequate prices for their production. As you would know, Madam Speaker, the Labor Party is conducting an inquiry within its processes into the overall uranium policy. I will not pre-empt the findings of that inquiry but, in regard to the present situation, it would be manifestly absurd to suggest that to have any more uranium mines in this country would add to Australia's export potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Last night the Treasurer announced a major restructuring of the interaction of the social security income test and taxation for age pensioners. Can the Minister inform the House of the basis of this reform, which will be achieved by 1995, and explain how it will improve retirement incomes for older Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some respects I think the difference between the Government and the Opposition on this issue is that we are interested in more than a question of attitude towards age pensioners or reform; we are interested in actually spelling out, in a clear-cut and fundamental way, what reform will mean in areas that are understood to be crucial, not only in terms of the work done by those responsible for reviewing the social security system but also in areas which are seen by people at the grassroots as being important issues for age pensioners today.

ANSWER.PARA: We have approached the question of reform in the relationship between the income test and the tax treatment of income in stages. In April this year we announced the first and extremely important stage. For all full rate pensioners the income test free area-$40 for single pensioners and $70 for married pensioners-will become tax free by July next year. Historically, for the first time we will ensure that there is identity of treatment for full rate pensioners, so that all full rate pensioners will no longer pay tax when that reform is completed in July next year. The Treasurer, in his statement, indicated a second stage in that reform. The Government will lock in the reform in terms of indexation. It will ensure from July 1991 that, henceforth, there will be no question of full rate pensioners paying tax and the value of that free area is to be maintained in real terms-an extraordinarily important reform. It is not a question of attitude or of saying `Somehow we will improve things'; it is a specific reform which will lock in the change announced in April this year, which I think gave pensioners a sense of credibility about this whole process.

Thirdly, the Government has made it very clear that this business of reform will not be all over in a day or two, a month or two, or a year or two. This reform will be carried out over a period, and bringing about that change will not be costless. So, from July 1995 we will ensure that all pensioners are removed altogether from the taxation system. In terms of simplicity, we will achieve what has never been achieved before. In regard to any withdrawal rate, which effectively will be via social security, we will ensure that we do not exceed 50c in the dollar.
