The problem of effective marginal tax rates, often bleated about by the Opposition, will be resolved by this Government.

What do we get from Opposition members at this point in time? We get griping criticism about their having thought of it. There was nothing in the policy statement put out by the Opposition that went clearly to the mechanism that might be employed to achieve a solution to the problem of high effective marginal tax rates and a way of achieving the kind of positive incentives for retirement income savings which, over time, would enable a fundamental change in retirement income policy so that we get the right balance between the government pension and annuities or superannuation; a proper balance in terms of retirement income. This Government, more than any previous government, has shown that it can deal with the central issue that the population is ageing. In the next 40 years, as many people will be over the age of 65 as have moved into that age group in the last 80 years. All that additional cost can be sensibly resolved by a mechanism which will simplify, make more equitable and provide a positive long term direction. That is solid policy. What we have heard from the Opposition is emotional claptrap.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. The July balance of payments figures suggest that the economy is still growing strongly. If economic growth in the September quarter is about one per cent, is it a fact that the Budget growth forecasts imply no further growth in the remaining three quarters of this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Treasurer was banging this drum last night. Let me straighten him up on what it means. He is talking about a recession. He ought to know. He and the former Treasurer were the recession specialists. In 1982-83 they gave us the first negative growth for 30 years. As I have said in this House on a number of occasions, it takes an extra special talent to actually make an economy contract, but that is what the previous Government managed to do.
—We are getting further into debt.

—The Opposition was in office. Its members were around the corridors. They were around giving the advice. What we saw was less than zero. We had a contraction. That is what a recession is. We have got in here 2 3/4 per cent growth on average for the year, which is a respectable number by Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development standards. It is slower than last year, but not much slower. On the national accounts, last year's figure was 3.3; this is 2 3/4. That will imply some slowing over the course of the year, but it will not mean a recession.

ANSWER.PARA: The balance of payments figure today has no implication for growth in the economy. It only has the implication for demand conditions which obtained six or nine months ago when imports were ordered then. Today's balance of payments figure is well within the current account forecast published in the Budget last night. In today's number, exports were up 6 per cent, seasonally adjusted. They have been growing by 7 per cent on average for the last five years. It is the highest rate of growth for the last 25 years. In other words, we have accomplished the fundamental restructuring of the economy that evaded the Opposition for so long.

I gave the figures last night and I will give them again. In the five years to 1988-90, we had an average rate of investment growth of 10.8 per cent. In the Opposition's previous five years, it was 1.6 per cent. In other words, our growth rate in investment has been seven times stronger. In the five years before that to 1978, it was 2.3 per cent. If one extracts from that the investment boom in the mining sector which came by virtue of the fact that the Japanese wanted Australian coal to offset their Middle East oil imports, which had nothing to do with Australian domestic economic policy, one sees that the Opposition's investment record in the 10 years to when we took office was zero against 10.8 per cent a year on average. So the fundamental restructuring which has eluded the economy for 15 years has been successful in the last five years. It is there because of a pick-up in the profit share, because of a massive shift in the factor shares from wages to profits, because of a dramatic shift in public saving and because of a reduction of 8 percentage points in the public sector borrowing requirement, making the private sector of the economy so much bigger and more robust, with a reduction in company tax. Is it any wonder that we have got an investment surge of this dimension? That is what will maintain growth through the coming year. As domestic demand falls off, it will be net exports that will carry the economy as we shift our production into the external sector, to exports and to import replacement.

If the shadow Treasurer looks at the Budget forecast, he will find that exports are growing on average by 7 per cent through the year, meaning that later on in the year they will be growing faster than 7 per cent. It is that export growth that will hold up gross domestic product and avoid a recession. So the whole premise of his question is wrong. To have a recession, one has to get under zero to have the economy contract. I am afraid that only he and his colleagues, the honourable member for Bennelong and Senator Stone, are clever enough to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In view of the fact that very significant technological advancement has occurred in the areas of solar and wind generation, making these renewable energy sources increasingly attractive and attainable, can the Minister inform the House what progress is being made to encourage the development of such renewable energy resources and to reward conservation, particularly given the fact that many State energy authorities may be hooked on their own agendas which are based on increased consumption and traditional energy sources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government provides support for the development of renewable energy and energy efficient technologies through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council program. Since that program commenced in 1978, some $62m has been committed to projects in these areas. Examples would include, in the honourable member's own State, wind farm demonstration at Esperance in cooperation with the State Energy Commission of Western Australia, development of improved domestic solar water heaters, development of high efficiency photo voltaic cells and systems for remote area application.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's commitment to this area was further demonstrated by the announcement in December 1987 that an additional $5m would be made available over five years for research into renewable energy, energy efficiency and energy conservation. We also provide support for programs to encourage energy conservation. Over the past decade some $7m has been committed to these programs, much of that in close co- operation with the States. In recognition of the importance of conservation the Government has also announced a doubling of its commitment to programs in this area from $1m in 1989-90 to a further increase of $1.4m in 1990-91.

Picking up the last point in the honourable member's question, there have been a number of claims that deficiencies exist in State electricity policies. Honourable members would be aware that the Treasurer last night announced a proposed inquiry into the efficiency of resource use in electricity generation and distribution to be conducted by the new Industry Commission. Of course, State governments will be consulted before proceeding with the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Community Services and Health aware that up to 400 Australian families are suffering both socially and financially as a result of haemophiliac family members being treated with blood products containing the HIV infection? Is the Minister also aware that the British Government has made available to the British Haemophilia Society a 10 million pound trust fund to assist 1,200 families in a similar situation? Can the Minister tell the House how much of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) funding allocated in the Budget will be used to help the families of Australian haemophiliacs infected with HIV?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the number of haemophiliacs affected by AIDS in this country and the problems that that causes. Of course, those people have access to the full range of services that we are seeking to provide in responding to this disease in this country. There have been claims that the Government has not acted on calls for compensation by people infected with HIV through the supply of blood or blood products in this country. In fact, the issue has been the subject of continued consideration since this route of infection was first recognised and the blood supply protected, not just by this Government but by all the governments in this country. In February 1985 the Australian Health Services Council established a working party which recommended against a compensation scheme on the grounds that there were no precedents for disease compensation-people with AIDS were already entitled to normal welfare arrangements and such a scheme would not affect the legal liability for claims for negligence-and that it would be a complex scheme to administer. That was the consideration in 1985. These recommendations were noted by all the Australian health Ministers at their conference in May 1985 and have formed the basis to date of the Government's response.

ANSWER.PARA: Compensation was again examined by the National Advisory Committee on AIDS working group in 1986 and a proposal for a compensation payment was considered at the Commonwealth level by an interdepartmental committee on AIDS in July 1987 and was not supported. The issue has also been the subject of a number of discussions between the Haemophilia Foundation of Australia and the Minister and departmental representatives. The Haemophilia Foundation lodged a submission with the Commonwealth Government in March 1989 to set out its grounds for special government assistance. This has been examined in the context of the Government's national HIV AIDS strategy, which is set out in the forthcoming White Paper.

There is no other comparable scheme for medically acquired conditions in this country. Honourable members in this House should be aware that if we move in this direction we will be setting a precedent which affects no other medically acquired condition as yet in this country. We have sought legal advice on whether people infected through the blood supply retain their right to seek compensation for negligence through the legal system. People do retain their common law right to pursue claims for negligence, though we all recognise that the difficulty lies in being able to prove negligence before HIV was known to be transmissible through the blood supply and the blood supply was secured. The universal coverage of medical and hospital needs under Medicare and the existing framework of income maintenance benefits provide support in this country for all eligible people. The basic criterion for any government assistance is the need of the claimant rather than the cause of the illness.

I believe the Government's position has remained consistent over a number of years. Nevertheless, we will pay close and continuous attention to what is perhaps one of the most difficult issues in the whole AIDS area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of reports that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has been underfunded by $28m in last night's Budget and that as a result it will be forced to reduce broadcast hours and defer some expenditures, including an extension of the second ABC radio network and 2JJJ? Can the Minister advise the House whether this is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports of the kind mentioned by the honourable member for Dobell in which the Chairman and the General Manager of the ABC have been claiming that through alleged underfunding they will need to cut television transmission time, reduce television program purchases, reduce expenditure on the second regional radio network extension and reduce expenditure on the proposed extension of the JJJ youth network. The Government does not accept in any way that the ABC has been underfunded. The Government decided last year that the ABC should be appropriated $450m for the year ended 1988-89 and that that amount should be cash limited-that is, that it would not be supplemented for unforeseen cost increases. That advice was given to the ABC on a number of occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government also decided that ABC funding should be maintained in real terms for the next two years but be subject to the efficiency dividend in the same way as all Government departments and most Budget funded agencies are required to be. Because inflation for 1988-89 was above the Budget estimate, the ABC claimed that its funding for that year should be increased by $30m and that that enhanced figure should become the base for which the price index should be applied for this year to get maintenance in real terms. The Government rejected that claim because it was not in accord with its earlier decision to provide the ABC with a cash limited appropriation of $450m for 1988-89 as it advised the ABC on several occasions.

In the context of this year's Budget the Government reconfirmed its decision to maintain last year's appropriation in real terms. This year's Budget allocation of $473.6m is an increase of 5.2 per cent, which represents real term maintenance minus the efficiency dividend. There is no breach of commitment by the Government in any way on the decision that was made last year and conveyed to the ABC. We totally reject the ABC's claim that it has been underfunded by $28m. That is not the end of the story. The resources available to the ABC total more than what comes from the Budget appropriations. The ABC has substantial receipts from other sources including its orchestral activities, bookshops and other activities. Last year those receipts amounted to $54m. This year the ABC's estimate for those receipts is $65 1/2m. The ABC keeps all of these receipts. They are cash receipts. They are not in any way taken from it by the Government. Furthermore, the ABC has cash balances. At the beginning of the last financial year its cash balance was minus $2 1/2m. During the last year it managed to improve on that situation. It had a positive cash balance at the beginning of this year of $5 1/2m-a turnaround of $8m. The total resources available to the ABC in 1989-90, this year, are $544.6m-that is, 8.6 per cent above last year. That has to be compared with the Budget forecast for the non-farm gross domestic product deflator of 6 1/4 per cent, so it is a substantial real increase in resources to the ABC.

I should also mention that the resources review which the ABC has committed itself to undertake is supposed to reduce staff by 15 per cent over a few years. That staff reduction should be producing salary savings of $24m this financial year. The ABC's resources for 1988-89 should be seen as being sufficient at least to provide for the same level of activity this year as last year. On any objective analysis the ABC has been fairly, indeed generously, treated. We reject absolutely the charge that there has been some underfunding of the ABC. The ABC should stop whingeing and get on with the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is is a fact that it was necessary to add a massive $1.7 billion to the Forward Estimates for 1989-90 to derive the Budget outlays estimate to allow for parameter changes including the substantial underestimate of the impact of inflation? Does this confirm that those Forward Estimates were a totally unreliable guide to future trends in Commonwealth spending?
—You never gave us Forward Estimates when you were around.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague the Minister for Defence says, the Opposition never gave us any Forward Estimates when it was around. That is dead right. When we came to office there were no Forward Estimates to be seen. They were available only to the Government. We now publish Forward Estimates, for three years out, with the Budget. Not only that but the documentation in the Budget is also about twice as much as it was, in terms of information provided to the Parliament and the public, in 1983-84. That is why it is such a mockery and a slur on the bureaucracy of this country to be talking about audits--
—You made a mistake.
—Order! I remind the honourable member for O'Connor of standing order 55.

—It is a mockery when we have Forward Estimates published by the Finance Department now each year for three years out. What the honourable member for Wentworth is now saying by implication is that somehow those numbers are tricked up-that they are not an accurate reflection of the Commonwealth's programs or its outlays.This can be the only implication from these claims that the Opposition should need an audit if it were to come to office. It treated the Finance Department like dirt when it was in office. If something was a receipt it made it a negative outlay. It cheated on all the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development classifications. We have given the Finance Department real status. What you see in Forward Estimates is what you get. They actually mean something. It is the kind of public accountability that should always have been in place. Now the Opposition hides behind the fact that it is not prepared to declare its policies. The Leader of the National Party of Australia has the audacity to say that he will announce them in an election campaign. This is the kind of cynicism he would have learned from Jack McEwen, Anthony, Nixon and all the other Country Party thugs we saw in this Parliament for years. He will show us the colour of his policies in the election campaign. I think he is in for a rude shock, just the same as his colleagues in the Liberal Party would be if they were to fall for that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Forward Estimates do mean something. There is a reconciliation table in the Budget Papers which reconciles every adjustment of the outlays from the Forward Estimates, through the April statement, to the Budget now. It shows that in terms of the main changes decisions were taken since 1982 adding $322m to outlays but with a negative effect in the out years-$1,621m of new policies, less $1,399m of savings. The result is that we are seeing another negative outlays year. They are the kinds of accounts the Opposition should always have had. There was no reason why the Opposition could not have revealed them and made the public and the commentators better informed about the nature of the public debate. Because it is always cheating on policy, it cheated on the documents as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —A paper is tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members earlier today. Details of the paper will be recorded in Hansard and the Votes and Proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: The schedule read as follows-
National Agenda for Women implementation report.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Budget to address Australia's fundamental economic problems.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are going to address as a matter of public importance the failure of the Budget to address Australia's fundamental economic problems. This Budget tried to perform a very difficult task. It tried to continue with what has been a blatant, politically driven early election strategy and to dress that up as being responsible. When we cut through the veneer of responsibility that has been painted by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this year's Budget Papers, there is an overwhelming disappointment with the extent to which this Budget fails to address our fundamental economic problems. It fails to develop an effective anti-inflationary strategy; it fails to develop a strategy to stimulate national savings; it fails to have an effective strategy for reducing our total debt; it fails to develop an effective strategy for increasing our productivity and our exports; it threatens a recession; it offers little hope for all Australians on the interest rate front; and, finally, it has no answer-absolutely none-to the emerging wages break-out that is evident in this country at the present time.

SPEECH.PARA: In the brief time available to me today I want to pick up three or four features of the Budget and to focus on them as matters of specific comment. Firstly, I want to lift the veneer of responsibility. Secondly, I want to talk about the issue of recession ducked in an answer to a question to the Treasurer today. Thirdly, I want to talk about the rape of the corporate sector that is inherent in this Budget. Fourthly, I want to talk about the wages issue and the potential wages explosion and, if there is time, I want to have a look at this new concept for the Industries Assistance Commission.

If we focus on the Budget and the veneer of responsibility I would emphasise to all in this House they should not be influenced by the size of the surplus. In fact, there are two elements to this veneer: the size of the surplus and more honesty in the forecasts. On the size of the surplus, it is important to recognise where the $9.1 billion has come from. The average Australian has every right to ask why he or she should be enthusiastic about a surplus of this magnitude, especially when it stands erect as a monument to the Treasurer's outstanding tax rip-off, to bracket creep, to sales tax excesses, to a decision to tax workers' superannuation as well as, in true Keating style, to his innovative accounting in respect of this year's outcome.

Last night I showed the Treasurer a chart which summarises quite nicely his performance in government. It emphasises quite clearly that this surplus has come from a phenomenal rip-off in tax over the life of this Government. The only significant expenditure restraint has been on payments to the States. The effect of that has been that the States have been pushed into debt and have been raising government taxes and charges, all of which has impacted on all Australians. The restraint on the Treasurer's own expenditure has been absolutely minimal. In simple terms the Treasurer has set out to make himself look good and to doctor his budget performance at the expense of everyone else. It does not mean anything that he is running a surplus or retiring debt if everyone else is being forced to run up debts and being forced into debt.

If we look at the Treasurer's innovative accounting in this Budget, it is very clear what he has done. He has pushed a substantial amount of revenue from last year into this year. He has brought forward a substantial amount of tax revenue, in particular from the corporate sector, from next year into this year. If we look back at last year's Budget outcome, there was an underestimate for non-pay as you earn (PAYE) individual tax, which we notice in this year's Budget goes up by 20 per cent. That figure was shoved from last year into this year to the tune of around $1 1/2 billion. Then there were some Reserve Bank of Australia profits which were not collected last year which were brought into account this year. There is the payment from defence service homes of $1 billion. There was a choice to get it paid last year or this year. It was paid on 14 July this year. Of course, there is the $1.4 billion and the associated public sector debt interest savings of $400m that have been brought forward in a one-off gain. If we take those sorts of adjustments and, undoubtedly, a host of others from this Budget surplus, we find that this surplus is significantly less than last year's outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —He fiddled the books.

—The Treasurer definitely fiddled the books and he definitely set out to look responsible rather than to deliver the goods. The simple fact is that this Budget has eased fiscal policy. The Government has been about easing fiscal policy, irrespective of its rhetoric, for the best part of the last 18 months. The difference between last year's May statement and the 1988 Budget is that there was an increase in expenditure in that Budget. Once again, there is an increase in expenditure in this Budget. The Government is on an increasing expenditure tack.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I want to raise is the issue of a recession. As the Treasurer pointed out in his answer today, his growth forecast for the year is 2 3/4 per cent. He boasts that that is pretty good by Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development standards. But he neglects to point out that the growth is working off a very strong base, that there is a possibility that that base will be upgraded and that the growth is carrying on strongly into at least the first quarter of this financial year. The fact is that, if there is no more growth in this whole financial year, that growth figure still comes in at 1.8 per cent. If there is a growth in the September quarter of 0.9 per cent, the next three quarters of the financial year have to be zero growth quarters in order to get the outcome of 2.75 per cent for the year as a whole.

The truth behind this number is that the Treasury people have built in the realistic possibility of a recession in the second half of this year. Growth is still running quite strongly, on the Treasurer's own admission, in this half year. To the extent it exceeds those numbers that I drew attention to, the second half of the year will be negative to give the Treasurer his predicted outcome. If we look at the Budget in somewhat more detail and relate it to the employment and unemployment forecasts we find, although it is not explicitly stated, that unemployment is predicted to go up. The unemployment rate is presently around 6 per cent. The average unemployment rate for the year as a whole is to be 6 1/4 per cent. I think this implies a sizable increase in the unemployment levels through the year in order to get that predicted result. There is no doubt that there is, as Senator Walsh warned us some months ago, a very high risk of a recession under this strategy. Do not forget what that strategy is: it is to stay with high interest rates; it is to hope that those interest rates bite; it is to hope that they will slow down the economy and achieve a soft landing. It is basically to sit on interest rates and pray. There is no more substance to the strategy than that.

The third point I would like to draw attention to is the rape of the corporate sector. The Treasurer needs investment. He tells us constantly how he needs investment. But the corporate sector is definitely being raped in this Budget. Taxes of $1.4 billion have been brought forward as a result of a desire to get the corporate sector to pay its tax earlier and to get the large companies to pay in their PAYE tax twice a month. This guy has no idea what that means to a lot of companies. It is a substantial increase in tax. Where will the corporate sector get this money to pay that tax? It will have to spend about $330m a year on interest because most of the corporate sector will find those earlier tax payments out of borrowings. There is a double slug: the Treasurer increases the tax burden by bringing payments forward and he slams the corporate sector with a high interest rate as well.

The corporate sector is also expected to live with a 3 per cent occupational superannuation increase and with the prospect of a wages blow-out. Despite the fiction in this Budget of earnings growth of 6 1/2 or 7 per cent, that growth is already running at about 8 per cent and we are about to get wage increases flowing through. There is plenty of drift out there. There is every chance that the earnings numbers will be well above the Budget forecasts. These forecasts are fictional. They are the weak point. There is a wages break-out in this country. There is an earnings break-out relative to the 6 1/2 per cent deal that was done with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. There is collectively, therefore, a substantial rape of the corporate sector. The bottom line is that the Treasurer needs investment to sustain productive capacity. When he most needs it he slams the group that is supposed to achieve that investment.
The fourth point I want to talk about is wages policy. Last night I was influenced by the comment made by Simon Crean speaking on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television. He said:
I personally don't think it does enough to get inflation down and that's one of the pressing problems facing this country.

Simon Crean has taken a direct shot at the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-and why wouldn't he?-because he has been duped. Simon Crean did a deal on behalf of the rank and file in this country based on an earnings projection of 6 1/2 per cent. He will have a lot of trouble holding that deal together when prices are now running at 7 1/2 per cent. When he agreed to the 6 1/2 per cent, the Treasurer was telling him inflation would be 4 1/2 per cent in the year to June this year and between 3 per cent and 4 per cent in the year to June next year. Mr Crean was totally duped. He agreed to 6 1/2 per cent. The pressure is on and the Treasurer knows that he cannot deliver. He has already had to back off once in the course of the last 12 months. Does the Treasurer remember his concept of a wage-tax trade off? He could not deliver on that because we ended up getting a wage increase across the board on top of the tax cuts from 1 July. The Treasurer gave ground to his mate in view of his special relationship with the trade union movement and he is about to do it again. These earnings numbers will come in well above forecast.

The most disturbing thing is the failure of the Budget to address our fundamental economic problem: the lack of production and the lack of exports in this country. All we get in the so-called micro-economic reform agenda is a new Industries Assistance Commission. Basically, the Commission is to receive a new name and a couple of years' worth of studies. One would not think that the studies on the list were the most important ones to be getting under way if we are serious about micro-economic reform. The concept seems to be, `If in doubt send it to a committee and hope it goes away'. There is no micro-economic reform strategy. We know why: the Treasurer got rolled. He got rolled when the discussion was held by the Cabinet.

There are some fundamental impediments to production in this country, and until the Government brings in policies that will reduce or eliminate them we will never trade our way out of these difficulties. The Government should direct its attention at this time to six main impediments. The first is the tax system. The burden of tax is too high and it saps incentive. It discourages savings investment and it encourages consumption and debt. The Treasurer does not understand it. He thinks he has a national savings policy when all he is doing is taxing the life out of superannuation. The benefits we are supposed to get from the superannuation scheme will not be received until the early to middle 1990s. For all that time the Government will be collecting nearly $1 billion a year in tax from superannuation. The Treasurer does not even understand the issue of superannuation.

The second area that needs attention is the role of government. The Government spends too much, regulates too much, and spends too much of its time trying to run businesses it should not be running-Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, the Commonwealth Bank, and so on. We need policies that bring about substantial cuts in expenditure, that reduce regulation, that privatise these government businesses.

Thirdly, there is labour market reform, the need to tie wages to productivity, to decentralise the process, to restore some incentive at the workplace level in terms of wage negotiation. Until the Government does that it will persist with a floor of 6 to 7 per cent under our inflation rate. In the Treasurer's own Budget he says that the inflation rate this year will be 7 1/2 per cent in Australia and 4 3/4 per cent in the rest of the world. He is quite happy to go on year after year with our inflation rate nearly double that of our trading partners, and wage increases nearly double those of our trading partners when we look at them relative to productivity.

Fourthly, there is a desperate need to get interest rates down and to stabilise the currency. The currency has been going up and down like a yoyo in recent years. Why would Senator Button's investment in the manufacturing sector take place when the dollar goes down 40 per cent and comes back 26 per cent in the space of a few years?

Fifthly, there are many infrastructure inefficiencies. There is too much competition or too much regulation of work and management practices in things like coastal shipping, the waterfront, road, rail and air transport, communications, a lack of airport facilities and runways, and so on. We have had no answers in those areas.

Finally, there is the need for a revamped education and skills system. Our skills are in short supply. We have a rigid wages system that erodes incentive. We have an education system that does not have too much to do with excellence any more. The fundamental problem in this country, as I said, is the deficiency of production and the deficiency of exports. This Budget does nothing about those. Indeed, to the extent that it does anything in relation to the corporate sector, the vehicle for change in that regard, it rapes it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will run through the litany of farrago and fiction given by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson).
—Why don't you answer the points?
—Order!
—The shadow Treasurer was heard in silence; I would also like to be heard in silence.
—Don't carry on like that.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—The shadow Treasurer started by saying that the size of the surplus, $9.1 billion, came from fiddled numbers. That was the first claim. Again, that was another cheap shot at the Government and the bureaucracy. On page 5.4 of the Budget statements it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The 1989-90 surplus of $9,122m or 2.5% of GDP principally reflects the cumulative effects of decisions to restrain the rate of growth in outlays.
So the surplus does not come about because of tax, but because of restraint in the growth of outlays. That is made quite clear. On page 4.42 of the same document, the Treasury states:
. . . taxpayers as a whole will be paying less tax in 1989-90 than would have been the case if the tax rates scale in place in 1983-84 had been fully indexed for inflation.
What does the shadow Treasurer say about that?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quoting yourself.
—How much of it did you write?

—Honourable members opposite seem to think that I wrote this document. The Treasury wrote it. That is another cheap shot at the Treasury. Honourable members opposite attack from their coward's castle. They have come back to attacking the bureaucrats who cannot defend themselves. That is the point about the tax scales.

SPEECH.PARA: We can consider also the sheer outcome of the revenue estimates for the year. The revenue from gross pay as you earn (PAYE) tax collections is estimated to increase by 5.4 per cent-less than the inflation rate-and net PAYE revenue is to increase by 4.6 per cent-about 2 per cent less than the inflation rate. The increase in the total individual rate is 8 per cent, slightly above the inflation rate, but this is supposed to be a big grab for money when in the Budget there is a $5.5 billion tax cut. The shadow Treasurer cannot even understand that there is a $5.5 billion tax cut from 1 July this year accounted for in this year's Budget, the largest tax cut in our history. Is it any wonder net PAYE revenue is to increase by 4.6 per cent? The shadow Treasurer said also that the revenue from other individuals was estimated to increase by 20 per cent. In that category is the property and business income of unincorporated individuals from last year's very high level of activity. Overall the total increase for individuals is 8 per cent; the overall total income tax increase is 10 per cent, with the inflation rate at 6 1/4 per cent and the consumer price index running at about 7 per cent. So much for the business about fiddled numbers!

The shadow Treasurer went on to talk about Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) profits being moved from one year to the next. Wrong! In this year's Budget $440m was received from RBA profit. Last year it was $500m. It is actually lower this year. The RBA profit in the Budget is lower this year than last year. The shadow Treasurer was wrong again. He tried to disparage the decision with respect to defence service homes. The decision was made a couple of years ago and the payment arrangements were made then. It is just where the thing falls. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) should not wave pathetic bits of paper at me. He is a pathetic character.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your Budget.
—Order! The honourable member for Farrer will cease interjecting.

—I have dealt with the first 10 minutes of the shadow Treasurer's speech: a fraudulent claim about RBA profits, and a fraudulent claim about tax and about the surplus being derived from tax when, as the Treasury says, it is derived from cuts in government spending. Of course, that is true. The revenue share in gross domestic product (GDP) this year is 26.2 per cent, the same as in 1982-83 and 1981-82. What else do honourable members opposite need? What else can we say to defeat those points?

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Treasurer then talked about a recession. I talked about that in Question Time. He said economic growth was at 2 3/4 per cent and that over the course of the year it would be slower. If it has averaged 2 3/4 per cent it will be slower. But there will not be a recession because we have net exports shifting and exports growing on average by 7 per cent. If the honourable member wants to talk about averages for growth, he has to talk about averages for exports. If exports are averaging 7 per cent, through the year they are higher than 7 per cent. That is what will keep production going and prevent a recession, a crash-landing like the one he gave us all back in 1982-83 and 1983-84.

We then heard a pathetic, hollow claim about the rape of the corporate sector. That claim came from this crowd who had corporate profits, the gross operating surplus, at the lowest level in the postwar years. In 1982-83 the share of private non-farm corporate sector gross operating surplus was 26 per cent. That figure can be found in table 5 on page 2.26 of the Budget Statements document. It has risen to 36.7 per cent, a figure higher than the average of 31.1 per cent achieved in the mid-1960s to early 1970s. So the shadow Treasurer talked about the rape of the corporate sector when it is enjoying unprecedented profitability. The honourable member says he is an economics professor. I have said this to him before: `Where did you get your ticket?'. If the honourable member cannot understand a couple of basic facts like that, it must have come from a lucky dip. Does he not understand that the corporate share is now higher than it has ever been? He is talking about the rape of the corporate sector! Why does he think people are out there supporting us in their thousands in corporate Australia? That is because they know what we have done for them.

In this Budget we are giving $5.5 billion in tax cuts, which comes off the corporate sector's wage bill. If that tax cut had not been there, there would have been a 12 to 15 per cent nominal wage increase. The private sector has virtually saved that $5 billion-plus tax cut. The company tax rate has been cut from 49c to 39c, which is worth $2 billion; and there is also $1 billion a year for dividend imputation. In the last year the corporate sector has picked up another $8 billion from us, and we are going to take $330m a year from that. And the honourable member calls that rape of the corporate sector!

TALK.START.PARA: —You're taking much more than that.
—Yes, we have got a bring forward of $1.1 billion.
—Your money?

—Yes, that is our money. Their cost is $330m. The cost to the corporate sector is tax money-tax money, mate! The ongoing cost of $330m a year is how much it will cost the corporate sector in real terms. That has to be set against a $8 billion package in the last year, and the highest profits coming off a decline in unit labour costs, the largest we have seen in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. And members of the Opposition talk about the rape of the corporate sector! If they want to be incredible and foolish, they are doing a pretty good job of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Wages policy is where I really started to get giggly. The honourable member said, `What would they do with their wages policy if there were a breakout in the wage system?'. The question is: What would the Opposition do? We have been in office for 6 1/2 years. We have changed the factor shares to get investment and employment going. What would the shadow Treasurer do? What would he do with the pilots wanting a 29 per cent increase in wages? His mate the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) is sitting next to him. I know what he says: `Go for your life. That's deregulation'. Members of the Opposition would wreck the airline companies, move into all the metals awards, the airline industry, the transport industry. We would have a 20 per cent national wage increase. Honourable members opposite say, `Oh yes?'. That is the deregulated nirvana, Liberal style. It is just like the situation in Margaret Thatcher's Britain. Honourable members opposite all held that up as a model. The British have the same craft structure as Australia but in Opposition members' deregulated nirvana wages this year are growing at 10 per cent, with inflation going at 10 per cent. In other words, that structure does not work. People out there in the corporate sector know that it would not work. They know about productivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Productivity?

—Here he is, the pal over here, talking about productivity. He will tie wages to a one per cent growth in productivity when the market wants to pay 15 per cent. Yet he disparages our outcome of 7 per cent. He wants to pay them one per cent but the market will pay them 15 per cent. When will honourable members opposite understand that being a member of the Liberal Party of Australia will not be enough to get them into office? They will have to think of some policies and realise that out there the corporate sector knows that we have rebuilt the structures, with profits and changes in the economy. Those people will not have the Opposition and that kind of sham policy. They know that all the riffraff on the conservative side of business are in the Liberal Party, and they will not have the Opposition managing their affairs. This is the least prepared Opposition ever for government. The honourable member for Kooyong, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), is the least prepared Leader of the Opposition ever to contest the Prime Ministership of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member then talks about failure to lift production and exports. I said in Question Time that exports have been running at an average rate of 7 per cent in the last five years, the fastest rate in the last 25 years. In relation to production, we have had on average twice the rate of GDP growth in the last five years that was the case during the term of the previous Government. Honourable members should have a look at the charts in terms of the components of GDP. On page 2.39 the chart shows GDP for the five years to 1988-89 at 4 per cent, under Labor, and for the five years to 1983-84 at 2.3 per cent. In the five years to 1978-79 it was 2.5 per cent. Honourable members opposite talk about production!

Then the honourable member for Wentworth says there has been no micro-economic reform. He speaks about the tax system. Fancy him having the hide to say that! He advised the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), for five years. Fancy having the hide to talk about the tax system when the previous Government had a 60 per cent top marginal rate, a bottom rate of 30 per cent, double tax on dividends and a 78c in the dollar tax on company distributions. We have cut that to 39c for companies with a 47 per cent imputation system by 1 January; we will have a top rate of 47c by January, not 60c, and a bottom rate of 24c, not 30c-and the honourable member talks about tax reform and the tax system! With the kind of tax system the Opposition had, the only expanding industry the Opposition had when it was in government was the tax avoidance industry. That was their one great creation in the years when they were in office. There is one thing about the liberals: when one gets a Liberal Party ticket, somehow one loses one's shame. When one signs on there is a kind of psychological drain and one loses one's shame. That is the only way these characters could ever get up and talk about wages systems, tax systems, micro-reform or exports. The gall of them is faint-making.

Then we hear talk about the stability of the currency. There is the old regulator out: the stability of the currency. The honourable member is on to the Governor of the Reserve Bank. He was used to telling them what they should do with interest rates and the currency. Stability of the currency? The honourable member would give us stability! He would be in there tricking up the foreign exchange market until they clobbered him to death. But he thinks that all those 24- and 25-year-olds sitting on the Reuters screens in New York and Tokyo will say, `Oh, the people in the pinstripe suits are back, so we'll leave them alone; we'll treat them kindly'. They would wash the Opposition away so brutally it would not know which way it went.
By the way, what did the Governor of the Reserve Bank say about the Opposition? He said:

Throughout more than six years in office, this Government has been very correct in its dealings with the Bank. . . . There has been no interference in matters that are the responsibility of the Bank. Only an ``insider'' can know that that has not always been so!

The Governor said that he regarded the claims made against the bank as a slur against it. He was talking about the honourable member opposite. He has damned the honourable member in a polite but vicious way. He knows all about the honourable member and the stability of the currency.

We have never heard from the honourable member opposite about inflation adjustment. Four press releases today have gone to nothing after his mate here, good old empty-head, got his inflation adjustment proposition going.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer will refer to honourable members by their titles.

—What will be the result of the inflation proposition? The honourable member picked it up on a Sunday afternoon. Can people imagine a change to the structure of this country which will deny nominal interest deductions and allow only real interest deductions so that today, instead of getting a deduction for 20 per cent, a person would get 13 per cent? Can people imagine the gross irresponsibility of picking up on a Sunday afternoon a proposal like that? It would simply destroy corporate Australia, stop borrowings, and lead to a failure to be able to fund the current account and to historic distortions and trafficking in existing loans, which would amount to enormous shifts of wealth. We would watch Australian companies shift offshore where they could borrow and get full interest deductions. Can people imagine anyone being so grossly irresponsible as the Leader of the Opposition?

SPEECH.PARA: What have we heard from the shadow Treasurer? Nothing! He has hidden from every radio interview, every question, for about 15 days. Well he might have done! When we have done with him on this question, he will be sorry he ever heard the term `inflation adjustment'. Last night we put a real savings proposal together, as we have been doing for six years.
It is a sham proposition proposed by an incompetent person. I have no trouble whatsoever in dismissing it and rejecting it with scorn and contempt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a tragic response. It is tragic for the nation and tragic for the economy. Again the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), has made a number of errors in his response this afternoon. Let me just look at one quote: `It is our money'. It is the great socialist ethic that somehow the taxpayers' money belongs to one Paul Keating, to the Treasurer. It is not his money. It may be taxpayers' money, but it is the people's money for which the Treasurer is a very temporary custodian. He will be even more temporary by the time the next elections come around. The arrogance of the Treasurer in saying here this afternoon that it is all his money, that it is all his to control in the interests of a narrow socialist agenda, should be rejected every time it raises its head.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the reference by the Treasurer to the piece of paper I waved at him and which he called `this pathetic bit of paper'. Let me tell the House what this pathetic bit of paper is. This pathetic bit of paper happens to come from Budget Paper No. 1, page 3.342, relating to the summary of major asset sales. It retails exactly what happened with the defence service homes scheme disposal. The figures are there for everyone to see. Those figures show that last year $400m was brought into the accounts and this year there is $1,015m from the defence service home loan transfer to Westpac Banking Corporation, a sale that was originally announced in May 1985-four years ago-and is only now being finalised. The Treasurer has been inaccurate, he has been arrogant, and we have come to expect that from him.

The Treasurer accuses us of attacking bureaucrats. We do better than attack bureaucrats. We bring very senior Treasury bureaucrats to the Senate and, if we are not satisfied with that, we bring them from the Senate to the House of Representatives. I am referring to a former Secretary to the Treasury. We are not about the business of attacking the bureaucrats; we are about the business of the good governance of this country. It is a great pity that this Government does not get on with the good governance of this country.

Of course, the Treasurer had a bad afternoon. He was very worried about that person who covets his job, Simon Crean of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), because Simon spoke the truth in relation to this Budget. He said the Budget lacks a trade strategy. Those were accurate words, picked up by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt). Yes, the Budget absolutely lacks a proper trade strategy for this country. Simon was right, for once. `Simon says' was an accurate expression, for once. Simon obviously covets the jobs of both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). They should look out. But reality is that by the time Simon Crean gets here he will be a long-serving shadow Treasurer and nothing much more.

We also heard a reference by the Treasurer to the Forward Estimates. I would like to draw the attention of the House to some of those Forward Estimates. I particularly refer country members to the Forward Estimates for road expenditure. What do they show? They show, for example, for 1990-91 an amount of $1430.8m; for 1991-92, $1430.8m; and for 1992-93, $1430.8m. For three years this Government is proposing, in its Forward Estimates, no increase in road funding. That is this Government's attitude to country Australia and it will pay a price for that.

Finally, the Treasurer said that what we see is what we get. I will tell this House what the nation sees. The nation sees a tired, out of touch government, hiding up here in Canberra, imposing a one-dimensional policy of high interest rates which is inflicting great agony across Australia, not only on the home buyer-and much of the media tends to focus on the home buyer-but also on small business operators and big business operators. The reality of the Government's interest rates is not 17 per cent or 18 per cent but 21 per cent and higher. The reality of its interest rates in the category of casual overdraft rate is 24.75 per cent at the moment. That is the agony flowing from the Federal Government's policy under this Treasurer. The Opposition totally rejects the approach of the Treasurer. I support strongly the submissions made by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson).

It is time to look at the facts, not the fiction, in relation to the Budget. Fact No. 1 is that under this Budget Australian taxpayers will have to pay an awful lot more tax this financial year compared with last financial year. Let me tell the House how much more. Individual income tax payments will rise by 8 per cent to $51.3 billion. Under the terms of this Budget total income tax will rise by $6 billion-that is, 10.1 per cent-to $65.5 billion. Under this huge taxing Government, this record taxing Treasurer, those are the facts on taxation in terms of the Budget.

Fact No. 2, and this will interest the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), relates to petroleum products. What is the Government doing in that area? The Budget figure is official and shows an increase of 9.3 per cent, from $4.82 billion to $5.6 billion. As the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) points out so accurately, very little of that has come back to roads; that allocation will be increased by a mere $116m. Again, that is not good enough in terms of rectifying the massive transport infrastructure problems imposed by this Federal Budget and maintained by Federal Labor Government policies.

Let us look at fact No. 3. I refer to social security and veterans' affairs. I realise that there are some good points in the Budget in those areas; I am prepared to concede that in the interests of accuracy. However, the more realistic approach is reflected in the comments made by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who pointed out that, in the Government's focus on social security and veterans' affairs, it took seven years for the Government to meet its commitment to raise the basic pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, and that will not be done until April of next year, the 75th anniversary of Gallipoli. Secondly, Labor continues to take nearly $1,000m a year in superannuation tax but will spend only $700m on retirement income improvements over six years. Thirdly, spreading retirement income reforms over six years is an act of gross arrogance which will infuriate retirees, who expect their legitimate problems to be overcome in the short term. These are all accurate points in respect of social security and veterans' affairs. Let me mention another area in passing, that of ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese. At long last those people get a small breakthrough, and I give credit to the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) and others for that. However, it is only a small breakthrough and does not apply to prisoners of war of Korea, Germany and elsewhere, so we now have different categories of ex-prisoners of war.

I move to fact No. 5 in respect of the Budget. This reflects the incredible priorities of this Government. There are millions of dollars of funding for acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). I do not dispute the requirement for funding for AIDS, but while there is an increase of $7m in funding for AIDS, what is the situation in respect of the hideous and horrific Ross River contagion which exists in Australia, especially outside the capital cities? Two years ago there was an allocation of $600,000, one year ago $400,000, last year there were zero dollars, and in this Budget zero again.

Let us look at some other priorities. On the one hand the Government can find $110m as an additional foreign aid package to black African front line states. On the other hand, it has effectively reduced, or failed to maintain fully, I should say, in the presence of the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), adequate road funding, including the rural local road funding structure. This Government has plundered the standard of living of thousands of Australians. It is now plundering the standard of living of future generations of Australians with its totally inadequate and flawed Budget. This epitomises a government that is tired, out of touch and soon to lose office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing provides a better illustration of the contrast between the Government and the Opposition than the fact that the previous Government left this Government with a $9 billion deficit, which we have converted to a $9 billion surplus. The $9 billion deficit that this Government inherited from the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), has been converted to a $9 billion surplus. What a contrast.

SPEECH.PARA: In the days when the Liberal Party was in government, taxpaying became optional for the rich and powerful in Australia. That Government did not collect the revenue that ought to have been collected and taxpaying became optional. I heard the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) talk about the growth in revenue. The reason why there has been a growth in revenue under this Government is that people for whom it was optional under the Liberal Government are now paying tax. That is what has changed. I want to talk about specific percentages. In effect, individual taxpayers are not paying more tax; we have simply broadened the tax base and made tax collections more effective.

In contrast with the Opposition, we will use this surplus to pay off debt that was accumulated when the Liberal and National parties were in government. Australians know that this Government is managing their money in a way that was never possible under the Liberal and National parties. Over recent weeks we have had the spectacle of the English cricket team. This Opposition is like that team: it is without a strong leader; its batting line-up lacks strength and it certainly has no attack. Pensioners and juniors in the English cricket team have faced the might of the Australian side. That is what we have opposite-pensioners and juniors ill-equipped to face up to this Government. People ought to understand that contrast.

The first big test for the Opposition comes tomorrow night. It will be interesting to see what it has. Let us see whether it has anything substantial. I suggest to my colleagues on this side and to the Australian people that the Opposition, like the English cricket team, will lose the first big test. Honourable members opposite do not have it. They have not been training, they do not have the skills and they certainly do not have the leadership. That is what it will come down to.

We already know that the Opposition has a shortage of policies. Despite the fact that we have been in government for 6 1/2 years, we are still awaiting policies and they are not being put down. It is interesting to observe that today the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong, praised this Government's Budget performance. Why? Because he was prepared to grapple with policies. Given John Elliott's timetable, he was due to bring some policies before us in September. The test is now before the Opposition. Will it produce any policies tomorrow night? That is the big test. So far, in 6 1/2 years, those opposite have not come good. At the moment their record is just like that of the English cricket team: it is shallow; it cannot do anything. It cannot even bat through a day. That is the contrast in this place.

Let us contrast what we have to offer with what the Opposition has to offer. I have already said that the surplus will be used to pay off overseas debt and domestic debt accumulated when the Liberal and National parties were in government. I say to the Australian people that that is very important. The money being used by this Government is certainly being used to pay off debt accumulated when the Opposition was in power.

I also want to say something about the general statistics that this Government is putting before the Australian people. In the next financial year we face moderate economic growth and moderate employment growth. What really worries the Australian people and me is that when the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth, talks about economic growth he is really talking about doing what the Opposition did in 1981-82 when it plunged the economy into recession. People know that under that strategy people lose their jobs. It is all very well for the Opposition to come in here and talk about these statistical outcomes, but what about personal outcomes? The Opposition's strategy, as has always been the case when it wants to shift the economy towards its statistical outcomes, is to punish ordinary workers. That is what the honourable member for Wentworth and other members opposite are talking about. He wants to restrain growth through the very simple strategy of moving towards a recession. That means a loss of jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think your high interest rates are doing?
—We have the memory of when those opposite--
—What about the workers?
—Order!
—We saw what happened in its last years in govern- ment--
—You ought to come out and say what happens to the workers in the western suburbs of Sydney.
—I warn the honourable member for Dundas.

—When those opposite were in government there was an enormous decline in jobs, which was manufactured by the Fraser-Howard coalition. There was a massive loss of jobs in Australia. The collection opposite has put up this proposition, `We can reduce growth in this economy and will go towards a recession'. They keep getting up in this place and challenging the Treasurer (Mr Keating) by saying, `Why have you got these growth projections of 2 3/4 per cent?'. The simple reason is that the private sector is growing and the Australian economy is being geared up for that growth. These statistics also demonstrate the enormous export growth that is flowing through in this economy. That was demonstrated even by today's statistics. This economy is getting itself into gear.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to note that, when one looks at the underpinning characteristic of investment in this economy, one can contrast the period in which we have been in government-there has been an enormous growth in investment, in fact a 10 per cent annual growth in investment-with the period in which the Opposition was in government when there was growth of 1.6 per cent. That suggests that the private sector is prepared to put its money on this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Confidence.

—Exactly. The private sector backs this Government and so do the ordinary workers, because ordinary workers have seen an enormous growth in the number of jobs-1.5 million since we have been in office. So ordinary workers have seen an enormous growth in the number of jobs and the private sector has seen growth in its profitability-we can take those figures up with the Opposition-and it has made a commitment by saying, `We will invest in this economy'. That contrasts with what happened when those opposite were in government. They have still not come up with any substantial policies.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it interesting that those opposite keep saying, `What will you do about wages?'. They want to do away with wages policy. They then jump up in Question Time and say, `What about the pilots? What about the air traffic controllers? What about teachers?'. One cannot do anything if one does not have a wages policy. Where is the Opposition's wages policy? It is opting out, as was the case with the tax system. People who were rich and powerful could opt out of the tax system under the Liberals and Nationals. It is the same formula: a rich and powerful union will be able to opt out of the wages system under the Liberals and Nationals. The pilots will be able to get a 29 per cent wage increase, as will everyone else. Where is the equity in that? That is a destructive wages policy in terms of the ordinary worker, who is left behind in that process. The ordinary worker has to pay the increased prices that result from that wages policy.

We have said that there is a way through it. One of the ways through it-we have already put this strategy in place-is a wage-tax trade-off. It makes sense. That is the first element. The second element is that people will get a reward in terms of wage increases if the workplace is restructured and modernised. The third element of that strategy is that we are suggesting to Australian workers-it is contained in this Budget-that if they can negotiate a proper superannuation increase with their employer, we will support that by providing tax concessions. So the three elements come together: a wage-tax trade-off, rewards for restructuring and the superannuation process. People on this side of the House and in the Australian community generally understand that if we have a proper superannuation policy we will not have the disaster that would have been ahead of us had the Opposition stayed in power.

It did not address this fundamental question: What will we do in the year 2025 when 25 per cent of the Australian population is of pensionable age? We are saying that the answer can be addressed, and it has been addressed in this Budget. First, we have enhanced the area of superannuation coverage. The Budget forecasts an enormous increase. There will be a $60 billion growth in superannuation. That is an enormous change in strategy. Secondly, we also recognise that those in receipt of pensions deserve to be free of continual tax problems. They should also have some incentive to earn extra income. That is the other part of our retirement policy. This Budget states, `We recognise that. We've already put a number of measures in place and we're putting further measures in place'. Come 1995, all people who are in receipt of pensions will not be in the tax system. That was never addressed by those opposite. We get only quick fixes and gimmicks from those opposite. Not only do we have a wages policy; we also have a retirement incomes policy. We have done that on the basis of research; not quick polling, not working out which electorate one is in today, not reacting to the local pressure group, but by asking what Australians really need.

The Australian people, when comparing this Government with the Opposition, should think of the English cricket team: the Opposition is without leadership; it is without any strength in its batting line-up and it certainly gets bowled over very easily because it has no policies. It is easy to get up and support this Government's policies and performance because the record is there, just like that of the Australian cricket team, and it is a very good record.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received advice from the National Party of Australia Whip that he has nominated Mr Anderson to be a member of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in place of Mr Adermann.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 11-15 (1989) and Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Proposals No. 1 (1989).

The tariff proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987, and the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act 1980. Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 11 to 14 (1989) and Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Proposals No. 1 (1989) formally place before Parliament, as required by law, tariff alterations made by notices published in the Gazette during the recent recess. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 15 (1989) is new and introduces amendments for certain textiles, clothing and footwear goods. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 11 (1989), operative on and from 1 March 1989, introduces unrestricted duty free access for footwear and certain fabrics of New Zealand origin. These changes accord with Australia's obligations under the closer economic relations trade agreement.
Customs Tariff Proposals No. 12 (1989), operative on and from 1 July 1989, contains the following:
Alterations to schedule one to take account of changes in the status and official title of a number of countries or places which qualify for preferential treatment;
changes to provide duty free and quota free access for apparel of New Zealand origin. This achieves free trade access a year earlier than originally proposed; and

alterations to give effect to the Government's recently announced decision on the Industries Assistance Commission's report on the mining, construction and agricultural equipment industries. These changes provide increased stability and greatly reduce cost for the industries concerned and resolve a number of tariff anomalies which emerged during the Commission's inquiry.

Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 13 to 15 contain changes to the administration of the textiles, clothing and footwear plan. This action follows the Government's acceptance of the recommendation by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 13 and 15 operate on and from 1 March 1989. Quota restrictions on brassiere back replacements have been abolished and a 25 per cent duty rate imposed. Metal parts of footwear and anti-radiation suits, anti-contamination suits and similar protective garments have also been removed from quota and a 15 per cent rate of duty implemented. Additional notes have been inserted in sections seven and 11 to define these protective garments.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 14, operative on and from 1 August 1989, introduces a free rate of duty for certain fabric woven from PVC coated polyester, and woven cut corduroy. It also implements quota free and duty free access for certain ski boots and cross-country ski footwear. Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Proposals No. 1 (1989), which operates on and from 1 July 1989, increases the export duty on concentrate produced from uranium ore obtained from the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory. The duty is increased from $1.15 to $1.30 per kilogram and was foreshadowed in the 1988-89 Budget Papers. Summaries of alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.

Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for certain technical amendments which will ensure that the Commonwealth borrowing levy continues to apply to all Commonwealth authorities and their subsidiaries, as was intended by the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987. The levy is imposed on the borrowings of all Commonwealth semi-government authorities and government-owned companies, other than those engaged in the business of financial intermediation, such as the Commonwealth Bank and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The levy, currently set at a rate of 0.125 per cent per annum, is designed to take account of the benefit these enterprises receive in terms of access to financial markets by virtue of their Commonwealth ownership. By ensuring that the effective cost of borrowings to these enterprises is more directly comparable with that faced by private sector borrowers, the enterprises are encouraged to take full account of the cost to the community of their investment decisions.

The amendments provided for in the Bill will expand the list of authorities subject to the levy to include the Civil Aviation Authority and Aerospace Technologies of Australia, two recently created Commonwealth authorities. The Bill also provides for the Australian Capital Territory Electricity and Water Authority to be excluded from paying the levy from 11 May 1989, the day Australian Capital Territory self-government was proclaimed. This will ensure that, under the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987, Australian Capital Territory authorities will be treated on the same basis as State and Northern Territory semi-government authorities. The Bill also provides for some minor definitional changes which will allow the levy to be applied to any new authorities through their enabling legislation, and to the subsidiaries of Commonwealth authorities. This will minimise the need for further legislative changes of this nature. These amendments will increase revenue raised from the levy in the 1989-90 financial year by an estimated $220,000 to $8,720,000. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill 1989 provides that, from the proclamation of Australian Capital Territory self-government on 11 May 1989, borrowings by the Australian Capital Territory Electricity and Water Authority (ACTEW) cease to be subject to the Commonwealth borrowing levy. The purpose of this Bill is to provide that the ACTEW should also cease to be liable for payments of the former Commonwealth guarantee charge. Under the current legislation, the ACTEW is liable for the charge in respect of outstanding amounts of borrowings undertaken in 1986-87. This Bill will reduce the revenue raised from the charge in 1989-90 by an estimated $54,000 to $2,446,000. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
