DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED FITOUT WORKS AT BOX HILL AND MOONEE PONDS, VICTORIA, ADELAIDE AND PERTH

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Proposed fitout works at Box Hill and Moonee Ponds, Victoria, Adelaide and Perth.

This is a proposal for fitout works in six pre-commitment lease office buildings in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia for the Australian Taxation Office. The Commonwealth will be entering into agreements to lease base buildings designed to accommodate the Australian Taxation Office at Box Hill and Moonee Ponds in Melbourne and at two locations each in Adelaide and in Perth. Since 1975 the Australian Taxation Office has been decentralising its larger offices from central business districts of major cities to suburban or country sites in an effort to bring staff closer to their work and to provide a better service to taxpayers. Where relocations outside the central business districts are possible there is the added benefit of reductions in high rentals.

The first office to be established under the decentralisation program was Parramatta, followed by Newcastle, Chatswood, Albury-Wodonga in New South Wales, and Dandenong in Victoria. The location of offices at Box Hill and Moonee Ponds followed a staff survey which indicated that many employees desired to work in those suburbs. In South Australia staff preferred to work in the central business district. At this centre and in Perth the existing offices will be split into two smaller offices. The functional requirements of the Australian Taxation Office are similar at each location and in each building. Each building will provide some 20,000 square metres of office space, ground floor shopfront space, and a controlled entry point for staff. The total cost of the fit-out works at the six locations is estimated at $46.1m at July 1989 prices. I table all drawings of the proposed works and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has no objection to the referral of these proposals to the Public Works Committee and, in general, accepts that this is fit-out work associated with works or leases to which the Commonwealth has already made a commitment. In general, in taking the overall project, the Opposition also agrees with the proposal whereby this and other government departments are removed from the central business district where that is practical. I hold a personal view that if decentralisation, even of our metropolitan areas, is to succeed it will be as a result of the initiative of government in moving certain of its service industries, particularly those with which the public and the professions have dealings, away from the central business district, consequently encouraging other people-in this case tax agents and people of that nature-to shift their office requirements closer to these sorts of government service centres. In that process some of the pressure will be taken off our great cities which I think is necessary if we are to avoid pollution and the concentration of all those gases that concern us in the environment today. We will not stop producing them, but we certainly will not concentrate them to the extent we do today, which I think has caused many problems for our cities. I hold the view that Canberra may have some faults, but past efforts to provide office buildings and government exercises in association with shopping centres have made a major contribution to the type of city it is. We think that is a good idea and that the Government is going the right way.

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one down side that I have been able to identify so far and that was identified recently in the Chatswood branch. Apparently, the Commissioner of Taxation was not able to keep a close enough eye on the staff, and they started to think they were Matt Dillon or somebody else and wanted to take journalists on their raids. I do not think any of us approved particularly of that exercise, but it is apparently indicative of the style of the Taxation Office today.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the building of tax offices rather than the internal organisation of the Tax Office, so the honourable member for O'Connor might stick to the matter before the House.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have been mentioning the advantages of a decentralised approach to servicing Australians in terms of the massive amounts of their income that they must deliver to the Tax Office because of the decisions of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). In that process I am raising the question that by shifting these buildings away from central control--
—I think we can talk about the buildings rather than what will happen in the buildings. The honourable member might stick to that matter.

—I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is significant that once a building is erected, the staff will be located there. Clearly, the Commissioner of Taxation lost control of one group, although I am told he has been to see them.
—I am saying to you that you will direct your remarks to the matter before the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do not want to take up any more of the House's time. The Opposition does not oppose this proposal. I think that the remarks I have made are worth noting. No doubt we will hear the response of the Public Works Committee in due course before this matter is concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Transitional-Depositors' Unclaimed Fund
``43. (1) In spite of the repeal of section 53 of the Principal Act effected by this Part, that section continues in force, after the commencement of this section, in relation to:
(a)money standing to the credit of the Depositors' Unclaimed Fund immediately before the commencement of this section; and
(b)money that became the absolute property of the Savings Bank before the commencement of this section; as if that repeal had not been effected.

``(2) A reference in section 69 of the Banking Act 1959 to unclaimed moneys does not include a reference to money standing to the credit of the Depositors' Unclaimed Fund immediately before the commencement of this section.''.

The Government has moved this amendment to ensure that in future the Commonwealth Savings Bank will be treated on the same basis as other banks in relation to unclaimed moneys. Consistent with the removal of the distinction between savings banks and trading banks, the intention in drafting the Bill was that all former savings banks, including the Commonwealth Savings Bank, should become subject to section 69 of the Banking Act 1959. This section requires that trading banks pay annually to the Commonwealth those moneys which have been unclaimed for seven years. It is not intended, however, that former savings banks should be required to pay to the Commonwealth the backlog of those moneys which have been unclaimed for eight years or more.

As it now stands, clause 43 (1) of the Bill requires that the Commonwealth Savings Bank pay to the Commonwealth all unclaimed moneys in amounts of $100 or more which it would hold at the time the amended legislation came into force. It is proposed that the present clause 43 be deleted so that the treatment of the Commonwealth Savings Bank will be brought into line with that of the other form of savings banks under section 69 of the Act as amended by clause 20. Proposed new clause 43 will relate only to the manner in which the Commonwealth Savings Bank holds moneys which are unclaimed for eight years or more. This amendment will not alter the financial implications of the Bill which I outlined in my second reading speech, since these were estimated on the assumption that all former savings banks would be treated equally.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unclear what purpose would be served by the proposed changes to section 81 of the Reserve Bank Act, as intended by the amendment moved by the Opposition. On the one hand the amendment appears to require that the Reserve Bank of Australia report to the Treasurer on any investigation of prudential matters undertaken pursuant to proposed section 61 of the Banking Act. On the other hand, the Bank would be required not to report on the affairs of an individual bank or on the affairs of an individual customer of the Bank; that is, the strictures in proposed new subsection (1a) would seem to cancel much or all of the effect of the requirements in proposed new subparagraph (aa). This would leave the Reserve Bank with the obligation only to report details of persons appointed to investigate and report on prudential matters under proposed section 61.

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult to see that this represents a matter of such importance that the Reserve Bank should report on it invariably and mandatorily rather than according to its discretion. If the Reserve Bank were to appoint a person other than a Reserve Bank officer to conduct an investigation, it could be expected to appoint professional auditors and accountants, including auditors already familiar with a particular bank's accounts. In view of the doubt regarding the usefulness of the provisions proposed by the Opposition and the fact that there is already a requirement in the Reserve Bank Act that the Reserve Bank report annually to the Treasurer on its operations, the Government does not support this amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIMITATION OF LIABILITY FOR MARITIME CLAIMS BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 April, on motion by Mr Robert Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Bill. There are only two things that I wish to say. The first relates to clause 7 of the Bill which provides that the applied provisions do not apply in relation to a ship that belongs to the naval, military or air forces of a foreign country. We are told in the explanatory memorandum that this clause ensures that the Act applies to vessels belonging to the defence forces of Australia but not to those of other countries. With respect to the Act applying to vessels belonging to the defence forces of Australia, it is probably a suitable opportunity simply to say that this Bill will provide one level of limitations on liability, that is, in money terms. There are other limitations, of course, and the tragic history of the Voyager should remind us of one other limitation that is still being imposed. We trust that the Government, in view of the public debate that took place in this country some months ago, might still at this stage see its way clear to reassess whether it should still rely on the statute of limitations to bar claims arising out of that accident.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter relates to aviation claims. To some extent, this Bill regularises claims for maritime accidents and limits the liability for claims arising out of such accidents. The situation with respect to aviation claims still lags behind. We trust that the Government will give attention to this to ensure that that matter is also brought into line with modern needs and requirements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Bill 1989 is proclaimed, Australia will become a party to the Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims 1976 and, subject to certain exceptions, the provisions of the 1976 Convention will then have the force of law in Australia. The 1976 Convention replaces and abrogates the International Convention relating to the Limitation of Liability of Owners of Sea-going Ships, agreed to at Brussels on 10 October 1957. The 1957 convention recognised the concept of limitation of liability of shipowners and set out certain rules relating to the limitation of liability for maritime claims. The 1957 convention also provided for upper monetary limits in respect of claims arising from a maritime incident in which loss of life, personal injury or property damage had occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: The notion and principles of limitation of liability have their origins in the eighteenth century. In the Bramley Moore case, Lord Denning described the rationale of limitation of liability as `a rule of public policy which has its origin in history and its justification in convenience'. Lord Justice Griffiths in the Garden City (No. 2) case said that the right to limitation of liability `is of long standing and generally accepted by the trading nations of the world. It is a right given to promote the general health of trade and in truth is no more than a way of distributing the insurance risk'.

In the early days of maritime trade, ship- owners often faced far greater risks than today. Most times they would have no direct control over the ships operations in the course of a voyage. Shipowners would therefore be unable to take practical steps to reduce the risk of vicarious liability for the acts or omissions of the master or crew. This was in contrast to land transport operations, where employers could be directly supervised. There was also the risk that commercially astute shipowners could limit their liability to the value of the ships by vesting ownership of the ship in a company with no other assets. It would be obviously against the interest of public policy to permit a proliferation of one-ship companies with grossly underinsured ships. Furthermore, the hazardous nature of every sea voyage was a substantial impediment to the growth of international trade.

A legal framework had to be developed to ensure the commercial viability of a shipping industry. Limitation of liability by statute seems to have commenced in 1734 with an Act which limited liability for losses by embezzlement and theft by the master or crew to the value of the ship and her appurtenances and the freight of the voyage. This limit was later extended to cases of robbery in which the master and mariners were not concerned, and more general limitation provisions were enacted by the merchant shipping Acts of 1854 and 1862.

British law on this issue applied in Australia until 1981 when amendments to the Navigation Act 1912 came into force, implementing the 1957 convention. The advantage of limitation is that, with maximum liability known, adequate assurance can be taken by a shipowner without it being prohibitively expensive. It is of interest to note that the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe has currently under consideration a draft convention for civil liability for damage caused during carriage of dangerous goods by road, rail and inland navigation vessels. This draft, which was given particular impetus by a major road tanker casualty in Spain a few years ago reflects the same kinds of principles of limitation of liability that have been the practice in shipping. The 1976 convention, which is set out in schedule 1 of this Bill, was adopted by the International Conference on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims at London on 19 November 1976 and came into force internationally on 1 December 1986.

When the British ferry Herald of Free Enterprise capsized and sank outside Zeebrugge Harbour in Belgium on 6 March 1987 with approximately 459 passengers and 80 crew aboard, the Australian Government proceeded with a study to find out how much compensation would be available to victims if a similar disaster occurred in Australia. It was quite clear that the limits operating under the 1957 convention were absurdly low. Based on the passenger carrying capacity of the Abel Tasman, the total compensation that would be available for claimants under the 1957 convention would be little more than $3m. Under the 1976 convention, it would be nearer $40m. Compensation of the Herald of Free Enterprise victims was complicated by the fact that the United Kingdom is a party to the Athens Convention Relating to the Carriage of Passengers and their Luggage. That convention places a limit on each individual claim. Therefore, although the United Kingdom had already become a party to the 1976 convention and thus the total compensation available was reasonably high, each passenger was limited individually to about $85,000. In the event, the United Kingdom Government came to a special arrangement with Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Co. ferries to increase this individual limit.

Australia is not a party to the Athens convention, and does not propose to become one. Nevertheless, having regard to the apparent difficulties for claimants connected with the Herald of Free Enterprise disaster, the need for Australia to adopt the 1976 convention was now more urgent than before. Although the States and the Northern Territory had been haggling with the Federal Government for some time over their concerns that damage to harbour works would cease to be excluded from limitation under the 1976 convention and, indeed, had been lukewarm about the new convention generally, the inadequacy of the 1957 convention compelled transport Ministers attending the 75th meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council in December 1987 to agree that Australia should accede to the 1976 convention.

The most significant change under the 1976 convention is the substantial increase in the amount of compensation claimable. The amount is still calculable in terms of units of account and is linked to the tonnage of the ship. The limit which a shipowner may claim is calculated by multiplying the tonnage of the ship-as calculated under internationally agreed rules-by the units of account laid down in the convention. For instance, a ship of 10,000 tons attracts a limit for claims for loss of life or personal injury of 3,914,000 units of account, calculated as follows: 330,000 units of account for the first 500 tons; 1,250,000 units of account for the next 2,500 tons; and 2,331,000 units of account for the next 7,000 tons.

A similar calculation for property claims yields a limit of 1,753,500 units of account. If the ship carries 500 passengers, each passenger attracts a limit of 46,666 units of account, making 23,333,000 in all. The unit of account is identical to the special drawing right (SDR) of the International Monetary Fund. Each day the IMF calculates the value of the SDR against the United States dollar by reference to a selected basket of world currencies. It then calculates the SDR against national currencies as reported by individual countries. The rate can be found in the Daily Commercial News, a newspaper published in Australia. For example, on 9 August 1989 the SDR equivalent was $1.6688. This would make the calculations on a 10,000 tonne ship $6,524,168 in respect of claims for loss of life or personal injury, $2,922,874 in respect of property claims, and $38,893,311 in respect of passenger claims.

The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) in his second reading speech gave some examples of amounts claimable. In addition to the persons entitled to the limitation of liability under the 1957 convention, article 1 of the 1976 convention extended the privilege to insurers and salvors. Salvors will now be entitled to the same limits as their insured. A salvor will be entitled to a limitation of liability when, for example, he puts members of a salvage team on board a stricken vessel, and they cause damage or loss.

Although this Bill applies the 1976 convention to all seagoing ships, it will still be open to the States and the Northern Territory to legislate themselves, if they wish, for ships in which they have a particular interest. The States and the Northern Territory have the option to legislate for the 1957 convention. Only Western Australia has done so. The States and the Northern Territory have not expressed a particular desire to legislate themselves for seagoing ships, but it is possible that there may be some State legislation to cover non-seagoing ships, such as harbour ferries. Claims which can be the subject of limitation include those in respect of death or personal injury; damage to property, including harbour works, on board or in direct connection with the operation of the ship or with salvage operations; loss of or delay in the carriage of goods or passengers; infringements of other non-contractual rights; removal or destruction of cargo; and efforts by third parties to minimise loss caused by the defendant.

Article 3 excludes certain claims from limitation such as those resulting from oil pollution or nuclear damage. Oil pollution damage is covered by its own convention-the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage 1969. Australia is already a party to that Convention. Its provisions are implemented by the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Act 1981. Both the 1957 and 1976 conventions provide that under certain circumstances a shipowner is deprived of the right to limit his liability. The 1957 convention provides that a shipowner cannot limit his liability if the occurrence giving rise to the claims resulted from the actual fault or privity of the owner. Article 4 of the 1976 convention provides that `a person shall not be entitled to limit his liability if it is proved that the loss resulted from his personal act or omission, committed with the intent to cause such loss or recklessly and with the knowledge that such loss would probably result'.

The wording of the two conventions represents a major difference as to conduct which will bar a shipowner from the right to limit his liability. Under the 1957 convention, provided that fault can be laid at the door of someone sufficiently senior in the shipowning company to be regarded as an alter ego of the company, a claimant may succeed in breaking the limits. `Alter ego' was the phrase used in the Lennards Carrying Co. case. For example, if someone in an executive position who is normally the person responsible in the company for the management and control of the navigation of vessels and the training of the crews has instituted a system of checks and safeguards which is disregarded by those further down the hierarchy, such as masters, the fault cannot be attributed to the `alter ego' of the company. However, where no proper system of safeguards, checks, reporting, et cetera has been instituted, this in itself is actual fault on the part of the `alter ego' of the owning company.

Under the 1976 convention, in order for a claimant to break limitation the loss must result from the shipowner's personal act or omission. This probably means someone much higher up in the company than is the case under the 1957 convention. More importantly, it would seem that there must be actual knowledge, which would probably include the turning of a blind eye, as opposed to constructive knowledge, to acts or omissions which caused the loss. The claimant would also have to show that the owner either intended to cause the loss or was sufficiently reckless that he knew that such loss was probable. Furthermore, the burden of proof is on the claimant, which means that under article 4 of the 1976 convention if there were any doubt about the personal misconduct of the owner he would be able to claim limited liability. Under the old law the burden of proof lay upon the person seeking to establish the right to limit. So it was the defendant shipowner who had to establish that the loss occurred without his actual fault or privity. The shifting of the burden of proof may well turn out to be the most significant change between the 1957 convention and the 1976 convention. Many cases have failed on burden of proof in the past. Nevertheless, whilst a claimant seeking to break the limits under the 1976 convention will have a harder job than previously, the upper limits of damages are substantially increased. The Government, therefore, believes that the net result of the trade-off is a fairer deal for the victim and a more predictable risk to be covered by the shipowner.

As the Minister indicated in his second reading speech, the Bill will be proclaimed in the second half of 1990. The Bill provides for proclamation to take place within 18 months of the royal assent. The Bill is a tribute to the accomplishments of the Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support. I commend the Bill to the support of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that there is such great interest in this important legislation. I am sure that the absence of members from the chamber is because the Opposition has indicated its strong support for this legislation.
—The Opposition is here.

—I know. It has indicated its strong support for this legislation through the honourable member for Menzies. I am pleased to speak on the Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Bill 1989. This Bill will greatly increase the amount of compensation available to victims of a maritime accident, a matter that has concerned many people for some time. Australia is currently party to the International Convention relating to the Limitation of the Liability of Owners of Seagoing Ships 1957 and its 1979 protocol. The convention and protocol, which are implemented by part 8 of the Navigation Act 1912, establish upper limits for claims arising from a maritime accident in which loss of life, personal injury or property damage occurs.

SPEECH.PARA: For some time now it has been felt that the limits set by the 1957 convention have been far too low. For this reason a diplomatic conference held in 1976 decided to adopt the Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims, which came into force internationally on 1 December 1986. To date there are 16 countries which are party to the convention. These include Japan, the Scandinavian countries, the United Kingdom, France, the Federal Republic of Germany and Liberia. With the passage of this Bill Australia will join these countries as a party to the 1976 convention.

A few simple statistics will illustrate just how inadequate and outdated the 1957 convention is. Under this Convention the total amount of compensation available to cover an accident to a ship of 10,000 tonnes would be little more than $3m. In the case of a major accident such as the disaster suffered by the Herald of Free Enterprise, already mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), in which there were 193 claimants, the average amount of compensation available to each claimant would be in the order of only $15,000 to $17,000. This is hardly enough to compensate adequately for serious and permanent injury or, indeed, for loss of life. Under the 1976 convention, which this Bill seeks to ratify, some $40m would be available to cover such an accident. The average compensation payment to each passenger would be in the order of some $200,000. The 1976 convention and the legislation now before the House make provision for both personal claims and property claims and set upper limits for both types of compensation. In the case of personal claims, the upper limit of total claim is based on the tonnage of the ship and in round figures ranges from $500,000 for a ship of 500 tons to $6m for a ship of 10,000 tons. In the case of property claims, which include claims for damage to other ships, general property and harbour works, the system for determining compensation is similar, ranging from $250,000 for a ship of 500 tons to almost $3m for a ship of 10,000 tons.

In addition, article 7 of the 1976 convention makes provision for a separate fund to compensate for loss of life or personal injury to passengers. Once again, the level of overall compensation is governed by a sliding scale which is determined by the number of passengers a particular vessel is licensed to carry. For example, the maximum compensation available to passengers on the Abel Tasman would be just under $40m. As a trade-off for the greatly increased levels of compensation now made available, the convention sets in place a virtually ironclad system of limiting liability. Under this system a person will be deprived of his or her right to limit liability only if it can be proved that the loss resulted from a personal act or omission committed with intent to cause such a loss or else committed recklessly with the knowledge that such a loss would probably result.

While the legislation before the House deals with property damage and damage to life and limb suffered by persons involved in a maritime accident, I believe it is important to consider also the damage done to the sea itself, which very much affects the quality of life not only of seafarers but of every man, woman and child on our planet. I would recommend to the House that we need to be very concerned as to the adequacy of our legislation covering damage to the sea and to monitor the situation continually and closely. This is a matter of particular importance to Australia because we depend almost exclusively on shipping to move our exports and imports and we have, in terms of tonnes per kilometres, the fifth largest shipping task in the world. To fulfil our trade commitments there are some 11,000 ship visits to Australia each year. Prevention is a positive approach to pollution. The cleanliness of Australia's oceans can be maintained through the enforcement of legislation, through education and through the continued development of control procedures for the prevention and physical removal of harmful substances from the marine environment.

As I have already indicated, the legislation now before the House is most commendable and I am sure it will be enthusiastically supported-indeed, I know it is enthusiastically supported. But by its very nature it is limited to a consideration of the need for adequate compensation for accidents connected with seagoing activities. I hope I have made clear that members of this House and people generally need also to be actively concerned lest there take place at sea those accidents for which there can be no adequate compensation: namely, those accidents that do irreparable damage to our entire marine environment.

I am pleased to note that there is within Australia general support for the legislation now before the House which will ratify the 1986 convention. Such support was indicated at the seventy-fifth meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council held in December 1987. At that meeting Federal, State and Northern Territory transport Ministers agreed that Australia should accede to the 1976 convention. I now have much pleasure in likewise lending my support to this important legislation and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I just want to express my appreciation to those people who have participated in this debate, including the spokesman for the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), and to thank him in particular for the observations that he made about the Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Bill and also for the support that he indicated the Opposition would provide. He recognised, in indicating the nature of that support, his understanding of the importance of this legislation to the compensation that is available to victims of maritime accidents, whether they result in personal injury or property injury. Of course, the Bill enables Australia to become a party to the 1976 Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims, to which reference has already been made.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to express my very great appreciation to the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), two members on this side of the House who have indicated by their previous commitment to questions of this kind that their concern is a continuing one. The quality of their contributions to this debate indicates not only the understanding that they bring to it but also the great deal of time and effort that has clearly gone into researching the material that they have brought to our attention. The honourable member for Herbert gave an extremely valuable historic outline and indicated a clear understanding of the implications of the legislation. The honourable member for Throsby indicated the background to this legislation and I appreciate the clarity of his presentation. The importance to shipping generally in Australia was also noted. That is something which the honourable member for Throsby has pursued on numerous occasions.

In conclusion, I want to express my personal appreciation to the officers of the Department of Transport and Communications who have been involved in the preparation of this legislation and for the advice which they have given to me. Not only has it been a very useful exercise as far as the Government and the Parliament are concerned but it has been extremely important as far as Australia is concerned, particularly to those people whom the legislation is designed to protect.
