DEBATE.TITLE: EXOTIC ANIMAL DISEASE CONTROL BILL 1989[COGNATE BILLS:DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1989EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989LAYING CHICKEN LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989MEAT CHICKEN LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989PIG SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill 1989 concurrently with orders of the day Nos 4 to 9. There being no objection, that course will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is general agreement amongst the livestock producers of Australia and the government departments concerned with the livestock industries that we need to improve the preparedness of this country to meet the very imminent threat of exotic disease which could decimate our livestock industries and our valuable exports. With that recognition there is an assumption of a need for more resources; hence the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill and related Bills which we are now debating. There is also general agreement and recognition that better coordination is needed to maximise what is being done at the present time and what can be done to protect one of the great natural advantages of Australia in international trade: that is, our isolation as an island continent from countries that have particular diseases. Part of that improved effort will be to provide more complete and timely information and advice. That is all agreed. But there are questions that need answers. Who should pay for those additional resources? Should it be the Federal and State governments, or industry? What percentage should each pay? Which industries should contribute? Who should control the money that is collected?

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition parties support this legislation because we recognise it is of the highest priority to protect the livestock industries and the exports of more than $8 billion that they so efficiently provide for this country against some very dangerous diseases-bluetongue, screw worm fly, rabies, et cetera.

The Opposition and the livestock industries are concerned that the national Government of this country is transferring some of its national and public health responsibility to the farmers of this country. If one considers the developments in primary industry, one can see that the Government has moved very much to a user pays principle. We have an example in the dollar for dollar arrangement that is being proposed in the legislation when in the past the Government paid for all disease preparedness. The Government is not applying the same policy of transferring to the non-primary industries the cost of what have always been considered Government responsibilities. This is not the only example; there are earlier examples. For example, a couple of years ago the chemical residue problem had the ability to decimate our beef export. The problem came about not through farmers breaking Government regulations in relation to the use of pesticides and weedicides, but through their following the very best advice on the use of those chemicals that was available at that time; yet the industry had to pay all that great cost. The beef industry, in particular, responded magnificently, but the Government at least could have shared that cost with the industry.

The national market basket survey has always been considered a public health responsibility; it is designed to see how pure are the foods that everybody in Australia eats and to check that they are free from a range of things which we would not want Australians to be eating. It should be a public health responsibility, but the Government has put it on to the farmers through levies. The national residue survey on the foods we eat and export, which should also be a national public health responsibility, is also being palmed off on to the farmers.

Perhaps the best example is the fishing industry which has a range of problems with respect to the uncertainty of the resource. Basically, the industry is paying for the departmental employees in Canberra. It has no ability to control the number or cost of those employees; there is no accountability to the industry for the levies that are placed on it. With the additional amount of $1 1/2m-$750,000 from the designated livestock industries and $750,000 from the Government-comes the test of whether Federal and State governments will maintain their expenditure in quarantine and in exotic disease prevention measures as they have in the past or whether this provides an opportunity for the Government to transfer more of the cost to rural industry. It will also be a test of whether the Government will adopt the same policies for some of the other industries in this country.

As I indicated, one of the purposes of the Bill is to levy a range of industries in related legislation so that they will pay 50 per cent, or $750,000. The representative of those industries is the National Farmers Federation (NFF). I accept that form of representation. I also commend the NFF for accepting the challenge of the Government in the May 1988 economic statement to combine with the Government so that there will be more resources against these potentially disastrous diseases. The industries which will pay, in particular, are the dairy, poultry, sheep meat and beef, pig and wool industries, which will pay about $300,000 of the $750,000. There is no doubt that those industries are all beneficiaries, but they are not the only beneficiaries. There are those who own horses, the equine industry; the deer industry; pets; the livestock breeding industry; and humans. There is a relationship between some diseases of animals and some diseases of humans, so there is certainly a general public health beneficiary with the provision of more resources.

More of the sheep and cattle livestock industry would be picked up if the livestock slaughter levy were replaced by the livestock transaction levy as a means of collection of money generally for the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, research and promotion, and so forth. It was announced today that the Government is increasing by 18 per cent the charges on the slaughter of animals because the kill will be down this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The industries are being used as a milking cow.
—That is a very good comment. We could also say that industry is being fleeced by the Government.
—You really have your snout in the trough.

—At least I am bringing home the bacon better than the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did last year. To return to the debate, I would hope that when the kill of livestock picks up, there will be an equal 18 per cent reduction in the charges by Government and that the Government will not just use it as a way of reducing its commitment and increasing that of the industry. I believe, however, that the levy should be extended to the other industries which benefit. I know the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) indicated in his second reading speech that it will be considered. The fact that there is no research or promotion levy arrangement or legislation for those industries is no reason for not being able to obtain financial assistance. For example, only a few months ago in the Parliament with the extension of the Horticultural Corporation the nursery industry was made to pay a levy. By negotiating with the providers of pots and other equipment that everybody in the nursery industry uses, the industry was able to collect the required amount of money to pay the levy. There is no reason why the same could not be done in the horse industry and with the pet population and their owners. They are major beneficiaries of keeping these diseases out of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The next question concerns who controls the money that is raised. We are talking about an exotic disease Bill and we certainly have some exotic titles in relation to it. We have the exotic disease preparedness trust account to look after the money and the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council which will advise on the use of the money as well as giving general and broader advice on priorities. That is one of the purposes of the broadening of advice-for it is a purpose to broaden advice-so that bodies other than the Australian Agricultural Council and the departments can be consulted about priorities and the best way of doing things. There will be eight members on the Council: one from the Australian Agricultural Council; one from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy; two from the National Farmers Federation; one who is expert in disaster and emergency management; one who is expert in communications and public relations; one who is expert in agricultural marketing; and one from the veterinary profession.

One of the concerns of the farmers of Australia, as represented by the National Farmers Federation, was that the Minister would be able to increase the levy unnecessarily or to transfer the responsibility from government or reduce the responsibility of government against the wishes of the industries concerned. I understand that one of the amendments which the Government has accepted and will be presenting is that the NFF representatives will have a veto on the rate of the levy-that is, the Minister will not be able to introduce a levy higher than that which was last recommended by the NFF representatives. I think that that is a sensible safeguard and certainly it improves the attitude of the Opposition parties to the legislation. Another sensible amendment is that any direction that the Minister gives to the council in relation to its duties must be a written direction by the Minister and must be tabled in Parliament as soon as possible.

Another area of concern is the role of the States. The State governments have been involved very much in animal disease prevention over the years. After all, they have their own responsibilities for primary industries and livestock industries in their States. They provide finance and adopt measures and programs in their own right. They are also agents of the Commonwealth in this area. They will pay 50 per cent of the cost of the control programs if there is any outbreak of exotic diseases. The States are also represented through the Australian Agricultural Council and the Ausvetplan which will be put into place in any such outbreak. So it is important to maintain the commitment of the States to both financial and procedural involvement.

I have received representations from State Ministers and concerned people in State parliaments concerning the duplication of advice from the proposed council and the Agricultural Council in relation to exotic diseases; the relationship of the Ausvetplan to the proposed preparedness council; and the fact that there will be only one Agricultural Council member on that consultative council. There is also a hint in the Minister's second reading speech that the financial arrangements between the Federal and State governments could be altered by this new levy and fund. I believe that it is important to recognise first of all that there is a need for a broader advice and expertise arrangement than was the case with just the Agricultural Council and the States, but similarly there should be a recognition that the States must continue to have an important role to play in which they feel that they are a continuing part of the process.

The final point I want to make is that this legislation presents us with an elaborate mechanism-the procedure, the council and the collection of levies; the amendment of about eight Bills-to put in place a new procedure to prevent what is possibly avoidable, that is, these disastrous animal diseases or pests that could have such an impact on our animal industries. We support that. It is important. The farmers of Australia support is, although reluctantly, because they believe the Government should be doing that anyway. But we could do all this and then another arm of the Federal Government, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS), through its policy of acceptable risk on the importation of animals and plants, could blow the whole thing.

I want to raise that most seriously. I am greatly concerned that we run a great risk of exotic diseases coming into this country officially through this policy of AQIS. This almost occurred with deer from New Zealand twelve months ago. There are other examples. I want to make that point in conclusion. What a disaster it would be if we collect all this extra money, set up all these procedures, do all these things for the benefit of the livestock industries of Australia and yet, through the official importation of animals, we allow the diseases which we are trying to prevent to be brought into this country. As I said earlier, the Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some years ago the then Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales, the predecessor of the present New South Wales Farmers Association, warned that an outbreak of some exotic diseases could devastate rural economies and ruin many of our country towns. It is very hard for people to visualise this but it could happen because an outbreak like that could virtually wipe out Australia's meat exports. An outbreak in the poultry industry could virtually wipe out chicken meat production.

SPEECH.PARA: Heeding the views of organisations like the farmer organisations and a wide range of people, not long after the Hawke Government was elected in 1983 it recognised for the first time, under the capable guidance of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), the need to do something about Australia's feral animal problem and the potential of that problem to spread exotic disease. About seven years ago I recall talking in the local pub at Nimmitabel in Eden-Monaro to a couple of people, Bernie Owers and Col Hunt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nimmitabel?

—Nimmitabel pub. I do not know whether the honourable member for Farrer has been that far away from his border, but it is certainly not very far from it. Col Hunt, who lived there at the time, and Bernie Owers talked about the feral animal problem in the Nimmitabel area-not only dogs, which were a real worry to farmers, but also pigs. I am sure that the honourable members who are here in the House today-all of whom, I note, represent country electorates-are aware of the importance of dealing with feral pigs, which constitute a more subtle danger than feral dogs.

SPEECH.PARA: Just after the Hawke Government came to office in 1983 and then again in 1984 I convened two Search conferences on these matters with the encouragement of people such as Col Hunt. Following the conferences, the Government initiated a number of measures to work towards control of feral animals and exotic disease outbreak in feral populations. This occurred after two attempts-first by the Minister in the previous Government, Mr Ralph Hunt, and then by the present Minister himself-to get a national Federal Government program on the ground. The honourable member for Werriwa, the present Minister, succeeded with his third attempt.

Along with the success of that, we have developed a network of a whole range of experts inside and outside the government. State and Federal experts have come up with many of the answers that we need. Some of them were referred to by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). Col Hunt himself is now an expert in feral animal containment through electric fencing. It is great to have seen him involved in some of the programs which were developed as a result of the initiation by this Government of a national program.

The purpose of the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill is to establish the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council and the exotic animal disease preparedness trust account. The Council is going to consolidate work which has already been done towards exotic disease preparedness. This includes the establishment of an animal resources branch in the then Bureau of Animal Health, now the Bureau of Rural Resources, under the very capable directorship of Dr George Wilson. Then there was the establishment of a wildlife and exotic diseases program in 1984, coordinated by the Bureau of Rural Resources. As well as that there was substantial funding for feral animal control under the community employment program. That is where Col Hunt had his entry into feral animal control. Then there were continuing employment programs in feral animal control. It is great to have worked with the Federal Minister and with people in his Department like George Wilson and David Murray so that we can have continuing employment programs in feral animal control. Not only are those people tackling the problem at the time; they are also training people in an area where we need plenty of expertise. In the past seven years my office staff and I have worked hard on the feral animal control issue because it is a matter of vital economic importance, and it is also important to the conservation of native flora and fauna, including those in national parks. I have been able to keep abreast of the excellent efforts being made under the exotic diseases program through the Bureau of Rural Resources to determine appropriate strategies and epidemiology priorities.

Introduced-that is, feral-and some native wild animals pose a major risk in an exotic disease emergency for a number of reasons: they are widespread, they are abundant, they are thought to share disease susceptibility of domestic stock, and they often lurk close to domestic stock. The potential of feral animals to destroy our rural industries and the Australian economy in an exotic disease outbreak is very often underestimated. We need to look to control feral and wild animals if we are to protect our domestic animals, let alone our native animals. If we are to contain disease in domestic stock, then control in feral and wild animals is vital. The techniques for their survey, sampling, containment and control are of the utmost importance and will save our domestic farm animals in the event of exotic disease outbreak. The contribution of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, through the Animal Resources Branch, is matched by at least 50 per cent State or Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation funding, resources and equipment. The projects are considered by the Animal Health Committee and the Vertebrate Pests Committee before going to the Standing Committee on Agriculture. The results of all these projects, which involve scientific research on feral animal control and research into strategic possibilities for control, are the basis of operational plans for incorporation in Ausvetplan and State exotic disease control plans.

Ausvetplan, the Australian veterinary emergency plan, coordinated by the Commonwealth Government as an element within the national control counter disaster plan, is extremely important. It provides a comprehensive structure which brings together animal health and counter disaster arrangements at Commonwealth, State and local levels. It cannot be overestimated. The national plan is important to deal with an exotic disease outbreak-so near that one trembles-and I notice the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) was hesitant in calling an exotic disease outbreak avoidable. He said, `We hope it is avoidable' or `It is possibly avoidable' and that is about as far as we can go. One trembles to call it avoidable.

The objectives of the exotic disease preparedness program are to provide a rapid eradication capability and thereby reduce the time domestic livestock are subject to disease outbreaks and their associated costs to farmers. The program's objectives are also to prevent such exotic disease outbreaks becoming endemic within Australia, while eradication is considered to be reasonably feasible. Establishment of this Bill will give effect to a commitment announced in the Government policy statement entitled Primary Industries and Resources, Policies for Growth. This aims to raise Australia's preparedness in emergencies to an ever higher level of readiness. The Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council will consist of eight part time members supported by a national secretariat located in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Its role will be to provide an independent stream of advice to the Government on exotic disease control policy and operations. It is intended that advice from the Council will focus especially on the wider management, social and financial implications of disease eradication operation. It will complement the excellent work already being done in the Bureau of Rural Resources by the Animal Resources Branch.

However, we should not lose sight of the expertise in that branch or in any way diminish its vital work in exotic disease control planning. There are areas where the Government needs to be wary about replacing important expertise with people who may well be good administrators. It is important that we listen to those people. I can think of a range of areas within government-the forestry industry, for instance, engineering, pharmaceutical benefits and the health area-where we ought not to lose sight of the need for close contact between those who are doing the research and those who are implementing the results of that research. In some cases those who are qualified should be the ones to do the job.

Since the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) first introduced a national program in 1983-84 tremendous strides have been made by Federal and State Governments through the funding of the feral animal control programs. I believe that these ought to continue. If anything, the whole area has been underfunded. It is important that we maintain-indeed, increase-funding under these programs. It is particularly important that we support every measure that can possibly be taken to ensure that Australia is protected against a possible exotic disease outbreak. It is with great pleasure that I support the Bills before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to support the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill. This Bill will establish the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council and provide the necessary funding formula. Because this proposed Council will need to be funded by livestock industries, the Bill currently before the House has with it a number of Bills which are designed to allow for levy collections. Those Bills are the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Amendment Bill, the Laying Chicken Levy Amendment Bill, the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill, all of which require amendment in order to allow the levy to be collected.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a little sad that I should rise to give this speech in a House as empty as this one is. I do not say that in any egotistical way. I do not expect honourable members to come flooding into the House to hear what I have to say, but I think the importance to the nation of the legislation currently before the House has largely been overlooked by the Parliament and the nation generally. We live in a veritable paradise. We live in a nation relatively free from the nastiest of exotic diseases. Because we have known nothing but this paradise for the produce of livestock we have scant regard for the real asset that is ours. The importance this House should place on quarantine and on keeping Australia free from exotic animal diseases cannot be overstated. The reason the Opposition supports the legislation presently before the House is simply that we recognise the importance of having a nation that continues to be free from exotic animal diseases and of having in place a committee that can act speedily if ever an exotic animal disease should be located in Australia.

It is entirely topical that I should address this matter on this day. It is entirely topical that the legislation should have come into this House today, Wednesday, 16 August. While we speak here, quarantine officers, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and every Australian sheep farmer are concerned about the delay in the unloading of live sheep in Saudi Arabia-a delay that has resulted entirely from a rumour that those live sheep were infected with the blue-tongue virus. The Minister has given us an assurance, and we have no reason to doubt his word, that those sheep are entirely free from the blue-tongue virus and from any other exotic disease. In fact, Anita Poddar pointed out in Monday's Advertiser that rarely has any strain of the bluetongue virus been found in Australia and never in commercial livestock. She said:
Several strains of the virus have been found in midges in northern Australia but the disease has never occurred in any flock.

The impact of the live sheep industry on agriculture in Australia is not appreciated widely enough. Yesterday an Australian news broadcaster pointed out that Australia exported 7.1 million live sheep worth $250m to the Middle East last financial year and about half of this went to Saudi Arabia. The Saudi Arabian market is worth somewhere between $70m and $125m to our economy, not to mention the boost it gives to the sheep industry by providing this market for live sheep. The news broadcast said:
The troubles started a fortnight ago when edicts from King Faud prevented 192,000 sheep in two ships being unloaded after reports that they had a rare disease bluetongue.
Late last week another consignment of 33,500 sheep was rejected because of claims that they had sheep pox.
``None of these claims has been supported by clinical evidence of any description . . .

Today we are dealing with a proposal to allow us to reassure the rest of the world that not only is Australia free from the worst of the exotic diseases but also were any disease to be found here it would be acted on promptly because of the establishment of the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council to be funded under the legislation presently before the House. Because of the importance of this legislation, because of the fundamental importance of maintaining a nation which has a reputation around the world for being vigilant in the way in which it deals with quarantine and disease control, the Opposition is prepared to support the Bill though we do not think it is a Bill that is in any sense perfect. In fact, we recognise that there are several amendments that would go a long way towards improving the Bill's overall efficiency.

We are not alone in the concerns we have expressed. We express them not purely for the sake of making a cheap political point but to echo concerns of the National Farmers Federation (NFF) and what it has already said to the Government about this legislation. I will quote briefly from a letter that Mr Prendergast of the National Farmers Federation sent to the honourable member for Murray when expressing concern about some of the detail of this legislation to establish the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council. Mr Prendergast said that the National Farmers Federation was largely in favour of this proposal. First, Mr Prendergast said:
There is a prima facie case that more resources need to be allocated to improve Australia's exotic disease preparedness . . .
That is what this legislation does. Secondly, he said:
That there is scope for better co-ordination between commodities . . .
The Council will allow that. Thirdly, he said:
That in certain circumstances it is appropriate that industry contributes to the funding.

Of course, this Bill ensures entirely that that will happen. In fact, the industry contributing to the funding is one of the areas of concern to which the Opposition wants to alert both the Government and the nation. The NFF, in its letter to the honourable member for Murray, has said that it has been concerned to ensure that the scheme is not used simply to fund Government responsibilities with industry moneys. The honourable member for Murray has alluded to this and expanded on this point.

We have a commitment by primary industry in Australia to find three-quarters of a million dollars for the establishment of this Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council-three-quarters of a million dollars that is coming from the livestock producers in Australia; three-quarters of a million dollars that is not being matched in any way by the livestock people who raise horses, deer or other breeding livestock. Even more significantly, this three-quarters of a million dollars is not being contributed to in any way by the millions of Australians who keep pets of one kind or another. All of those people will benefit because Australia will be exotic disease free and we have a guarantee that, should exotic disease occur, we have a Council that can act promptly to wipe it out. All of them benefit but the contribution to make this legislation and Council work comes from the livestock producers who are already paying levies and are therefore obliged to make an additional contribution.

The Minister, in his second reading speech, said that less than 0.01 per cent of the gross value of the industries would be required to fund this Council. That is perfectly true. One might say it is peanuts, but it is still an imposition being borne by primary producers on behalf of the total community.

The National Farmers Federation recognises, as did the honourable member for Murray, that while the Bill is not perfect, it is welcomed. Furthermore, the National Farmers Federation recognises, as did the honourable member for Murray, that the Government has agreed to make some amendments to the way in which levies are collected to ensure that a more equitable collection system applies than was originally proposed. We support this legislation because we recognise the importance of quarantine to Australia's export industry, particularly its livestock industries.

I grew up in an area that was quarantined and declared fruit fly free. That is unrelated to the Bill but it has this significance-in that area I recognised the importance of keeping the Riverland of South Australia fruit fly free and I recognised that this was only possible by diligent and vigilant exercise from the Department of Agriculture in ensuring that all people who entered or left the area did so through a road block that was policed. That has been invaluable for South Australia's horticultural exports. It has been invaluable for the region. This legislation has the capacity to be similarly invaluable for the nation. It allows us to declare to the world that we have a veritable paradise in terms of the control of exotic diseases.

The Lindsay review on quarantine gave us a national perspective of what our quarantine should be all about. This legislation protects an industry estimated to be worth almost $8 billion. It is important to have protections in place because the people with whom we trade are so fiercely competitive. As we have seen this week in the case of the live sheep trade into Saudi Arabia, the smallest excuse for a quarantine claim can jeopardise an entire industry. The quarantine wing of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has been diligent in the past and in 1985, for example, successfully stamped out an outbreak of avian influenza, which was prominent in Victoria.

We recognise that the importation of animals is a real risk to Australia. This sort of quarantine standard helps us not only to declare to the rest of the world that the animals we send overseas are exotic disease free but also to ensure that the animals we bring into Australia are similarly disease free. A real concern is being expressed-and it is relevant to this legislation that I say so-by the pig industry about the importation of pig meat into Australia and the possible occurrence in Australia of transmissible gastroenteritis (TGE) as a result of pig meats coming into Australia. The honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) alerted my office to say that he had been approached by the Darling Downs Pork Producers' Association, which was concerned that too little had been done to control the importation of fresh pork and the possible spread of TGE as a result. The honourable member for Groom and I have mutually agreed that a committee which I chair on behalf of the Opposition ought to be meeting with the quarantine wing of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to ensure that all that can be done is being done to satisfy pork producers across Australia that TGE and the importation of fresh pork will not pose a major problem. I know that the honourable member for Groom will be pleased to be able to reassure the Darling Downs Pork Producers' Association that this matter has not simply been conveniently overlooked.

I conclude by referring to a comment made by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) who preceded me in this debate. He said that the honourable member for Murray had been hesitant in reassuring the House that we could be sure that the legislation would keep Australia exotic disease free. The honourable member for Murray was responsible in being hesitant because this Bill contains no reassurance that Australia will be exotic disease free. This Bill allows us to put in place a consultative council that can reassure those who receive our produce that everything that can be done is being done to keep the nation exotic disease free. In fact, it is not possible to avoid perfectly the importation of exotic diseases; it is possible to be constantly vigilant as a nation. It is because this Bill allows us to be constantly vigilant and to be more efficient than we otherwise would have been in the policing, stamping out and, preferably, the total restriction on any exotic diseases, that I am pleased to support its passage through the House this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), have reason to be grateful to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service for the work which it has undertaken over the years to ensure that, as much as possible, our primary industry is disease free. I come from an area which has a very large potato growing industry. We know that Australia's potato growing industry has always been concerned about the possibility of potato nematode and diseases such as black wart coming in from places such as New Zealand. The golden cyst nematode is endemic in other countries as well. If those diseases were to come into Australia there would be very serious effects upon the economy of all potato growing areas. It certainly would mean that we would not be in a position to maintain the integrity of the industry. So, like the honourable member for Wakefield, I am very grateful to the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has served the nation particularly well in restricting the number of exotic diseases entering the country and threatening our very important primary industries. It has always been to our advantage as a marketer of primary industry commodities to be able to sell our goods on world markets with the knowledge that our history of clean products provided us with a competitive advantage over other nations. It has to be recognised that our farm products earn this nation about 40 per cent of our export revenue. While there might be some argument about whether that is something to be relied upon in the future, nevertheless it is and always has been extremely important to Australia's economy. I imagine that it will be that way proportionately for a long time to come, until such time as our manufacturing industries take up the offers that have been made to them to accept the challenge to restructure Australia's economy.

I need hardly remind the House that an outbreak of any of the exotic diseases covered by the then Prime Minister's Premiers agreement of 1955 would have had a devastating effect upon our economy as a whole and upon the livelihood of farm families and rural communities in particular. I applaud the amendment to the package of draft legislation which was tabled on 24 May 1989. Because of the likelihood that an outbreak of a new exotic disease would occur without warning, immediate response to that risk is vital if the outbreak is to be contained and controlled. The current mechanism for taking action is inappropriate to meet this contingency because it is too slow at the implementation level. Therefore, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has decided to amend the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill to enable the new exotic disease to be determined by regulation, which means that action can be taken immediately.

Because of the importance of the industry sector to our economy it has been necessary to ensure that the most up-to-date plan for ensuring its secure future be in place. Of course, that is covered by the Bill. The establishment of the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council will mean that we have the basis for the mechanism that is necessary to ensure not only the maintenance of the high standards of our quarantine service, but also that it is improved. Given that there exists even greater threat to our livestock industry through modern travel and greater volumes of trade between nations, the need for such planning cannot be stressed too much. It is a very sobering thought that, as estimated in 1985, an outbreak of foot and mouth disease could cost Australia between $2 billion and $3 billion per annum. That is a very large number of bickies.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be more.

—Quite true; as the honourable member for Wannon says, it could well be more. Our freedom from diseases such as foot and mouth disease has ensured that our industry access to markets has been as good as it is. The introduction to the summary document of the Australian veterinary emergency plan of 1987 stresses the difficulties posed by animal disease emergencies. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The economic impact is immediately national; not focal.
The operational phase of the emergency control is usually much longer, lasting weeks, months or years.
The demand for resources may be very much larger and may continue for a much longer time.
The reasons for many essential control measures will not always be obvious to the general public or to many of the people called upon to provide assistance.

If the disease becomes endemic the impact on the economy and communities is immediate and long lasting. In my own area, should foot and mouth disease break out, it would devastate the economies of Ballarat, Ararat, Stawell, Beaufort, Avoca and, I might say, even areas beyond the boundaries of my electorate-it is difficult to contain it-such as Hamilton, every small community on the plains of the great and extraordinarily productive Western District of Victoria and the communities to the north and west of the Pyrenees. I say `all of those communities', because all of them are integral to the kind of farming that takes place.

Ausvetplan, which is now in place, provides a comprehensive approach to coping with outbreaks of any of the threatening exotic diseases. To the individual farmer, understandably, sometimes the measures appear to be drastic. The necessary destruction of livestock can mean a whole life's work disappears, but on sober reflection every farmer knows that these measures are necessary. If it were not his farm, it might well have been someone else's. Australia faces problems that are peculiar to this country. Vast tracts of land are sparsely inhabited. Although much of it is composed of grazing properties, the carrying capacity of those areas is low. Stock roam over large areas as grasslands are seldom lush. But the same territory is also subject to the presence of feral stock such as brumbies, camels, pigs, goats, donkeys, buffalo, wild cattle and deer. All these animals are possible vectors, and control mechanisms of outbreaks in remote areas are logistically very complex. I know that my colleague the honourable member for Hawker would agree with me that if we were to have an outbreak of foot and mouth disease in the north of Australia, its control would be almost impossible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the honourable member for Ballarat that his reference is to the honourable member for Wannon, Mr Hawker.
—Yes, I am sorry. The honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) does not have a great number of farmers in her electorate, now that I come to think of it.

SPEECH.PARA: While farmers and farmer organisations, and meat processors and related unions are quite aware of the potential damage and cost of diseases such as foot and mouth disease, I doubt whether city dwellers know very much about it. But it is of as much significance to them as it is to anybody else. In fact, in some respects, it is more so. I stress to those who might be concerned about city issues who may well be listening tonight that they should recognise that we are still a nation which is dependent upon primary industry for a large proportion of its export earnings. Programs that are part and parcel of everyday expectations such as those associated with education, health, community services and social security would be hard hit in the event of an outbreak of a disease such as foot and mouth disease. Not only would control mechanisms be massively expensive, but we would also lose billions of dollars worth of trade. As a favoured supplier, our status would be lost and our premium markets would close. Hence the need for the most stringent of quarantine regulations.

Australia enjoys a reputation for its high standards of quarantine, and this must be maintained and constantly enhanced by reviewing procedures and putting in place the most modern scientific knowledge and surveillance procedures. I am not surprised to learn of the cooperation of the various primary industry groups involved in producing livestock in being prepared to make their contribution to ensuring that our record is maintained.

As the Minister indicated, our exports of livestock and livestock products are currently worth $8 billion per annum. We do not want that jeopardised. He gave us an indication of the immediate trade implications of an outbreak of foot and mouth disease and what it would do to our United States market. Immediately our US market would close for 12 months-possibly longer, because we would have to get back into that market; we would have to demonstrate the integrity of our livestock. I emphasise foot and mouth disease even though there is quite a large range of new exotic diseases. I know that the Minister has demonstrated his capacity in regard to foot and mouth disease quite often. I want to stress how extremely important the establishment of the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council is. I compliment the Minister on having been able to gain the cooperation of the industry sectors in making their contribution to the Exotic Disease Preparedness Trust Account. With the Government being prepared to match its cost on a dollar for dollar basis, this will ensure that it has the money to draw upon to ensure that the kinds of programs that it wishes to put in place are able to get under way as soon as possible.

I commend the way the Opposition has supported the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill. It is understandable that occasionally Opposition members find an opportunity to say a few words here and there. It is an extremely important Bill and its implications are far reaching. As I said, we want to maintain the integrity of the quarantine services that we have in this country. This legislation will ensure that that takes place. I have a great deal of pleasure in supporting this legislation. I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is easy to support the sentiments of the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) in many ways. In speaking to the legislation before the House I will be concentrating on the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill. The points that have been raised already highlight the importance of maintaining Australia's exotic disease free status. I also commend the honourable member for Ballarat for making the point about the importance of this subject to people not just on the land, not just in small country towns but also city dwellers. That is a point that ought to be underlined. It should be brought home to all Australians more often, because, as has been pointed out already, an $8 billion a year industry is not one we can afford to see affected adversely, as it may well be if we were to have an outbreak of one of these exotic diseases or pests. This $8 billion industry, by any measure, is our largest export industry. Our present parlous current account status underlines yet again the importance of maintaining these exports.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also very important to realise how vigilant we must be in maintaining preparedness against exotic diseases. It is always difficult to assess that level of preparedness when we do not see a real outbreak. We can believe that we are properly prepared, but until our preparedness is put to the test, it is only our best assessment. Clearly, the moves that are being foreshadowed in this Bill are another step in the right direction. It is important that we not only support this step but also continue to build on that because there are so many ways in which exotic diseases can come into Australia. With increased air travel, with increased trade, with the increase in the number of people coming through our airports-not to mention some of the illegal visitors we seem to have from time to time along our northern shores-the risk of an outbreak is ever present. In many ways the risk is increased on a purely exponential basis by the growing number of people and articles coming into Australia every year.

While we talk about the effect that an outbreak may have on our livestock industries, we also have to consider the effect it would have on our native fauna. Again, this should be brought home to people in the cities who are concerned about our flora and fauna and about the environment in general so that they realise that the outbreak of an exotic disease in Australia would have dramatic effects right across the country, not just on our livestock industries but on all areas.

It is for this and many other reasons that it is so important that we maintain our disease free status. As was pointed out by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the value of some areas of trade, such as the live sheep trade, is so important that we have to be ever vigilant. The recent concern over the live sheep trade to Saudi Arabia highlights yet again the dramatic impact that even a relatively isolated incident or two can have on the live sheep trade. Already the price of boat sheep, boat wethers, has fallen significantly-by anything up to 25 per cent-in the last couple of months. No doubt what is happening in the Middle East right now could well see that fall continue. So the danger is very real; it is very immediate. As has been pointed out by other speakers, an outbreak of foot and mouth disease alone would completely close off our meat exports to America and we would not be able to regain those exports for at least 12 months after we had cleaned up the outbreak.

If we are to control an outbreak, if it occurs-hopefully we could avoid it in the first place-we have to consider three main factors: first of all, an adequate legislative framework; secondly, a workable plan to contain the outbreak; and, thirdly, current practices in relation to that control. There have been some flaws in that area and I hope that this Bill will lead to the setting up of a council that will rectify these problems. In fact, the legislative framework at a Federal level is primarily concerned with preventing the introduction of disease or anything that may carry that disease. Clearly, the States and the Territories have legislation that is concerned with eradicating disease should an outbreak occur at any time.

Unfortunately, with the present system of quarantine and stock disease legislation we do not have a coordinated or blanket approach to this problem. So it is important for the Commonwealth and the States to have the necessary powers to contain promptly and eradicate an outbreak of any exotic disease or living pest. It is also vital that everyone realise that the consequences of any inadequacies in the preparedness of State and Federal governments will have to be borne by us all, not just by the primary producers. I think that is a point that should be reinforced again and again because it is so easy, particularly for those living in cities, to feel that they are immune from the effects of such an outbreak. We have to remember the enormous impact that an outbreak of an exotic disease would have on our trade. We have to realise that we are talking not just of millions or hundreds of millions of dollars a year but of billions of dollars.

As has been pointed out, model plans aimed at controlling various diseases have been developed by the Commonwealth over the period since 1955. Regrettably, it seems to have taken an awfully long time to get from there to here. Maybe it is fortunate that we have not seen any serious outbreaks in that period. Overall, there have been a number of scares, and I would like to talk about one or two of those because I think they highlight some of the problems we could have. We have had some scares in Australia, including at Portland in my electorate. The likely cost of foot and mouth disease has been highlighted; it could be of the order of $2 billion to $3 billion per annum. I would suggest that, if screw-worm fly were to take hold in Australia, it could cost a similar amount. Of course, the effects would not just be on our livestock industry; they would be widespread throughout some of our native fauna as well.

It is worth recalling that in April last year some dead screw-worm flies were found on a ship in Darwin. While these flies were actually discovered on 4 April they were not sent to Canberra for positive identification until 12 May and that identification took until 18 May. I think that highlights the fact that we have to improve our preparedness; we have to improve our response rate. It took six weeks from the time those flies were found until they were positively identified-far too long if those flies had been only part of a group which had escaped. In another case, on a ship that left Darwin for the Philippines two cattle were found to have died. Those cattle, which were thrown overboard, had wounds that were consistent with screw-worm fly, but no samples of the maggots were taken so it is hard to prove exactly what the wounds were. On another occasion, nine dead screw-worm flies were found on a ship in Portland. Whilst they were dead-certainly for most of the year the climate in southern Australia is not conducive to the spread of screw-worm fly-it is not impossible for unusual climatic conditions to prevail at the time a ship comes into a southern port. On an occasion such as that it is possible to foresee a scenario where screw-worm fly could escape and take hold in Australia. As I have said, if that were to happen the cost to Australian industry would run into billions of dollars.

We are talking about the effects on our major export industries of a disaster of enormous proportions. Accordingly, it is very important that the moves proposed in this legislation are seen to be effective. Industry has been asked to contribute three-quarters of a million dollars, which the Government will match. Whether that is adequate I think should be reviewed regularly, although, as I said at the beginning of my speech, without a positive outbreak it is always difficult to know whether the state of preparedness we believe we have is really sufficient. Nonetheless, it is a serious matter and one that we should continue to address.

The concerns of the National Farmers Federation should be taken on board by the Government-namely, that pet owners, horse owners and deer owners will not be paying anything towards the levy while they will stand to benefit from the work that will be done by the council that will be set up under this legislation. That is something the Government might consider looking at further. The level of funding has to be put in this light: it is not a question of industry picking up the cost of a service that should properly be borne by government. Clearly, while the livestock industry is the immediate beneficiary, Australia as a whole is benefiting by maintaining that exotic disease-free status. As I have said before, the possible effects, not just on the livestock industries but also on Australian native fauna would be dramatic. If such an outbreak were to move into the household pet area this would bring home the problem to people in the cities.

In conclusion, I would like to add my support to this legislation. While I believe it has the one or two shortcomings I have highlighted, I think it is a positive step in the right direction. If we can maintain that exotic disease-free status in Australia we will be doing our livestock industries and our great export industries an enormous favour; we will be maintaining something that is for the benefit of all Australians. As the honourable member for Wakefield pointed out in his concluding remarks, no reassurance is ever sufficient to completely assure the livestock producers of this country that we can maintain that disease-free status. Every day thousands of people and thousands of objects are coming into this country from overseas, any one of which could bring with it the seeds of disaster. We have to be ever vigilant. I sincerely hope that this Bill is a positive step in helping to maintain the position where Australia's livestock producers can take advantage of markets right round the world. If we were to lose that position we would certainly find ourselves very much the poorer and this would affect all Australians, not just our livestock producers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak to the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill and cognate Bills tonight. There is a series of amendments to existing Acts which cover a wide range of livestock, most of which seem to reside in the large electorate of Maranoa, including the wild ones as well as the domesticated ones. That probably includes some humans as well as the animals! I would have liked to have seen the Bill entitled the Exotic Animal Control Bill. What is needed in this country is an attempt by government to wipe out some of the exotic feral animals that are wandering our countryside rather than an attack on the diseases that they might be carrying. I would have thought it more sensible to spend the money and efforts of these people who are going to get together on the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council on looking at a program of attempting to annihilate some of these species.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this is happening in the Northern Territory where the wild buffaloes, which were introduced back in the 1870s, are being brought under control. They are being shot out from helicopters. The Northern Territory and Commonwealth governments are spending a lot of money up there because of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication programs which have been foisted upon us mainly by the United States Government. With those diseases present, it does not particularly want our meat. They are not exotic diseases, but they are quite prevalent. Both the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the primary producers of this country have done an excellent job in bringing these diseases under control. Of course, the annihilation of the buffalo in its wild state is essential. The only animals of that species that will be retained will be behind barbed wire and will at least be controlled to a certain extent. Obviously, a few always escape, which is how these diseases are introduced into this country.

Australia is the biggest island in the world. For many years the Aboriginals migrated with their wild pigs, which came down from New Guinea and established themselves in the Cape York Peninsula area. The Indonesian islands to the north-west are full of foot and mouth disease. It is a miracle that we have not had some of these diseases introduced up to this time. That that has not occurred is only as a result of the vigilance of the quarantine services that have been established. An all-up amount of about $168m per year is spent. Of course, 60 per cent of that is recouped from the livestock and wool industries in Australia to help the taxpayer and the Government keep these diseases under control. Nobody likes being sprayed up and down with some exotic spray when he arrives in Australia from foreign shores. It is probably one of these sprays that escapes into the environment and causes all sorts of supposed problems including blowing holes in the ozone layer. There has always been a hole in the ozone layer. From the way in which some people carry on one would think it had only just arrived. None of us likes being sprayed up and down, but it has a distinct purpose, which is to help kill any foreign insects that might be on the aircraft. Of course, we do not want any of those insects to come to our shores.

It is not just the outbreak of some exotic diseases that is of concern. Some exotic diseases have actually been introduced to help control our feral animals. Probably the most successful was myxomatosis in rabbits. It is an exotic virus that eventually sends rabbits blind, gives them a fever and kills them. The cane toad has also been brought in. It was introduced as an exotic animal to help control beetles and some sort of insect in the cane industry. These things are not always able to be controlled. The cane toad seems to be wandering across northern Australia and will probably be a bigger curse than a plus when it is finished with. The cactoblastis was introduced in my own area from South America in the 1920s and 1930s. The cactus or prickly pear itself was introduced as an exotic plant. There are many species of plants which have been introduced as well as diseases that have to be controlled. The cactus loved our very rich fertile brigalow lands, went berserk and spread very rapidly from the centre of New South Wales right up into northern Queensland. The cactoblastis was introduced by the Department and the researchers who were involved in Queensland. They have managed not to wipe out the cactus but certainly to keep it under control. If the cactoblastis ever died out, the cactus itself would take off and become a pest again.

This new piece of legislation called the Exotic Animals Disease Control Bill 1989 will involve amendments to the Wool Marketing Act, the Dairy Produce Act and the Rural Industries Research Act. In this cognate debate there will also be amendments to the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act, the Egg Industry (Hen Quota) Levy Act, the Laying Chicken Levy Act, the Meat Chicken Levy Act, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act and the Pig Slaughter Levy Act. They are all being amended to include amendments to the levies that are collected from these producers to raise revenue. It is being funded dollar for dollar by the Federal Government. The industry is putting up $750,000 and the Government is putting in the equivalent amount to take it up to $1.5m. The wool industry is putting up about $300,000 of that $750,000, so one can see how important the wool industry continues to be to the nation. It is paying a very large percentage. The percentage which each industry will contribute is worked out in each of the Acts. The livestock industry is contributing 26 per cent, the wool industry about 30 per cent, the pig industry 4 per cent, and so it goes on. The percentage is tied roughly to the gross income of that industry, the percentage of the levy is applied and then the particular levy is collected.

From what I have read, I am not too sure what the council intends to do other than look at means and ways of continuing to help us control the outbreak of diseases. The council to be set up will consist of eight part-time members, two from the National Farmers Federation, a representative from the Australian Agricultural Council, an officer from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and three people with special qualifications. The council will terminate in June 1995. I am not sure why it should terminate then. I would have thought that something like this-I guess it is a sunset clause-ought to continue if it is regarded as useful. I object to the industries continuing to have to contribute so much. It is amazing that some of the exotic diseases around, particularly those associated with humans, including acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) which has been introduced into this country of late, have had an increase of $7m in the Budget. We are now spending up to $60m a year to control the exotic human disease called AIDS but when it comes to controlling livestock exotic diseases and looking after our animals which we depend on so much for our exports of wool and beef, et cetera, the producer has to contribute half.

The same applies to the inspection levies. The industry is currently putting in 60 per cent and the Government 40 per cent. There has been an announcement today that the inspection levies are going up. Since the Budget was announced there has been a trickling out of the increases. These can be called taxation or whatever we like but they are levies. They are in a sense attacks on the industry. There has been an increase of 18 per cent in the levy. It has gone up 18 per cent today. That is running well ahead of the inflation figure, even at 7 1/2 per cent. Inflation was meant to be 4 1/2 per cent last year. It turned out at about 7 per cent, about double what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) thought it would be. He has estimated that in the coming 12 months the inflation rate will be 7 1/2 per cent. We have seen an 18 per cent increase in these sorts of charges.

I point out to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), that I hope that this quango that is being set up will not increase the charges of the inspection people. We have seen a rise from $22 to $26 an hour for the meat inspection services and an increase in the inspectors' salaries of about $6,000 a year. That has been passed on to the meat producer. Our policy is to at least try to reduce that burden a little and go for a 50 per cent recovery. The Labor Party is presently opting for a 60 per cent recovery of the cost associated with that service. It is one of the biggest items. It is running at over $100m per year for our meat inspection services. That is a similar sort of thing. It covers the inspection of meat for diseases that might be in carcasses before they are exported to other parts of the world, particularly to America, which imposed these inspection services on us when we picked up the huge market that became available to us. It is very important for us to spend the sort of money we do to keep our product free of these diseases. At the end of the day, when the markets get tough, it is the quality of our product and the fact that we do not have some of these diseases such as foot and mouth in Australia that enables us to maintain our United States beef market. If ever foot and mouth broke out, overnight we would lose that market completely. Not until we can prove to the purchasers of our products that we have totally eradicated the disease will we be able to trade with them again.

It is important for us to understand that the Fraser Government spent about $350m when in office on the high security quarantine station at Geelong. It was established by the taxpayers of this nation to carry out all sorts of experiments and to breed some of the inoculates that are needed to combat some of these diseases. I still support the concept of not storing the foot and mouth virus in Australia. I think South Africa is the place we have to go to get the inoculant. It is important for constituents and members of the House to understand that in the event of an outbreak of these diseases, the scorched earth policy is the one that will be adopted. Any animal suspected of having such a disease will be shot on sight and buried as quickly as possible. That is extended to cover a radius. One of the jobs of the committee will be to increase the sort of work that is needed to determine how many livestock should be killed. The idea is that it should extend outwards-a bit analogous to the sort of clean-up that happens when an atomic reactor blows up. In the case of disease, everything within sight is buried, animals are killed and as the program extends outwards eventually a stage is reached at which inoculation is started. I guess if it ever happens practically every animal in Australia will have to be inoculated before we can continue to export some of these products.

Bluetongue has always been a problem in our sheep industry. I also mention the screw-worm fly. We now have a fly which comes further and further south. We have mosquitoes which spread exotic types of fevers amongst humans. Some of the members of this House have been wanting the Government to spend more money in that direction. We also have three-day sickness that breaks out amongst cattle, particularly when the climate becomes more humid and we get a higher rainfall. It encourages the spread of these diseases.

I support the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) in the work that he has done since he has been a member of this House to encourage the Government to eradicate more of Australia's feral animals. There is an awful lot of chat about the environment these days. All of a sudden it has become socially acceptable to be a greenie. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as white as he is, has become a born again green. He spends a lot of time on the golf course. Golf course fairways are totally flattened before grass is put in. It is amazing how all of a sudden we become interested in these things.

I guess that some of these exotic wild animals are doing more damage to our environment than most things. We have a huge wild pig population roaming this country. Wild pigs do enormous damage in my electorate, especially on my own property. We trap and poison them with 1080 and blast at them with shotguns. We have a game industry set up; people go out nightly to shoot these animals. At least it is keeping them under control. It is similar to the kangaroo quota that we have to keep our kangaroos under control. The Minister would know that there is an enormous population of wild pigs wandering around. They are great carriers of some of these diseases, particularly brucella. I guess that they would get foot and mouth disease quickly and would carry it around if it ever gets here. We should have a program to exterminate them.

I have a list of animals that I have seen while travelling around the countryside. We have wild pigs, camels, donkeys, cattle, goats, sheep, horses, foxes, rabbits, deer, dogs, cats and rats. There are probably half a dozen other animals we could add to the list. All of these animals that are not native to this country cause enormous problems to the normal livestock which we have introduced. A lot of them have gone wild. The buffalo is not on my list but that animal has caused enormous damage in Kakadu. One of the Labor Party senators said that some of that national park was just clapped out buffalo country. I spent a bit of time there in my younger days tranquillising them. There is no doubt that they did a lot of damage wallowing around and flattening the place generally. But, as I said earlier, they are just about under control.

The Minister and the Government ought to be supporting the honourable member for Eden-Monaro in getting a feral animal control program under way. I know there have been some experiments and some trials have been run. There is a small levy which the councils pay but it is not much. We should be making a greater effort to exterminate some of these animals. The camels are being captured and exported to Saudi Arabia. There is some use in that regard. There are hundreds of them wandering the inland deserts. There are thousands of donkeys in Australia, particularly in the Kimberley area. There are wild cattle everywhere. They are going to be a problem if foot and mouth disease or one of the other exotic diseases breaks out. A lot of them have been brought under control by the brucella program. Those that cannot be mustered have been shot from helicopters or from horseback. There are heaps of goats. Some of them have been crossed with exotic mohair imports and all of a sudden we have some sort of stud goats. But most of the goats in Australia which are now quite popular at the shows have come straight out of the back blocks around Charleville and elsewhere. There are still a lot of wild goats around. It is amazing how many wild sheep one sees when one travels around, the big woolly things running in the scrub. There are many brumbies and they have to be shot. The animal liberationists do not like the sight of this but the brumbies have to be kept under control. Foxes and rabbits seem to be increasing.

I hope that this new committee will do something for us. The Budget was brought down last night. It is a pity that some of the surplus of $9 billion could not go towards this sort of thing. It could have been better spent there than on some of the programs the Government has in place. We are not in government; we are in opposition. We are supporting the legislation tonight. I have much pleasure in doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have been in the House and have heard the contributions of the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) and the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). They have all made substantial points. I am very happy that the Opposition supports the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill and the amendments that I intend to move to it when we go into the committee stage. The honourable member for Maranoa put a lot of emphasis on feral animal control, and the points he made are true enough. We are focusing attention on buffaloes as a feral population because of a disease affecting them. We have other programs under way in some other feral populations, particularly pigs.

SPEECH.PARA: Those programs are only being trialed and reference to those programs was originally associated with the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). He also made reference to the rabbit population. We are looking at a new disease that has decimated the rabbit population in Italy and Spain: namely, viral haemorhagic tracheo-pneumonia. I think it is the disease that I currently have! We spend about $10.7m a year in other programs but mainly the Australian Animal Health Laboratory (AAHL) screw-worm fly program. There is also foot and mouth vaccine in storage in Britain and a few other similar programs.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd), in the most comprehensive contribution to the debate, made a general criticism of the Government's policy and administration with respect to the quarantine and exotic disease preparedness response area. He made reference to the acceptable risk criteria and to a National Farmers Federation letter about industry levy questions, particularly with the owners of horses and deer being non-contributors. He said that he hoped the increased funding would not be followed by cuts in other areas. I refer honourable members back to my second reading speech, which makes it plain enough. If I could get horses and deer into levy programs it would be pretty good. But we just do not have the levy base or the organisation to do so. The reason we are going down the path we are is that we already have Bills in place for the collection of levies from the industries in question. We have a levy base which actually enables us to collect levies.

I would like to explain in general terms what we are doing in response to the questions raised by the Deputy Leader of the National Party. The initiative is basically an honest attempt to supplement and augment existing expenditure programs in the exotic disease preparedness and response programs and to broaden the range of policy advice available to government. We were already spending about $700,000 to $750,000 per year. This initiative came from the industry development review I conducted in May 1988, which recommended that we should not only upgrade expenditure in this area but also involve industry more. That flowed from our experience with the introduction into AAHL of various diseases in relation to which there is a need to consult industry and to accept industry advice. Our action has been accepted by the National Farmers Federation and the relevant affiliates with whom we consulted quite comprehensively during the preparation of these Bills.

The Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill will not allow the Government to supplant funding of established programs with new industry levy receipts. It is not true to say that benefits will flow equally to all livestock industries, including those that are not making a levy contribution. Discretionary powers exist in the Bill to tailor new expenditure programs in a way which will stream direct benefits exclusively to participating levy payers.

As I have already said, the honourable member for Murray made reference to the acceptable risk approval criteria for introducing new livestock genotypes. The alternative to acceptable risk-that is a pretty tough criterion-is zero risk. But that would simply preclude Australia from the ability to upgrade the livestock genetic base to keep up with overseas competitors. The brahmin herd in this country started with 28 head. With the facility that we now have in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and other facilities for the introduction of other genotypes, we believe that the acceptable risk criteria, if very tightly and scientifically applied, enable us to introduce new genetic material. I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
