SPEECH.PARA: The second stage, with which we are currently concerned, will remedy many of the deficiencies that we have seen associated with stage one and will particularly overcome, at least in large part, some of the delays that I know have concerned the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), who has drawn my attention to some of those problems in the past.

I do not want to respond to the various contributions that were made in this debate; we can deal with specific questions in the committee stage. But Senator Walters drew one important issue to the attention of a Opposition spokesperson tonight, and that was the question of the movement from monthly to fortnightly collections. I think that the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) will recognise that we will need overall consistency. We and the agency will certainly consider whether we need to move from monthly to fortnightly collections and whether there are positive advantages in that move but we will need to ensure that we can actually do it without creating more problems than we solve. If it is feasible I am sure that we would like to go in the direction that Senator Walters has suggested to the honourable member for Sturt.

That is really the only issue raised in the second reading debate to which I particularly want to respond, except to reiterate that an enormous amount of work has gone into the scheme up to this particular point. I appreciate the efforts of honourable members, advisers and people in the gallery tonight who have a history of association with the scheme, which potentially could have been more controversial than it has been. It has been managed at every stage so far with a great deal of sensitivity on the part of everyone concerned. I appreciate particularly the acknowledgment by the honourable member for Sturt of cooperation from my office. I hope that people feel that they have been able to get on top of the issues involved. It is a fine piece of legislation, if I might say so, and is certainly a credit to those who have been responsible for getting it to this stage. I hope that, without too much acrimony in the committee stage, we can move the legislation on to the Senate and, by 1 October, put the new scheme into operation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 4-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 5 (Interpretation-definitions).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 5, page 3, line 10, omit the definition of ``child support'', substitute the following definitions:
`` `child support' means financial support under this Act, including financial support under this Act by way of lump sum payment or by way of transfer or settlement of property;
`child support agreement' has the meaning given by section 63b;''.
(2) Clause 5, page 3, lines 16 to 18, omit the definition of ``child support percentage'', substitute the following definitions:
`` `child support percentage' has the meaning given by section 34 (as modified in relation to certain cases by paragraphs 35 (e) and 51 (b) and (c));
`child support terminating event' has the meaning given by section 11a;''.
(3) Clause 5, page 3, lines 24 to 28, omit the definitions of ``custodian entitled to child support'' and ``de facto spouse'', substitute the following definitions:
`` `court exercising jurisdiction under this Act' does not include a court exercising jurisdiction in proceedings under paragraph 63 (a);
`court having jurisdiction under this Act' does not include a court that has jurisdiction under this Act only in relation to the recovery of amounts of child support;

``custodian entitled to child support' has the meaning given by section 29 or, in relation to a case in which the liability to pay the child support concerned arose because of the acceptance by the Registrar of a child support agreement, section 63p;''.
(4) Clause 5, page 3, line 31, after ``Part 2'' insert (Children who may be covered by Act)''.

When the then Acting Minister for Social Security, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), introduced this Bill he indicated that the Government would be moving certain amendments. Firstly, a new part 1a would restate the availability of the counselling facilities of the Family Court or a Family Court of a State to parties involved in the administrative assessment process. Secondly, the new part 4a would provide for registration and enforcement of agreements between liable parents and custodians covered by the Bill. The private agreements regime provided for in amendments in relation to child support matters would mirror the effect of the current regime under section 86 of the Family Law Act. An agreement on child support matters in writing and signed by both parents could be registered with the Child Support Agency. Registration would make provisions of the agreement enforceable and variable as if they were provisions of consent orders of a court. Thirdly, a new division 4a and part 5 would provide that the courts could substitute child support informs other than periodic amounts. The courts would be able to order that child support assessment by the Registrar be reduced because of support provided in other forms. The division would also ensure that the custodian who is in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit is always entitled to apply to the Registrar to receive at least 75 per cent of his or her assessed child support by way of periodic amounts.

Fourthly, the amendments would enable the assessment process to take account of the changed circumstances of the parties such as changes in income or care arrangements for children. Fifthly, the secrecy provision would balance the need to protect the confidentiality of tax information and other information necessarily obtained in the administration of the scheme as it relates to each parent, with the need for all parties to be aware of the matters taken into account by the Child Support Agency in making an assessment. Sixthly, there are consequential amendments to the Child Support Act 1988, the Family Law Act 1975, the Social Security Act 1947 and the Taxation Administration Act 1953. Seventhly, there are amendments relating to the details of how courts exercising jurisdiction under the Bill would reach a decision to make an order. Eighthly, there are minor technical amendments. The amendments will complete the legislative package to implement stage two of the child support scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 8, after clause 19 insert the following new clause:
Children declared deemed eligible children are eligible children
``19a. A child declared, by a court, to be deemed to be an eligible child under section 31a is, for the purposes of this Act, an eligible child.''.

In my speech during the second reading debate I indicated that it was my personal view that clause 19 should be amended in a way that would ensure that a child is made an eligible child in these circumstances. I would have liked to have added clause 19a, which simply states:
``19a. Where
(a) a person, on the commencing day, is in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit-
a definition we have now inserted in the legislation-
with respect to a child; and
(b) the child would not, apart from this section, be an eligible child;
such child is, for the purposes of this Act, deemed to be an eligible child.''.

That would have meant that all children whose parents were receiving supporting benefits would be entitled to an assessment under the formula that this legislation contains. However, the amendment I am proposing on behalf of the Opposition is a variant on that. It states:
``19a. A child declared, by a court, to be deemed to be an eligible child under section 31a is, for the purposes of this Act, an eligible child.''.
Later, I will propose that we add new clause 31a. The purpose of new clause 31a would be to add the words:
``31a. Where:
(a) a person, on the commencing day, is in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit with respect to a child; and
(b) the child would not, apart from this section, be an eligible child;
application may be made to a court, having or exercising jurisdiction under section 64, for the making of a decree that the child is, for the purposes of this Act, deemed to be an eligible child.''.
Another clause would then have to be added to that:
``31b. Where a court makes a decree under section 31a that a child is deemed to be an eligible child, the provisions of this Act apply to the child as if he or she were an eligible child.''.

It has been argued that my personally preferred option was retrospective. The amendments I am proposing on behalf of the Opposition put the matter for determination into the hands of the court. They enable every supporting beneficiary to apply to the court to have his or her children declared to be eligible children and the assessment maintenance then to be determined. In that sense, all it does is say to the court, `You can, on the application of the supporting parent, the custodial parent, make an order and declare the child to be an eligible child'. It is another way of making a maintenance order that says the maintenance that shall be payable will be lifted to the realistic level set by the formula. It becomes indexed because it is adjusted year by year.

I do not agree with those who argue that my personally preferred option was retrospective. It did not ever propose the retrospective application of the formula; it proposed that the formula be applied from a prospective date. It is argued that the retrospective application-I said I do not believe it is that-would create an injustice. There is no suggestion that maintenance payable under a formula should be paid in respect of past maintenance collected and that past maintenance should be collected under the formula.

It is argued that there are closely intertwined maintenance and property orders in respect of many of these supporting parents. If there are, let the courts vary the rate of maintenance payable in the light of these arrangements. That would have been appropriate if my amendment were the one I was currently proposing, but I am proposing the Opposition's amendment and the courts will be given the opportunity to determine whether there are closely intertwined arrangements. If there are, they do not have to declare the children eligible children.

It has been argued that for many thousands arrangements have been made which involve an attempt to pay out the maintenance arrangements in lump sum form. If that is the case, let the court examine the circumstances and the history and say that that is so. But if that is not so, why not do justice to children who are in poverty and to taxpayers who are overburdened by ensuring that non-custodial parents in those circumstances pay at a level of maintenance that is regarded by the Fogarty Child Support Consultative Group as a level which is equitable for separated and intact families.

It is argued that people will be upset because of the settled expectations and arrangements. That is a very novel suggestion. There were many age pensioners receiving means test free pensions even though they had substantial assets whose settled expectations were upset by this Government. We are suggesting that we perhaps upset the settled expectations of a few people who are failing to support their children. I have supported the Minister's legislation on this issue very positively. I cannot understand why he has turned a blind eye to these very poor families when it is clear that the fathers of these children can afford, under formula arrangements, to pay the maintenance.

In the light of the amendment I have moved, I hope that the Minister will reconsider the proposal. If it is appropriate to distinguish between custodial parents who have a right to apply for a maintenance order for the first time or a right to apply for a variation of a maintenance order and those who have arrangements paid out in lump sum form, let us do that.

Further, liable parents will criticise the proposal and claim it is unfair. But the mothers who are supporting the children will not criticise this Parliament for doing justice to them, their children and taxpayers, especially those in intact families who are disadvantaged in the way I described in my speech during the second reading debate by the withdrawal mechanisms in respect of the supporting parent. They will not be upset. They will see the whole thing as bringing some fairness into the overall system.

The Department of Social Security administers a requirement that applicants for the sole parent pension take reasonable action to claim maintenance. This legislation is simplifying that procedure, giving the Department the opportunity to say to supporting parents, `You should apply to the court for your children to be declared eligible children'. Many people would make that application where there are circumstances that have brought about other arrangements that did not justify such an application or where proper advice was not given to the parents. Many thousands of supporting parents and many more thousands of children would benefit as a consequence of the proper application of the formula in these cases. If the Department of Social Security is not going to do that, what will its attitude be to the maintenance level being fixed by the court?

As a consequence of this Parliament's support of this legislation I hope that the courts will now automatically, either on review or ab initio in respect of families that are not now caught under the Government's proposals, use the formula maintenance as the starting point upon which they should base their maintenance orders, for Parliament has determined that the amounts under the formula are regarded as appropriate in the light of expert advice that has been given. Parliaments have determined that non-custodial parents with the income that they have can afford the level of maintenance that is required under the formula. I therefore hope that this Parliament can do justice not only to children whose parents separate after 1 October but also to those children whose parents separated before.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the thrust of what the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) is suggesting is that one can have a circumstance where a child is deemed by a court to be declared an eligible child under section 31a. He is effectively introducing the possibility of retrospectivity or applying the use of the formula to a whole class of cases that normally would not otherwise be included within the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I will have to explain pretty clearly and firmly to the honourable member for Sturt that from the very beginning with respect to child support we have been very conscious of the fact that there are potential benefits to custodial parents and to their children in allowing the possibility that the honourable member has in mind, but at the same time one introduces, at least from the point of view of non-custodial parents, the possibility of not only perceived retrospectivity but also a sense of some injustice that will have to be worked out in probably thousands of individual cases in the terms of the way that the previous rules have operated under the Family Court of Australia. It just seems to me to be quite unrealistic. The whole scheme would never have reached the point it has at the moment if we had allowed that possibility. The reason that what potentially could have been a very controversial scheme has been non-controversial is that we made it very clear right from the start that our approach would be a prospective rather than a retrospective one-that is, that the formula would not apply; that even though superficially it may seem that some injustices might be exercised, we would not allow the court to apply or the Agency to operate in such a way that it could be said that we were introducing retrospectivity by our approach.

That is because under the previous regime there were a raft of arrangements that could be entered into to deal with the various ways in which people arrived at maintenance either in cash or in kind, a myriad of arrangements that may have been acceptable to courts at particular times and, indeed, might be varied by courts, but which I do not think should be varied in terms of the principles of this legislation as we move to an administrative system.

With the consent and the support of the Opposition, I think, we are making a very radical change. We are taking something out of a court-certainly allowing appeal back to the court in a range of circumstances-and essentially moving to an administrative system that treats a very high proportion of cases as standard cases dealt with in terms of an administrative formula approach where individual circumstances are not of interest to the Agency or of particular interest to the court. If we went the way that the honourable member for Sturt is suggesting, I think that he would be taking us down a track that could lead to an attempt to unscramble those previous arrangements and, indeed, could threaten what has essentially been relatively non-controversial legislation and a system which in the future will mean a revolutionary change in the responsibilities of custodial parents. On behalf of the Government, I indicate that I will not be supporting either this particular proposed clause or the consequential amendments that have been foreshadowed by the honourable member for Sturt.

That the amendment (Mr Wilson's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 29, page 11, lines 34-36, omit paragraph (c), substitute the following paragraph:
``(c) child support is payable for the child by the liable parent to the custodian entitled to child support on and from:

(i) if the application was made to the Registrar within 28 days after the earliest day or the most recent earliest day, as the case requires, on which an application for administrative assessment of child support could properly be made by the custodian entitled to child support seeking payment of child support for the child from the liable parent-that earliest day; or

(ii) in any other case-the 28th day before the day on which the application was made to the Registrar or such later day as may be accepted by the Registrar, not being a day later than the day on which the application was made to the Registrar; and''.

Briefly, I just want to outline the amendment, which I have moved on behalf of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) in light of his absence. It picks up words similar to those contained in the Government's amendments to paragraphs 29 (c) and (d) but it adds a subparagraph (ii). Subparagraph (i) states that, where a spouse is separated and within one month of the separation the custodial parent makes application for administrative assessment of maintenance, the maintenance so assessed is to be backdated to the date of separation. At a maximum, it can be backdated 28 days, but if that parent does not make the application until the twenty-ninth day there is no backdating of the administratively assessed maintenance that becomes payable.

We in the Opposition think that is a little unfair, for a number of reasons. Firstly, it means that those people are disadvantaged by up to one month's maintenance. We think it is unfair because there are many circumstances when separations occur where, for at least a month and sometimes much longer, there is the hope, an expectation, a dream of the possibility of a family reunion, and there is concern that the very act of taking the step of asking for administrative assessment will be that final seal, that final sign that the spouse, with the children in her custody, acknowledges that the marriage has broken down. We think it is unfair and unfortunate that, if people apply within 28 days, the maintenance is backdated but, if they apply after 28 days, they get payment from the date of application. We would like a situation where, whenever an application is made, it can be backdated 28 days or to the date of separation, whichever is the lesser of two periods. We think that would not then put pressure on some families where there is that hope of those families reuniting.

We ask the Government to give serious consideration to accepting our amendment. It does not then make any substantial difference to a family that is separated if an application is made within 28 days or is made some time in the future. It is argued that there is a problem about determining what maintenance was paid in the intervening period. If that is a reason against our proposed new clause it would also be a reason against the Government's clause. Surely some administrative procedure-or some court procedure if need be-could be considered to bring into account any maintenance that may have been paid either during the first months of separation or a month preceding the date upon which the application was made. We therefore urge the Government to accept our amendment.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Pilgrimage to Gallipoli-Forestry Industry-Kixotol-Tractor Manufacturing-Restitution Payments-Infantry Combat Badge-Furniture Manufacturing-Metro Meats Piggery

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Howe) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As this is the second day of sitting after the winter recess I am sure that some colleagues wish to speak in the adjournment debate. It has arrived five minutes early and I will afford them that opportunity by addressing the House on this occasion in relation to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs. I have always adopted a reasonably fair-minded approach to the portfolio of veterans' affairs by accurately representing to the House, to the Parliament and to the veterans community across Australia-I seem to have visited so many veterans during the winter recess-a fair and proper approach to fighting the battle to ensure that veterans and war widows get a fair go.

SPEECH.PARA: In that context, I support the Government's initiative to provide for a pilgrimage to Gallipoli on the occasion of the seventy-fifth anniversary of Gallipoli, on 25 April 1990. That project will now cost some $800,000 plus, as revealed in the Budget Papers last night. That seventy-fifth anniversary of Gallipoli will indeed be a very special occasion for this nation and should be properly commemorated. For that reason, at this early stage of the Budget session, I signify to the House the Opposition's support for the pilgrimage to Gallipoli next year.

The logistics associated with that pilgrimage will not be easy. They involve huge amounts of resources, including a Royal Australian Air Force Boeing 707 as well as medical resources while travelling overseas, while in Turkey and upon return. I understand that the Royal Australian Navy will be sending a ship to Gallipoli to stand off Anzac Cove as part of the seventy-fifth anniversary. I say again that I believe there is bipartisan support for the Gallipoli pilgrimage-a pilgrimage that I hope will go smoothly and successfully, involving, as it does, some very elderly people who served this nation well in World War I.

I forewarn the House that I think there will be some difficulties in reducing the list of applicants to the number which can be catered for in the Boeing 707. My understanding is that there has been a huge number of applicants. Whilst the original statement from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) indicated that priority would be given to Gallipoli veterans-in fact, World War I veterans were eligible whether they were at Gallipoli or not-and that there would be space for some war widows as well as some schoolchildren, and I support that concept, I understand that there have been over 80 applicants from Gallipoli veterans alone, quite apart from any other category of World War I veteran.

I think this nation and New Zealand sometimes need to be reminded that we owe much of our national identity to events that occurred at Gallipoli on 25 April 1915. In a sense, in commemorating the seventy-fifth anniversary we are reaffirming our national identity and, at the same time, affording a unique circumstance to see just one more time some of the original Anzacs, some of the original soldiers, sailors and airmen who fought at Gallipoli, stand on that hallowed beach in Turkey as part of Anzac Day 1990-the seventy-fifth anniversary.

I place on record in this House on this second day of the Budget session that the Opposition supports the Government's initiative. I wish the project well. It will not be easy logistically. I hope that it will not be utilised for campaign purposes by any of the parliamentarians at various levels of seniority who will be participating, and I hope that it will clearly reaffirm the national identities of Australia and New Zealand. I pay tribute to the soldiers, sailors and airmen involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this adjournment debate to inform honourable members of my impression of the damage caused by logging and clear-felling to the southern rainforest area in New South Wales. In February this year I travelled through the area following a visit made by my colleagues the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) and Senators Bruce Childs and Bryant Burns. The devastation caused by the woodchipping is appalling. The area looks like a moonscape or the site of an atomic bomb test. Travelling through it is an eerie experience and one can sense that the decimation is unnatural and wrong. Such destruction should not be allowed to take place. One cannot imagine the visual pollution. The devastation that has been caused by woodchipping is horrible. It comes as no surprise to me that there is a strong and growing opposition in the region to the granting of further woodchipping export licences to Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd, which is seeking permission to extend its woodchipping into environmentally sensitive natural forest.

SPEECH.PARA: I back the stand of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) that Tantawangalo, Coolangubra and Egan Peaks be exempted from logging. Many farmers in the Tantawangalo catchment area are concerned that logging will seriously affect local water supplies and that the initial clearing of forest will lead to soil erosion and the silting up of rivers, creeks and dams. The regrowth that follows will cause water levels in the area to fall. This same regrowth is also a serious bushfire hazard. Clear-felling also ruins the habitat of local wildlife. The Egan Peaks area, which contains a magnificent eucalyptus forest, providing a home to numerous threatened species of flora and fauna, would be destroyed by the proposed logging.

When will governments possess the courage and intelligence to stand up to the woodchipping lobby, which wants to ruin our environment for their profits? I welcome the announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of the planting of millions of trees. The way to go about it is to replant and harvest trees and plantations and not to clear-fell our forest. The woodchippers pillage our natural heritage for only minor economic gain to Australia. In 1986-87 woodchips accounted for only 0.85 per cent of total merchandise exported. Yet we endure the destruction of environmentally sensitive areas and ruin a potential goldmine for the tourist industry.

I remind honourable members that the amount of forests in Australia has almost halved since 1788. The destruction of native forests must cease. I am not a dogmatic greenie who is against all development, but clear-felling is nothing short of environmental vandalism. We should utilise our scientific knowledge to enable us to harvest and maintain our forests at the same time. Until this is done, we should realise that woodchipping exports cannot continue to expand at the expense of our native forests. Alternatives to the logging of native forests such as the planting of cleared crown land should be seriously investigated. One should take account of the Prime Minister's recent announcement on the environment in which he proposed the planting of new forests and so on. That is the solution. It is not only a problem of a few people losing their jobs. It is also a question of how many jobs are going to be lost in the tourist industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the House the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott) had the good sense to ask the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) a question relating to a very important industry in South Australia known as Wye Industries Limited and the product that it has developed called Kixotol, which is the reverse of low toxic. I congratulate the honourable member for Hindmarsh on leading this charge to help retain an industry in Adelaide. I have certainly been heavily involved in several areas of South Australia. In this context, I mention bromine, a product of the harvesting and extraction of salt, which can be developed in Dry Creek, Lochiel or Whyalla.

SPEECH.PARA: Kixotol has some very important benefits. It is, to the best standards possible, dioxin free and is used in the blowing of polyurethanes. In the past, chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), the most dangerous of all chemicals, the trade name of which is Freon, have been used for this purpose. Now, polyurethanes are blown with CO2. Kixotol is a fire retardant chemical with amazing properties. It is used for the foam cladding that goes around refrigerators and for the foam on the dashboards of cars. Certainly, in terms of the legislation that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) is trying to develop and put together, this product has important fire retardant ramifications for soft goods and foam manufacturing industries. Its implication is being picked up all around Australia and the world.

Mr Mark Weston and Mr Alan Truscott have invested several million of their own dollars. There is a possibility that multinational companies such as Dutch Shell and Roche Marg are looking to buy this company, which wants to remain in South Australia and manufacture in Adelaide. It has got forward orders. In fact, I believe that a deal is being closed today that will significantly enhance its sales. We have turned our back on the black box flight recorder, the marvellous work done by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the wet system of colour photocopying, the heart pacer which was invented in Australia, the Interscan airport radar system, and Mr Ralph Sarich's orbital engine, which has gone to the United States to be developed.

If Kixotol is used in polyurethane and hard foams, over 1,200 tonnes of CFCs will be taken out of the ozone layer straight-away. So it has important ramifications for the environment. This is a value added industry. This product is not in the research and development stage. Austrade and State development agencies need to look at some of the questions involved. The South Australian Government has preached locally that it has given a lot in terms of research. In fact, the Minister for State Development in South Australia, Mr Lynn Arnold, gave the company, which is looking for $4m, a quarter of an hour of his time. As yet, the open letters written by Mr Scott and me to the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, have yet to be answered. That is most disappointing.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you write them?

—The honourable member wants to know when we wrote them. This letter was dated over four weeks ago. I support what Wye Industries is trying to do. This company is attempting to bring some credibility and recognition to Australia, rather than allowing an industry go to overseas interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was actually looking forward to going home early tonight. I was rather hoping that there would not be an adjournment debate. However, I find myself filled with a form of missionary zeal. I rise to debunk some of the nonsense spoken by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). I was also confronted with some gobbledegook from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt). It is the good fortune of the honourable member for Adelaide that the honourable member for Hotham offended me first.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up what the honourable member for Hotham said about the utilisation of our scientific skills. I think this is a very wise thing to do; it is very sensible. It is quite contrary to what the honourable member for Hotham was suggesting. He gave us a tirade against woodchipping. The tragedy is that the same gentleman would also be against pulping. On that formula there is no future. We were given the nonsense about the tourist industry replacing jobs. The tourist industry provides jobs for women and young people in the main. They are part time jobs and low paid jobs. It does not provide work for blue collar workers whose jobs in the timber industry have been lost.

We are confronted with another phenomenon-the perfidy of the conservation movement. I draw the attention of the House to a paper published by Dr Rolf Gerritson of the Australian National University. It is the first time I have seen an academic actually analyse the nature of the greenie movement. We have in Australia a very slothful media who tend to give the greenies the high moral ground because, after all, all they want to do is look after the environment. Nothing could be further from the truth. Their agenda is about naked power. They utilise people. In Tasmania we find that they promote tourism against the timber industry. Once having won the battle and got rid of the timber industry, they turn on the tourist industry and ban the construction of hotels. The reality is that in some cases tourism can be far more environmentally damaging than the well managed timber industry.

We continue to get this furphy that since the settlement of Australia the area of forest land has been reduced dramatically. Of course, that is true. Forest areas have been reduced dramatically, but they have not been reduced by forestry; they have been reduced by farming. Forestry has not been responsible for the reduction of forest areas; it has been farming, as it has been farming which has been mainly responsible for the rise in salinity. We are now recognising that, and I think the farming community is acting very responsibly in addressing the problem.

We talk about utilising our scientific skills, but we ought to utilise the skills of the people trained in this industry. I draw the attention of the House to the greatest dry sclerophyll forest in Australia. Many people may not know where it is, but it is by far the biggest forest of this type. It is far bigger than anything in Tasmania and it is in my electorate, in the goldfields. From this forest for over 40 years timber was cut at the rate of half a million tonnes a year, a rate which exceeded the felling rate in the great forests of the south-west of Western Australia. In those days no attempt was made at regeneration, yet that country has regenerated magnificently by accident. There are some areas where because of drought or fire or perhaps because it was taken over by bluebush it did not regenerate, but in the main it has regenerated very well indeed. Today it is still the biggest forest of this type in the whole of this nation. That is a consequence of logging. In those days wood was ripped out at an unprecedented rate. It was plundered to support the mines; it was burnt in the boilers; it was used for structure in the mines. Well over 10,000 tonnes a day-half a million tonnes a year-was felled, a rate which exceeds that of the south-west forests.

These are the things that ought to be recognised by people who come into this House and debate environmental issues without any rationality or sense. Not only do we do our own intellects a grave disservice; we also do the environment a very grave disservice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to the speech by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and I commend him on what he was saying. It is a pity that some of his colleagues do not listen to him. Tonight I want to speak about something Senator Button had to say today in answer to a question from my colleague Senator MacGibbon, who asked about the Government's treatment of Waltanna Tractors, a tractor manufacturer in my electorate. I have raised this issue in the House before and I have certainly raised it with Senator Button, something which he acknowledges. The Government has failed to understand what its tariff policy is doing to small manufacturers and, in particular, what has happened to this manufacturer since the Government removed the bounty that was provided to assist Australian tractor manufacturers, not to give them an advantage but to allow them to compete with imports.
—A fair go.

—Just to give them a fair go, as my colleague points out. The Government has now created the ludicrous situation where a manufacturer of tractors in Australia-a manufacturer who has about 65 per cent Australian content in his tractors-has to pay duty on components he has to import because they are not available in Australia. Yet someone who wishes to import a similar tractor fully assembled pays no duty whatsoever. In other words, the Australian manufacturer is penalised for manufacturing in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with great regret that I say that Senator Button fails to understand a very simple and fundamental fact about a small manufacturer's job. He has suggested that this manufacturer ought to apply for commercial tariff concessions. In fact, he has done that on one of the major components he is forced to import because it is not available in Australia. The fact is that if Senator Button thought about how long it takes for someone to go through the process of getting a tariff concession he would realise that that person would go broke long before he got around to getting the concession. In order to do it he has to go around to every person in Australia who might be able to manufacture the component and get him to sign a customs form, a declaration, saying that he cannot make it. Having gone back to the Customs people, he is then told to check with anyone else who might be able to make it. Here we have someone in a small business who is trying to get on with the job of manufacturing something and who is told that if he wants an even chance, a fair go, in comparison to others he has to spend his life running around Australia looking for a manufacturer who might be able to make these things and ask whether or not that manufacturer is prepared to sign a statement saying either that he cannot make it or that he will consider making it. This is just in the land of Noddy.

Instead of Senator Button criticising my colleague in the Senate, he should take a long hard look at what his policies are doing to small manufacturers. There are many others in a similar boat who are just trying to have a go-to take up the challenge of improving manufacturing in Australia. Unfortunately, this manufacturer, whom I know quite well and who is a very genuine person, a decent and committed person, has been faced with a choice of either trying to compete on an unfair basis with a fully imported tractor or going to Canada, where he has been offered all sorts of concessions. Going to Canada is something that I am sure he would not do lightly, having lived in the Hamilton district all his life. Not only would he be able to manufacture those same tractors in Canada, with all sorts of incentives from the Canadian Government, but having done that he would be able to send those tractors back to Australia completely duty free.

I put it to all honourable members that the Government's manufacturing policy is a farce when someone is faced with that choice. Where is this Government when it says that it wants to encourage manufacturing in Australia? The fact is that we have an example here of a small manufacturer who has been totally snowed by government regulation and by unfair duties on those parts for his tractors that he cannot get made in Australia and which he has to import from overseas, while at the same time a fully imported tractor attracts no duty whatsoever. I call upon the Government to have a long hard look at what it is on about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise a matter which affects a constituent in my electorate, a person who was a victim of Nazi persecution during the Second World War. Madam Speaker, I do not know whether you had a chance to see any of the series War and Remembrance, which was shown in recent months on the Channel 10 network. While it might have had some elements which were intended to appeal to a mass audience, it did not hide from the fact that the Holocaust occurred during the Nazi years. It sought to portray to the wider community the impact of those horrible years on people of Jewish background. It was nowhere near as good as that excellent, very long film called Shoah which was shown on Special Broadcasting Service television some time last year and which portrayed in very graphic detail what happened during that horrible time.

SPEECH.PARA: My constituent-a Mr Jacob Swaab-was a citizen of the Netherlands. He receives from the Government of the Netherlands what I understand is called a restitution payment in compensation for the persecution which he suffered during the Nazi occupation. Under the current law, if a person receives a restitution payment from the Federal Republic of Germany that payment is exempt from the social security incomes test. That is the result of an amendment to the Social Security Act which this Government introduced in May 1988. I believe that that occurred as a result of urging by people such as Walter Lippmann from the Federation of Jewish Welfare Societies. At that time I am sure all members of the House congratulated the Government on taking out of the incomes test restitution payments from the Federal Republic of Germany.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.

—I am pleased that that has the support of the honourable member for Parramatta. I believe that there is an anomaly with former citizens of the Netherlands and Austria because a number of people who are now living in Australia receive restitution payments from the Netherlands and Austrian governments. Unfortunately, the Department of Social Security, under the law as it now stands, must take that income into account under the incomes test for pension purposes. At least under the Income Tax Assessment Act that payment is not taxable and the Australian Taxation Office is doing the right thing in not counting it as income which has to be assessed for income tax. But unfortunately it is being used to reduce people's pensions because it is being classified as assessable income. That is something I hope the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and the Government can address at the earliest opportunity. I hope that a proposal to extend the exemption for restitution payments to payments received from the Dutch and Austrian governments would have the support of all honourable members. I know that my constituent, Mr Swaab, would be very grateful if consideration could be given to this matter in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: In the one or two minutes that are left to me tonight I wish to raise a second matter which is of concern to local constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —There must be an election coming.
—I am disappointed that the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), would put such a cynical view on something which I have sought to raise in--
—A constructive way.

—I agree, in a constructive way. The second matter which I wish to raise affects a veteran and might be of some interest to the shadow Minister. There are a number of Australians who served in Vietnam before 1971 and who should be entitled to receive the Infantry Combat Badge. Unfortunately, only those who served after 29 July 1970 are entitled to receive that Badge. I believe that Australians who served in Vietnam before that period should be entitled to receive it. Most of these people probably served longer than those Vietnam veterans who are entitled to wear the Badge. This is an anomaly which I hope the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) can address at the earliest opportunity, because I know that there are a lot of Vietnam veterans in my electorate who think this is an anomaly which can be fixed quite easily if the Government is prepared to attack it head on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to preface my remarks in the adjournment debate tonight by following the example of the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) and complimenting the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) on the comments he made in response to the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). I understand some of the missionary zeal which prompted him to get to his feet to talk about the future of the forestry industry and the concern he feels at the present indulgence that is being given to to people loosely called `greenies'.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise because in this House just prior to the winter recess I raised with the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories the question of what was to be done by the Government to compensate those furniture manufacturers who were dependent on hardwoods, particularly Australian quality hardwoods, for the manufacture of quality furniture and those who were dependent also on the importation of hardwoods for the manufacture of quality furniture. I have a quality furniture manufacturer in my electorate, located at Angaston. He trades under the name of Ruefenacht Furniture. He finds that the opportunity he had to produce furniture which is unique in Australian terms has now gone as a result of the raw material no longer being available to him. My question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), through the Minister representing him in this chamber, related to what he proposed to do to offer some sort of compensation to those who, like Mr Ruefenacht, quite innocently found themselves caught--
Mr John Brown interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Parramatta for the timely interjection.
—I am only here to help.
—The Chair does not thank the honourable member for Parramatta.

—Frankly, the question concerned what the Government proposed to do to allow people like Mr Ruefenacht to be compensated for having innocently lost what was previously a growth industry. I have seen some of Mr Ruefenacht's furniture. It is unique. It is obvious that it cannot be manufactured out of anything other than quality hardwood. As I indicated to the House, I am still awaiting a reply from the Minister on this question.

SPEECH.PARA: I said, Madam Speaker, that I only wished to preface my comments with those remarks. In fact the presence tonight of the honourable member for Parramatta, order of the day No. 3-the Exotic Animal Disease Control Bill-and a comment made by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) about the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) 12 months ago when he promised to bring home the bacon have prompted me to rise and bring to the attention of the House a concern I have in my electorate as a result of a proposal by Metro Meats in South Australia to build at Two Wells, just north of Adelaide, what it hopes will be a super piggery. I know that the honourable member for Parramatta would understand some of the difficulties that Metro Meats faces in its endeavour to build a super piggery and the intention it has of producing what it hopes will be super pigs.

Metro Meats has a proposal to build a piggery that will house 1,200 sows at Lower Light, adjacent to Two Wells, just 40 kilometres north of Adelaide. It has chosen the site not because it simply wishes to have a large piggery-after all, a 1,200 sow piggery will very likely produce between 12,000 and 17,000 piglets-but because it wishes to have one which can be quarantine perfect and can allow it to undertake the technological advances in pig meat that we have become accustomed to seeing exhibited in the sheep industry, particularly at Collinsville by Mr Neil Garnett. Metro Meats therefore has formed a company called Metrotech. It is intended that this company should include representatives from the University of Adelaide along with those from Metro Meats in developing what it hopes will be a super pig for the Australian market.

The company has run into some difficulties because there is a great deal of concern in the region about a piggery of that magnitude. I am told by those who are responsible for treating the effluent outflow from this piggery that, with modern techniques, it is possible to get the effluent outflow down to the point at which it is almost possible to drink a glass of it at the end of the process and not be unduly affected. I have no intention of opening the piggery and testing the effluent by so doing. I do not know whether the honourable member for Parramatta is prepared to come into Wakefield and prove the point, but I do take the point that the company believes that it can treat this effluent outflow so that it will not be harmful to the environment or be unduly offensive.
An interesting aside is that since there has been some local resistance to this piggery an opportunity now exists for the piggery to be located on Commonwealth property--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. If he gets quickly to his feet he can continue, as no-one else has risen.

—I thank you for that consideration, Madam Speaker. I just wanted to go on to say that the opportunity exists for the piggery to be located on Commonwealth property as there is a property at Port Wakefield which runs down the coast adjacent to Two Wells and which is known as the Port Wakefield proof range. Should there continue to be difficulty in locating the piggery outside the proof range, then I look forward to the opportunity to have the piggery located within the proof range, at the Minister's discretion.
—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until 10 a.m. tomorrow.
